PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It gives me great pleasure to inform the Senate that, after a nationwide ballot of Australian Democrat members, Senator Meg Lees has been elected Leader of the Australian Democrats and Senator Natasha Stott Despoja has been elected Deputy Leader.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering block 3 of the amendments under the heading `Confirmation of Extinguishment' on running sheet 18. The question is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

(5) Schedule 1, item 9, page 11 (line 27) to page 12 (line 16), omit subsections (4) and (5).

TAB.EMPHASIS: Exclusion of acts benefiting Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders

PARA.TAB: (9) An act is not a previous exclusive possession act if it is:

TAB.TAB: (a) the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or

(12) Schedule 1, item 9, page 17 (after line 2), at the end of subsection (1), add:

PARA.TAB: ; and (d) to the extent that the act involves the grant of rights and interests that are not inconsistent with native title rights and interests in relation to the land or waters covered by the lease concerned, the rights and interests granted, and the doing of any activity in giving effect to them, prevail over the native title rights and interests but do not extinguish them.

INTERJECT.PARA: (12A) Schedule 1, item 9, page 17 (after line 22), after section 23H, insert:

PARA.TAB: In the case of a previous non-exclusive possession act to which subparagraph 23F(3)(c)(ii) applies:

TAB.TAB: (a) notice must be given, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, to any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters that will be affected by the act about the doing or proposed doing of the act, or acts of that class, in relation to the land or waters concerned; and

(45) Schedule 1, page 118 (after line 4), after item 12, insert:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 47A Reserves etc. covered by claimant applications

PARA.TAB: (1) This section applies if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a claimant application is made in relation to an area; and
(b) when the application is made:

(i) a freehold estate exists, or a lease is in force, over the area or the area is vested in any person, if the grant of the freehold estate or lease or the vesting took place under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(ii) the area is held on trust, or is reserved, for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; and
(c) when the application is made, one or more members of the native title claim group occupy the area.

PARA.TAB: (2) For all purposes under this Act in relation to the application, any extinguishment, of the native title rights and interests in relation to the area that are claimed in the application, by any of the following acts must be disregarded:

TAB.TAB: (a) the grant or vesting mentioned in subparagraph (1)(b)(i) or the creation of the trust or reservation mentioned in subparagraph (1)(b)(ii);
(b) the creation of any other prior interest in relation to the area, other than, in the case of an area held on trust as mentioned in subparagraph (1)(b)(ii), the grant of a freehold estate.
Note: The applicant will still need to show the existence of any connection with the land or waters concerned that may be required by the common law concept of native title.

PARA.TAB: (3) If the determination on the application is that the native title claim group hold the native title rights and interests claimed:

TAB.TAB: (a) the determination does not affect:
(i) the validity of the grant or vesting or of the creation of the trust or reservation; or
(ii) the validity of the creation of any other prior interest in relation to the area; or
(iii) any interest of the Crown in any capacity, or of any statutory authority, in any public works on the land or waters concerned; and
(b) the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the grant or vesting or the creation of the trust or reservation or any other prior interest.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exclusion of Crown ownership of natural resources

PARA.TAB: (4) For the purposes of this section, a reference to the creation of an interest in relation to an area does not include a reference to the creation of an interest that confirms ownership of natural resources by, or confers ownership of natural resources on, the Crown in any capacity.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 47B Vacant Crown land covered by claimant applications

PARA.TAB: (1) This section applies if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a claimant application is made in relation to an area; and
(b) when the application is made, the area is not:
(i) covered by a freehold estate or a lease; or

(ii) covered by a reservation, proclamation, declaration, condition, permission or authority, made or conferred by the Crown in any capacity, or by the making, amendment or repeal of legislation of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, under which the whole or a part of the land or waters in the area is to be used for public purposes or for a particular purpose; or
(iii) subject to a resumption process (see paragraph (5)(b)); and
(c) when the application is made, one or more members of the native title claim group occupy the area.

PARA.TAB: (2) For all purposes under this Act in relation to the application, any extinguishment, of the native title rights and interests in relation to the area that are claimed in the application, by the creation of any prior interest in relation to the area must be disregarded.

TAB.TAB: Note: The applicant will still need to show the existence of any connection with the land or waters concerned that may be required by the common law concept of native title.

PARA.TAB: (3) If the determination on the application is that the native title claim group hold the native title rights and interests claimed:

TAB.TAB: (a) the determination does not affect:
(i) the validity of the creation of any prior interest in relation to the area; or
(ii) any interest of the Crown in any capacity, or of any statutory authority, in any public works on the land or waters concerned; and
(b) the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the creation of any prior interest in relation to the area.

PARA.TAB: (4) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), if, after a lease covering an area expires or is terminated, the lease is renewed, or its term is extended, the area is taken to be covered by the lease during the period between the expiry or termination and the renewal or extension.
(5) For the purposes of this section:

TAB.TAB: (a) the creation of a prior interest in relation to an area does not include the creation of an interest that confirms ownership of natural resources by, or confers ownership of natural resources on, the Crown in any capacity; and
(b) an area is subject to a resumption process at a particular time (the test time ) if:
(i) all interests last existing in relation to the area before the test time were acquired, resumed or revoked by, or surrendered to, the Crown in any capacity; and
(ii) when that happened, the Crown had a bona fide intention of using the area for public purposes or for a particular purpose; and
(iii) the Crown still had a bona fide intention of that kind in relation to the area at the test time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what you basically did was read out the amendments on page 3 of the running sheet. The opposition does not have any problems with those. I hope they do not conflict with anything further in the debate; I do not think they do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating in the committee stages schedule 4 of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , which covers nearly eight per cent of Australia and lists those leases which have been advised as conferring exclusive possession and, therefore, where native title is unable to be claimed. The schedule includes all sorts of things—from Scouts halls to grazing homesteads and perpetual leases, but there are no pastoral leases in this schedule. There are some 15,000—nearly 80 per cent of the leases in Queensland—freehold perpetual leases that have been granted for ever and a day. If this schedule goes down, they will be subject to native title and all that implies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier of Queensland has worked very hard and assiduously to get these leases on. They are not, I repeat, a grazing lease; they are a perpetual lease. I would say that 80 per cent of Queensland graziers have this type of lease, some have dual ownership of this type of grazing lease. But most of the smaller holdings—the 20,000; 30,000; 40,000 acres—are these types of perpetual leases; the big properties are the grazing leases.

So if you draw a line from Dalby and out to Roma, most of the sheep country is covered by this type of lease. If this parliament were to let these people down—those who have been lulled into a false sense of security by the fact that the Premier of Queensland and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) have told them that their leases are safe—if today they find that they are pushed out of their safety zone, then you are going to hear a big cry from the bush.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) talked very smoothly about certainty and how native title is mostly about fishing and camping. Under these amendments, they will expose farmers to the greatest uncertainties by refusing to confirm that their leases reflect exclusive possession. We keep coming back to the underlying uncertainty: what is native title itself? It is very misleading of the Leader of the Opposition to say that native title is mostly about fishing and visiting small parts of a property.

Most claims I have seen have been for millions of acres, and many prominent native title crusaders have said that native title is a lot more than just going onto a property and fishing or getting a piece of wood for a didgeridoo. We have heard it is from housing to economic development. Some Aboriginal people have said that native title—and I think Senator Harradine agrees with this, which surprises me—is a better form of title than a lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a different title—more underlying.

—Senator Harradine corrects me and says that it is a different title and more underlying. Nevertheless, this uncertainty created by continually hearing that it is not just a visit to the property or going and getting a piece of wood for a didgeridoo. It is not just traditional pursuits. If that were the case, there would never be any opposition to people going on and moving around the properties. There never has been, and I do not think there ever would be. Even now, during this uncertainly of the times, I hear that Aboriginal people are still going onto the properties in Cape York.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important schedule because it covers most of the pastoral activity in Australia. I certainly hope we can rely on Senator Harradine's support to defeat this amendment relating to this schedule and back up what Kim Beazley said—that he would give certainty and that Aboriginal native title was really only about going on small parts of properties. If it were only that, as I said, there would be no problems with native title. But until we know what native title is, until we know that these schedules are excluded from claim, there will continue to be a huge amount of uncertainty out there. I would support the continuation of schedule 4 in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to say anything until Senator Boswell made some comments. I must say to my friend Senator Boswell that what he has been saying has unnecessarily and unforgivably caused grave concern amongst ordinary people, farmers, in the bush, particularly in Queensland. If he does not know what native title is, he has not read the Mabo judgment or the Wik judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter that, as I said, we in the parliament over the years should have been dealing with in statute law. Had we done that we would have been able to have certainty and the farmers of Australia, the miners of Australia, the people of Australia, including the indigenous people of Australia, would have had certainty. But we failed in that responsibility, and that responsibility was taken up by the courts as a result of an application by persons who knew that they had an underlying right to native title.

The High Court made the decisions. At the time, in 1993, I did say that the High Court had put us to shame for not doing what we as parliamentarians should have been doing over the years. I do not include in that everybody here. Those of us who were here are to blame. We then had to face the High Court's determination that terra nullius was a legal fiction. Arising from that, there was an underlying right to native title. Following Wik, at that time people did feel that pastoral leases extinguished native title. That was knocked into a cocked hat by the Wik decision.

And what are we about? It seems to me that some people are going around the place saying parliament is doing and imposing this, that and the other on pastoral leaseholders. We are not. We are trying to codify with some certainty—as much certainty as we possibly can—in this legislation what we believe and what appears to be the common law rights, in any event, of native title holders and of everybody else. We are trying to do it with some degree of justice and balance.

My staff get calls from worried pastoralists and their wives, crying over the phone and that sort of thing. That is totally unnecessary and I believe unforgivable. Those people have been unnecessarily upset because, when this legislation goes through, pastoralists will be able to do the same thing that they were able to do before. You have not read it if you think otherwise. They will be able to do the same things without having to negotiate as they are able to do now. If they want an upgrade, depending on how big the upgrade is, that could trigger the right to negotiate.

I say to Senator Boswell, through you, Madam Chairman: bear in mind that I come from the bush. I was raised in the bush and I was educated in my primary school in the bush. I know what it is like. I know what it is like to be on a farm where the mother is there with seven kids on her own. I know what persons may be feeling and the fear that is in the hearts of some of those women who are out on their own whilst their husbands are working elsewhere to make some money because the farm will not provide the necessary income.

I feel that to describe this legislation now as fit for the ash can is also absolutely unnecessary. What we have here is the Howard government bill—90 per cent. Let nobody forget that. I am prepared to take the flak for this. I took the decision rightly or wrongly some two weeks ago that I would adopt a minimalist position. The government is here to govern. It is trying to do a job. It is trying to codify as best it can what the High Court has said, and I was prepared to help that situation. My amendments, I hope, will improve it.

The cutting edge issue, I suppose, is the mining on pastoral leases, if you want to boil it down to that. As I said last night, that is a matter where I believe it is just not appropriate for indigenous native title holders to be able to have the right to negotiate when it comes to mining on crown land and not have the same right to negotiate when it comes to mining on their land, their rights coexisting with pastoral leaseholders. That is it in a nutshell.

Let us always remember, and I appeal to you to always understand this, that what Wik said really was that there could be coexistence of rights over a particular land—coexistence of native title rights with the rights of the leaseholders—but that the rights of the leaseholders and their interests prevail over the rights and interests of native title holders if the exercise of those rights interferes with pastoralists. That is it in a nutshell. The people I know out bush have coexisted with the Aboriginal people for years and years. They should not be concerned unnecessarily about this particular legislation. I was going to vote for the government on this schedule before you rose from your seat, Senator Bolkus, and I still am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak in this debate. In the last two hours last night I did not speak very much at all. I try not to react to Senator Boswell, but it is very difficult. It is very difficult because we had a member of the National Party yesterday saying that she would approve of pastoralists being armed with illegal weapons. I find this totally over the top. I want to know when the National Party, particularly in Queensland, is going to recognise that it actually governs for everybody and when we are going to stop having these kinds of comments made.

SPEECH.PARA: We had representatives of Aurukun, who are the Wik people, here all week in this parliament. Unfortunately the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was unable to see them. It would have put a human face on the debate for him, I think, if he had been able to meet with them. It just gets to me that we constantly allow people to run around in the media and to raise the temperature in this debate, as members of the National Party have done. And then we get a lecture from Senator Boswell this morning. Not only do we get a lecture, but we do not get from him any apology for those statements by De-Anne Kelly—no apology whatsoever.

The Wik people said, `We do not understand those comments. We do not have those problems with pastoralists. We are pastoralists ourselves,' those that have been allowed to be in Cape York. They said, `We do not understand that a representative in our government should be saying that people need to arm themselves with illegal weapons to defend themselves against our people. We are not like that.'

I understand why Senator Harradine feels strongly about this, because in this place we have tried. I have said a few things that I regret, but we are getting to the end of this debate and I just feel that it is about time we stopped this kind of language. I hope that when we go out of this place we are not going to have a repeat of it, more of this sort of language. I read in the paper this morning what Wendy Craik from the National Farmers Federation said. I do not think she knew what she was saying. I am sure it was not what she meant. She said, `Not all pastoralists are racists.' The obvious question is, `How many are?' I am sure she did not mean that, but that is what she said—`Not all pastoralists are racists.' I would not want to say any of them are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all Uniting Church ministers are racists.
—That is true. I am not sure how many are, but I am sure that there are some. This is the problem that we have. I was not going to speak but I felt I had to respond to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have a paper I have prepared, Native title claims over freehold land and exclusive possession tenure in Western Australia , incorporated in Hansard . I believe I have the agreement of the other side to do this, to save time. I also seek leave to table a number of documents which I have circulated in the chamber: Claim over private freehold ; Freehold claims: Bremer Bay, Western Australia ; Exmouth claims: Western Australia ; and Kalgoorlie: exclusive possession 99‐year leases .

—I have indicated that I have no problems with it. We are going through the paper to see what we have to respond to. In respect of the documents, I would like a bit longer before we give final approval for them to be tabled. We are still going through them at the moment. That is the ALP's position.

—I would like a little time to go through them. I would like to make a short statement in relation to them. We have debated a number of times the fact that, currently, a native title claim over freehold land does not mean a thing. The way claims are put in basically means that a person has to do the search and work out after that where freehold exists. It is not the requirement of those with freehold; you do not have to defend it, as some people have suggested. It does not actually prove anything. Certainly, we will be looking through these documents. They might help if people actually read the claims and get some advice on what the claims mean, but they do not actually prove your argument at all.

—I did this to avoid debate. These documents are claims, except for one, that have been accepted by the Native Title Tribunal. Many people under these claims have received letters and some of them are going through mediation. To say it does not affect them is not correct. I am not going to debate this. I have sought leave, to save time, to have a document incorporated and several others tabled. If that is not done I reserve my right to come in here and read every word. I seek leave to have the paper incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Native Title Claims over Freehold Land and Exclusive Possession Tenure in Western Australia

SPEECH.PARA: There are numerous examples of native title claims which have been accepted by the National Native Title Tribunal (NNTT) over freehold and exclusive possession leasehold tenure in Western Australia.

A number of these claims specifically include freehold granted after 1 January 1994 despite the fact that these grants were made as a result of land subdivisions subject to pre-existing larger freehold titles. There are several thousand titles of this type issued in WA each year.

All freehold in the South-West is subject of claims which means that, every time a subdivision occurs and a new freehold title is issued, that freehold is automatically under claim and the owners are parties to the claims process. All these claims will eventually have to be referred to the Federal Court as they will be unable to be resolved by mediation. This means that the freehold owners will be forced to defend their interests in court.

Invariably claims include freehold held by the state, government agencies and government trading enterprises. They also include freehold titles granted after 1 January 1994 even though these titles are created on land which had been previously private freehold and had been subdivided, or Crown freehold set aside as freehold land for many years, in some cases more than fifty.

There are over 40,000 such titles in the Perth metropolitan region alone. Every time one of these blocks of land is sold to a private party, it remains claimed and the private owner again becomes automatically a party to the native title claim process.

One example of this problem is the recent sale of homes in the North West town of Exmouth. The land involved was acquired by the Western Australian Government from pastoral leases in 1963 in an agreement between the State Government, the Commonwealth Government and the Government of the United States of America for the purposes of constructing the Exmouth tracking station and the town of Exmouth to house and provide services for US servicemen and other residents.
The land was subdivided in the 1960s for housing and servicing (road, amenities, community facilities).

As part of the agreement for returning land to the State in 1992, each lot was to be offered for public sale. Land was returned to the Western Australian Government, including freehold land held by the Commonwealth, and passed back into the Crown estate before being offered for sale.
94 Homes have been sold and new titles have been issued to the purchasers. These titles are now subject to a native title claim which has been accepted by the NNTT.

Another example of freehold being claimed in the South West region of Western Australia is where the holders of conditional purchase lease or a war service lease exercise their obligation to convert the lease to freehold. Since 1994 over 200 leases have been converted and the owners have been issued with freehold titles. All of these freehold titles are subject to accepted native title claims despite the State Government providing the NNTT with the details of the conversions.

Title holders have been receiving notices form the NNTT to attend mediation conferences. Some farmers have had to interrupt their harvesting activities to attend these conferences in the last 3 weeks.

There are also 33 freehold titles subject to multiple claims in the Bremer Bay Townsite in Western Australia. In this case the land had previously been subject to conditional purchase leases which the Crown acquired and developed as a residential subdivision. The land was sold in October 1995. The purchasers have all been advised by the NNTT that their titles are under claim and they are to attend mediation conferences.

This was done despite numerous submissions from the State Government seeking to have these titles excluded from the claim. Mediation has not been successful and now the title holders will be required to defend their title in the Federal Court. Some have deferred plans to build homes on the land because of the claims.
Prior to being subdivided and developed, this land was the subject of a conditional purchase lease which carries a legal right of conversion to freehold.

In addition to claims over freehold there are also claims over residential lease hold in various parts of the state. These are residential leases which have been granted with exclusive possession. One such example is the 99 year residential leasehold in Kalgoorlie which is under claim.
Prepared by Senator Winston Crane
Senator for Western Australia
5 December 1997

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the other documents.
—I would like to defer the decision on that for another half hour or so whilst we have a chance to look at them. On the face of it, there is probably no problem; it is just the normal thing to do.
—At this stage, leave is not granted.

—I would like to ask the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) a question and perhaps get some instructions. You are talking about claims against freehold land as if that were a unique situation in the law. Can you have claims made in respect of planning schemes or by mortgagors or mortgagees? Can you have claims made by tenants and leaseholders? Have there been cases of such claims over the years?
—How about compulsory acquisition?

—Yes—compulsory acquisition and rights that a mortgagee or a mortgagor might have or that a tenant might have. Are such claims made? Is there any other example where, in reference to the disputes that might arise over land, parliament has prescribed certain properties over which claims cannot be made? Is there any example of that in the past? I will sit down because I know everybody wants to get on with the Christmas cheer so that we can say nice things to each other across the chamber. I know that everybody is waiting to tell each other how much we love each other so we can go away happily at Christmas time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to be brief. Obviously there are legal disputes over property transfers, contracts and other things as part of our general law all the time—landlords trying to get rid of tenants and tenants complaining about landlords and whether a title has been effectively transferred and all those sorts of things. But we are dealing here with a completely different situation. This is the interaction of a statutory title issued by the Crown purporting to grant exclusive possession to the titleholder being challenged by a person exercising what they believe to be their common law property rights in relation to that exclusive statutory tenure and all the consequences that flow from that. That is the whole point about native title.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why it is obviously difficult for most Australians to comprehend. Generally we do not have a concept any more of common law property rights as such, exercisable in the way that native title is. Our land title system is statutory. The interrelationship of that common law title, which is not defined and has to be determined on a case‐by-case basis based on the traditional law and custom of the people who make the claim, and the statutory title that has been granted over the land is the essence of the issue. If you have claims, as is happening at least in relation to public freehold, what is the relationship between the statutory title which purports to grant exclusive possession to the title holder when a common law claim is made seeking to exercise native title rights on that property? That is the issue that is being addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be my last question. What I am putting is that, whether it is native title, the Torrens scheme or whatever, the concept behind it is a concept of tenure. That means that in the relationship between the person who wants to have some right over the land and the land itself there is no idea of absolute ownership of the land. That concept of tenure has not been changed and could not be changed, I would have thought, because it is the concept behind common law and the statutory law. In this case, it seems to me—and I seek a comment on this—that that concept of tenure is not changed by the common law or by native title pursued according to common law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole point of Mabo was an acceptance of the acquisition of sovereignty by the crown, but that it is not until the crown exercises that sovereignty that native title is necessarily extinguished. It is when the crown exercises that sovereignty in such a way as to grant exclusive possession by virtue of its acquisition of the sovereignty that has the extinguishing effect. As Brennan makes clear, there is no reversion to the native title; there is a reversion to the crown because of the crown's acquisition. That is where some of the legal confusion enters into it.

—Minister, in relation to this bizarre schedule 4 list, can you advise the committee why the rights and obligations of the grantees were not identified in the legislation, considering you said it was thought of very carefully and there were lots of months to think about it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might address the issue of how schedule 4 was put together because it is obviously of some concern to the other parties. It is, as I think we have stated before, a schedule containing leases which the Commonwealth government considers on the basis of the common law of conferred exclusive possession on the lessee and, therefore, as a result of Mabo and Wik, have extinguished native title. We did it on the basis, as I said before, of a conservative independent legal analysis undertaken by a professor of property law from the University of Sydney and officers of the Attorney‐General's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: We have rejected a number of the proposed state and territory leases which we were not satisfied were grants of exclusive possession. If there was any doubt, it was not put on the list. It contains basically specific types of residential, commercial, community purpose and agricultural leases. There are no pastoral leases in the schedule nor are there lesser interests, such as licences or permits, and mining leases are specifically excluded.

We did take the draft schedule, equally and at the same time, to indigenous and farming representatives, who were briefed on it and were invited to examine and discuss it with us before any final determination of it was made. We have gone through what I believe to be a quite exhaustive process in ensuring that this schedule is independently assessed on a legal basis and that we have adopted an extremely conservative approach. It covers only leases in those particular categories and those leases cover 7.7 per cent of Australia. It leaves open for native title claims 79 per cent of Australia.

We believe it is important that the parliament confirm the fact that exclusive possession has been granted in relation to these leases and, therefore, native title is extinguished. If you do not say that and you say that native title may have survived on these leases and that they are all the same, then all of those 60,000 lessees who have grants of exclusive possession are open to native title claim and potentially every one of them is subject to a determination in court as to whether or not exclusive possession has been granted.

The legal advice we have, as I said—independently assessed by a separate professor of law at the University of Sydney—is that they grant exclusive possession, therefore, the prospects of native title surviving are, in our view, zero. But if you leave them open to be tested, you leave open to the courts potentially 60,000 case-by-case determinations as to whether or not a grant of exclusive possession has been granted, when that is clear.

To us it seems much better to have the energy, resources and time of this nation devoted to determining the existence of native title on the 79 per cent of Australia on which we know it may have survived—that is, all pastoral leases, vacant crown land and Aboriginal land. So the resources of all of us involved in this process are devoted to seeking those determinations. As a government we are devoting the resources to seeking those determinations. We have absolutely no difficulty with those determinations being made and we hope they will be made. We applaud the Hope Vale agreement which will result in the first determined native title being exercised on the mainland of Australia. But we do believe that, in the interests of certainty, these exclusive possession leases ought to have their exclusive possession confirmed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you did say, `If there was any doubt,' and you have mentioned some people who have one opinion. I believe dozens of commentators over the last few months have definitely put doubt in relation to the extinguishment principle applying to community purpose leases. When you say, `If there was any doubt,' is it not the case that crown to crown grants are currently under category D of the existing act—that is, they are in the non-extinguishment principle? When you say, `If there was any doubt,' surely the wording of the current act does provide sufficient doubt and they should not be on this list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth putting on the record that probably one of the most unrecognised aspects of the Wik debate is the fact that the Wik people have not as yet had their rights to coexist on the land confirmed. The Wik case confirmed that a pastoral lease did not necessarily extinguish native title, but it went on to say that, for the purposes of the particular claim in question, the Wik people had to pursue their claim on the basis of the individual leases involved in their situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to put that on the record in the context of this debate because the government is going down a road which is fundamentally flawed. It is not looking at the individual leases, which is what the Wik decision demanded should happen in the case of the Wik people. It is not doing that. It is going to categories of leases, it is going to instruments at state law and it has asked all the state governments, as I said last night, to produce their shopping lists of what provisions, what categories of leases and so on should be covered.

Within that collection of shopping lists we have already found some leases that you could say did not necessarily extinguish native title. We also found historic leases, ghost leases, leases that had expired. We are also in no real position to make an assessment as to whether all those categories actually do confer exclusive possession. To the extent that there is any vagueness, we do not know that the actual leases pursuant to those categories confer exclusive possession.

We are doing here precisely what the High Court in Wik refused to do. That was to make a general assessment of people's rights on the basis of a categorisation of a lease. They will probably have to go through processes for another five to 10 years. What this particular legislation will do is cut away their rights to pursue claims under the causes of action they have instituted already. One of the cruel things about this particular measure is that the Wik people, having won that case last year, will probably have their rights rendered ineffectual because of the provisions, particularly in this part of the legislation.

Let us get it on the record that the government is being a bit fast and loose with this. If they say, `It takes so many resources to get it right. We think we have some certainty with what we are putting up,' and they cannot get it right with the resources of a Commonwealth government and all the state and territory governments to go through the instruments, how do you think the claimants, the rep bodies and their representatives will be able to do it within the timetables and processes laid down by this legislation?

We really are tilting the balance in such a way here that the people involved, whether it is the Wik or other claimants, have Buckley's chance of having the resources, at the first point, to be able to pursue with any degree of certainty their rights. If the government cannot do it, how can we expect them to do it. This is really one of the most unjust parts of the legislation in that those who were celebrating this time last year in front of the High Court will have to swallow the bitter effects of this bill and these particular uncontrolled, ill thought out, fundamentally flawed extinguishment provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to take up that point. I wonder whether Senator Bolkus could explain to the committee how the Wik people will be prevented by this schedule from pursuing their claim. That is a quite extraordinary statement. I wonder whether he could explain what he means.

—There is one particular lease that you can point to straight away and that is the Mitchelton pastoral lease. It is a dead lease. The advice I have is that it is one of those leases that could very well confirm extinguishment in respect of the people involved. That advice has come from one of their solicitors. They are concerned about that. I think they have a right to be concerned about it. That is one instance off the cuff. The advice I have is that the Mitchelton pastoral lease is one that is relevant to their case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point to the committee that there are no pastoral leases, historic or otherwise, on the schedule. The leases in the Wik case are not affected by this schedule at all. There is not one current or historic lease on the schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —You know quite well that it is not just the schedule that extinguishes.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Minchin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the extinguishment provisions. 23G of the extinguishment provisions does cover the sorts of interests that we are talking about here and does cover pastoral leases. Do not sectionalise the debate and say that this is just the schedule. The schedule is one part of the problem. The other part is that which we are attacking through our amendments—amendment 15, for instance. All of it together has an effect which does extinguish in respect of the Wik people in particular. 23G is the provision which deals with the confirmation of partial extinguishment of native title by previous non‐exclusive possession acts. What the people will probably be left with is merely a remnant right to hunt and fish.
—But no claim over waters, remember.
—Sorry, maybe just to hunt, but not with guns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus moved from a discussion of the schedule to a discussion of the confirmation of partial extinguishment. Can I just say on that subject, because no doubt it will come up, that it is correct to say that the confirmation of partial extinguishment provisions do not reflect the decision in Wik.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear from the majority judgments in Mabo that native title is extinguished by an unqualified grant of an inconsistent estate in land by the Crown or other inconsistent dealings with land by the Crown as stated by Brennan, Deane, Gaudron and Toohey. That was confirmed by a number of the justices in Wik—Gaudron in the majority judgment, and Brennan J, with whom Dawson and McHugh agreed. In particular, Justice Kirby, one of the majority, made it clear in his judgment in Wik that if there is an inconsistency between the interests of the lessee and those of native title holders, the native title is extinguished to the extent of the inconsistency. The bill implements that exactly.

It is only to the extent that there is an inconsistency with the exercise of the native title rights that there is an extinguishment. That is the common law. All it means at the upmost is a right of exclusive possession. Every native title up to that can survive.

BREAK.PARA: We have said in our other amendments, which we are either coming to or have dealt with that, that where Aboriginal people are on a reserve or occupying vacant crown land over which a past lease has affected either partial or full extinguishment, it is to be disregarded for the purposes of determining the native title claims. I think it is only fair and proper to set aside the common law effect of that past grant in order that Aboriginal people currently occupying that land, either by reserve or vacant crown land, can make a full native title claim regardless of the past extinguishing effect of previous grants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister whether the wording on pages 109 to 111 of the Native Title Act is familiar to him. Section 229(2)(b) states under category A:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the grant is not:
(i) a grant by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity. . .
Section 230(d) states under category B:
. . . the grant is not:
(i) a grant by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity. . .
Does the minister agree that that makes Crown to Crown grants, category D past acts, subject to extinguishment under the existing act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am familiar with the past act provisions in 229. What occurred is that, by dint of the parliament at that time, there was a proposition that a validated grant by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown or a statutory authority of the Crown was subject to the non-extinguishment principles.

SPEECH.PARA: Again you had this extraordinary anomalous situation where a valid Crown to Crown grant of freehold at common law extinguishes native title, but validated ones by dint of this act do not. We think that is a hopeless situation. All it does is invite all the relevant authorities to assert that they are valid grants.

BREAK.PARA: We think that is a hopeless anomaly. We think that, as a matter of common law, a grant of freehold is a grant of freehold and a grant of freehold extinguishes native title. To try to draw a distinction between the ownership of the title is to again invite a legal nightmare. The fact of a grant of freehold is the extinguishing act, and it is certainly our view that confirmation of extinguishment by a grant of freehold should be made. To try to draw some legal distinction between the owner of the title, whether it is the CSIRO or some other statutory authority instead of you or me, is legally unsustainable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of Crown to Crown grants has obviously caused the minister to clutch at straws. He is using the word `freehold' fairly loosely here. Quite clearly, this is one area where you are nailed to the post, Minister. You have quite clearly extinguished areas of Australia which are not currently extinguished for native title.

SPEECH.PARA: You may have chosen your words carefully when you made media releases saying, `We will not extinguish pastoral grants', and we have lots of criticism of the way you said that. But here quite clearly are bucket loads of extinguishment, including the Worrowa title claim which was defence land that is hardly ever used by defence and for which there is absolutely zero need to extinguish native title. Could you please explain why you have been misleading the Australian community about your non-bucket loads of extinguishment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are confirming the common law that grants of freehold extinguish native title. These are confirmation provisions seeking to confirm that, where freehold has been granted, native title is extinguished. That is what we are doing in these provisions. As to any grant of freehold, we have accepted grants made by or under legislation in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people where they wish to claim native title, but it is clear that a grant of freehold extinguishes native title. All our provisions do is confirm that.
—I ask the minister: is it a fact that under 23G of your confirmation provisions historic leases would have the effect of confirming that a claimant cannot get exclusive possession?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the confirmation provisions in 23G is that, where there has been a grant that is inconsistent with native title, then native title is extinguished to that extent. In other words, the only native title right that could be extinguished by that definition is exclusive possession.

SPEECH.PARA: You will have seen from what I said of Brennan yesterday the enormous legal complexity of any notion of revival. We have stated in our amendments—which we have yet to formally adopt—that, where a past extinguishing act has occurred on land occupied by Aboriginal people, either by a dedicated reserve or land which has reverted to vacant crown land which they occupy, then any previous extinguishing act, either partial or full, is to be disregarded for the purposes of the native title claim.

We believe that will remove this problem from Aboriginal people who have the obvious prospects of being able to succeed in a native title claim because they occupy the land. Any suggestion that extinguishment—even partial—is to be ignored entirely across all of Australia is again to invite a legal nightmare of the revival of native title on a rolling basis.

I know it is expressed in legalese, but Chief Justice Brennan, in confirming what Gareth Evans said, that extinguishment means extinguishment, did point to the significant legal problems, and we are coming to this in terms of the permanency argument. But, if the prospect of ongoing revival is to be sustained, as he says, you:
. . . create problems of title not easy to resolve. If the holders of native title were recognised as the owners of an estate in remainder in the land—
that is, it reverts or the title revives—

could the priority right to a selection enjoyed by a lessee be exercised? And would the holders of native title have become liable to pay for the improvements to the land effected during the expired lease?

What happens if there are millions of dollars of property improvements on the land? Are the native title holders now liable for those? These are very significant legal questions that are raised in practice by the suggestion being made. I again quote Brennan:

To what extent was the discretion to enforce a forfeiture against a lessee affected by the supposed existence of native title in the land? In the unusual event of the determination in fee simple, would the land revert to the Crown or would it be taken by the holders of native title?
He says:

These questions indicate some of the problems that would arise . . . In my opinion, the common law could not recognise native title once the Crown alienated a freehold or leasehold estate . . . the common law was powerless to recognise native title as reviving after the determination of a pastoral lease . . .

Those are powerful injunctions to us about the enormous legal problems that will flow from any suggestion of revival except in the particular circumstances where we have said, `Disregard the previous extinguishing act.' I think you are inviting years of enormous legal uncertainty by anything other than what we have presented.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that Senator Minchin talks about problems if you do not permanently extinguish, he in fact acknowledges that there is capacity for revival of native title. That is the point in this debate. The point in this debate is that the court has actually left the issue undetermined. That is why you have just made a five‐minute speech telling us what you are concerned about if native title were to revive. What we are concerned about is that we should allow native title to revive. With 23G, with other provisions, with a capacity to quickly roll over crown land, with a capacity to quickly issue permits, with a capacity to renew without consultation with indigenous claimants—all these provisions together—the result is that those who may technically be able to seek exclusive possession will very easily by the ready application of these provisions be denied such capacity. As I said just a moment ago, you have just confirmed that native title in your consideration and in the view of the government may possibly revive in certain circumstances, otherwise you would not be moving this provision. That is precisely the point you are making. You have to move this provision. You have to get it carried, because you want certainty. To the degree that you want certainty you acknowledge directly that there is some uncertainty as to what happens on the expiration of the interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are confirming what we understand to be the common law as said by Chief Justice Brennan. We believe it is important to confirm that that is the common law, because otherwise it will be asserted by some that it can revive and we will have endless litigation over that issue, while we believe clearly on the basis of Mabo and Wik that as a matter of common law native title is extinguished. Your own Attorney‐General, foreign minister, Leader of the Government in the Senate, now deputy leader, Gareth Evans, said that extinguishment means extinguishment; it cannot revive. That was clearly the then government's view when it passed this act in 1993. I do not know what has happened to now lead you down the path of irresponsibly seeking to change that position. It is impossible for the common law to recognise that sort of revival, as Chief Justice Brennan said. So we are not saying that. We say that is the common law. We say it needs to be confirmed, because otherwise it will be asserted to the contrary and we will have endless litigation for years on end.

—Minister, you cannot back your horses in terms of High Court judgments. You might want to do what Chief Justice Brennan wanted to do, but the good judge was actually in the minority. The common law does not reflect Justice Brennan's position on this point. It is like backing the second horse in the Melbourne Cup and claiming it has won. It has not. If you really want to reflect the common law, you reflect the opinion of the majority on the High Court, not Chief Justice Brennan in this instance, since his argument was not persuasive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That was precisely the point that I had been going to make since the minister quoted Chief Justice Brennan last night. Chief Justice Brennan was very eloquent in what he said, but he was in the minority. What we have to be careful about here is to make absolutely sure that we are taking action which does not in fact impair the common law rights of the native title holders. I am sure that that is the government's view, and I understand what the government is doing. But you can quote Toohey, who was the lead judge in the majority. He is quite clear about the matter. I am not going through it all but he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I have concluded that none of the grants necessarily extinguished "all incidents of Aboriginal title", no further question arises in these appeals as to any concept of the suspension of native title rights during the currency of the grants.

So he used the word `suspension'. I put to you, Minister, that there may be a point to having 237A but there is no point in having that whilst 23G is in its current terms. Senator Bolkus referred to 23G, and that is the crux of the matter. If you look at 23G—and I might just do this and I will not have to repeat it when I move my amendments—you are using the word `extinguish'. It says:
Subject to subsection (2), if a previous non‐exclusive possession act . . . is attributable to the Commonwealth:

PARA.TAB: (a) the act extinguishes any native title rights and interests in relation to the land or waters covered by the lease concerned to the extent that the act involves the grant of rights and interests that are inconsistent with the native title rights and interests; and

(b) any native title rights and interests in relation to the land or waters covered by the lease concerned are extinguished to the extent that they confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the land or waters to the exclusion of all others;

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I am making is that, as with the negotiations concerning the Native Title Bill in 1993, the question of extinguishment is centrally important for the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . It is centrally important. That is agreed all round. At page 48 of the government's explanatory memorandum this is noted:

Some of the Justices in Wik specifically left open the question whether native title is permanently extinguished by the grant of inconsistent pastoral lease rights, or whether the native title rights can revive on the expiration of the pastoral lease.

You noted in your explanatory memorandum that particular fact, that the court has left it open. Therefore, the common law is open on that particular question. That is why it is so important that we try to get it right. You also say in the explanatory memorandum:
The policy of the Government is to provide that extinguishment is permanent.

Commonwealth legislation should, where practical, maintain common law rights and the possibility of the ongoing recognition rather than peremptory extinguishment. What I am doing in my amendments is being consistent with the Wik decision, maintaining the possibility that native title may be merely suspended rather than extinguished forever to the extent of the inconsistency, that is, the pastoral leaseholders' rights prevail over the native title holders' rights to the extent of whatever the inconsistency of the latter is with the former.

There is every possibility, I believe, that native title was only suspended for the duration of the lease. Legislative action taken to extinguish rather than to suspend potentially surviving rights falls short, I believe, of the fair and decent balance which all parties, including the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), are seeking.

I have had another think about this. I put it to you that the word `suspended' instead of `extinguished' could be put in proposed section 23G to make that clear. You may well have a point with 237A but, whilst you have 237A, that is going to be read down to apply. The word `extinguish' in 23G is going to be read in conjunction with 237A, and I do not think that is appropriate at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to briefly respond to that. Brennan was in the minority on the question of whether a native title was necessarily extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease. That was the case. The case did not turn on the issue of the effect of extinguishment. The question was whether the grant of the lease necessarily extinguished native title. Mabo had said that leaseholds, the grant of a lease, necessarily extinguishes native title. In Wik, 4:3, they decided the grant of a pastoral lease does not necessarily do so—it may, but you have to examine the terms of every lease to work out whether the rights granted under that particular lease extinguish the native title.

SPEECH.PARA: So the High Court has not decided that native title can revive. Brennan, in his minority judgment saying that pastoral leases do necessarily extinguish native title, went on to state the law as we understood it to be arising out of Mabo—that is, once extinguished, always extinguished. That was the point. They used the word `extinguish' through Mabo and Wik, all of them, quite deliberately.

What Toohey was talking about was that, where the native title rights are not extinguished but can survive, they survive subject to the rights of the pastoralist. In other words, their exercise, even though they are not necessarily inconsistent, may survive and may, therefore, be treated as being suspended, I suppose, while the consistent rights are being exercised. Toohey says in his judgment:
It is that inconsistency—
that is, where rights that are granted are inconsistent—
that renders the native title rights unenforceable at law and in that sense extinguished.

He was then basically saying that, if the two can coexist, no question of implicit extinguishment arises and it is implicit extinguishment with which these peoples are concerned. So he is saying that you have to draw the distinction between rights granted that are inconsistent with native title. Where that is the case, as Toohey says `extinguishment', where they are not inconsistent but can both survive, it is what he describes as suspension. While the consistent rights are being exercised, you have to have in law some sort of relationship and, as the majority said, where consistent rights are being exercised, the statutory rights of the pastoralist prevail over the common law right of the native title holder.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely why I am suggesting the use of the word `suspension' in 23G. I take the point. I see what you have quoted Toohey as saying. That is true. That is precisely why I want to have `suspended' there. What else are you going to say? You cannot say it is extinguished. If you are going to have the definition in the legislation in 237 as, `The word extinguish, in relation to native title, means permanently extinguish the native title . . . to avoid any doubt,' you should be using `suspension' instead of `extinguish'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry to labour this point, but, in effect, we are taking the Toohey doctrine—certainly confirmed by Kirby and the three others. As it says in 23G(1)(a):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the act extinguishes any native title rights and interests in relation to the land or waters covered by the lease concerned to the extent that the act involves the grant of rights and interests that are inconsistent with the native title rights and interests;

So, to the extent that they are inconsistent, as stated by Toohey J., they are unenforceable at law and are extinguished. To the extent that the native title rights and interests are not inconsistent, they survive. But, in relation to all our pastoral lease provisions, they are subject to the rights of the pastoralist. They can be exercised and they survive, but they are subject to the rights of the pastoralist.

23G merely confirms what is evident, basically, from Toohey, that is, where there is an inconsistent grant, extinguishment occurs. It is a confirmation of what we describe as partial extinguishment. Whatever particular rights granted under the lease are inconsistent with the continued existence of native title rights, extinguishment occurs, as he states.

23G leaves entirely to the courts the question of which native title rights and interests are inconsistent with the rights granted under the lease. That is a matter for the courts entirely. All we are talking about is what happens once the court finds an inconsistency, and then the doctrine espoused by Toohey, Kirby and the rest is triggered—that is, it is extinguishment. It is entirely for the courts to determine the inconsistency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the whole point. If they revive when the lease runs out, what happens then? You are saying that the native title rights and interests are extinguished over that piece of land where there is a leasehold. You are saying they are extinguished to the extent that they are inconsistent with the rights and interests of the pastoralists. That is true; that is the law.

SPEECH.PARA: You are saying that is extinguishment, but what happens when the lease is renewed? How can you say those interests over that piece of land—say, fishing, hunting, camping, gathering or whatever—are gone forever? They are not. They do revive if there is a change in the terms of the lease and there is not the inconsistency between the rights and interests of the pastoral leaseholders and the rights and the rights and interests of the Aboriginal people, the native title holders. You cannot just use the word `extinguishment' there. What I am putting to you is that the better word there is `suspension'. That does not interfere at all with what you are doing. It may well be that under those circumstances I could see my way clear to vote for 237A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to that in relation to the issue of vesting. Is it not the case that the Mabo judgment quite clearly stated that vesting does not per se extinguish native title? Yet in your bill you said, `it consists of the grant or vesting of any of the following', including things like residential lease and community purposes lease. You have used the common law. You are ignoring the Native Title Act 1993. You say, `That uncertainty I am putting away,' but if the Mabo judgment clearly said that vesting—simply setting aside land for a purpose—does not per se extinguish native title, what on earth are you doing?
—I am not sure that I understood the question.

—The Mabo judgment clearly indicated that vesting of land did not per se extinguish native title—that is, setting aside land for a certain purpose did not of itself, and should not of course, extinguish native title. We do not know, you do not know, nobody knows, what is going to happen in the future, whether that reserved land is going to be used for the purpose for which it was simply set aside. Why have you caused the setting aside of land to be the basis of extinguishment? Whilst you are at it, can you please let me know on what basis the 800 Crown to Crown grants in Western Australia that have been squirreled away over the last three years have been made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a confusion here between reserves and vesting. Land vested for an exclusive possession purpose extinguishes native title. That is absolutely clear. It is an alienation by the Crown for an exclusive possession purpose. That is different to a reserve and it depends on what the land is reserved for. If it is reserved for a national park, there is no reservation for an exclusive possession so it does not extinguish. I think there is a confusion there on your part. What was the question about 800 Crown to Crown grants in Western Australia?

—I wanted you to see if you could provide some information on that. I have been given to understand that around 800 Crown to Crown grants have been squirreled away by the Western Australian government over the past three years, perhaps waiting for this moment. Can you tell me what the nature of those Crown to Crown grants would be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are asserting that the Western Australian government has squirreled away something of which I have no knowledge. So I am simply unable to answer your question until I have more information.

—Just following on from what Senator Harradine said about taking 23H with 23G, which talks about preserving common law rights, or equity rights for that matter, in land and what that might otherwise affect, aren't you really trying to get to the point in some ways that Senator Harradine is talking about—that you do not want to extinguish rights permanently if that would be unjust? Perhaps another word instead of `extinguishment' might get over that, such as `suppression' or the word Senator Harradine uses. It does seem that, if you take 23G and 23H together, you are trying to do something like Senator Harradine's proposal in any event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the court that used the term `extinguishment', not `suppression'. Extinguishment means extinguishment. We have seen from Toohey, Brennan and the rest how they interpret extinguishment and inconsistency and inconsistency leading to extinguishment. I draw your attention to our amendment, which adds to 23G a paragraph (d), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to the extent that the act involves the grant of rights and interests that are not inconsistent with native title rights and interests in relation to the land or waters covered by the lease concerned, the rights and interests granted, and the doing of any activity in giving effect to them, prevail over the native title rights and interests but do not extinguish them.

So we just want to make absolutely clear by saying this that all those rights and interests that are not by definition a matter of law as stated by Toohey are inconsistent. Again, that is a matter for the courts, not this parliament. Those do not extinguish but just restate the Wik position prevailing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I have one point that I would like to add in respect of the government's amendments. It has not been raised before, but it relates to amendment No. 5. Arising from what I say, I would like to defer consideration of amendment No. 5 until later on in the voting process. What amendment No. 5 seeks to do is to delete (4) and (5) of 23B. It does so to redress that the, as we are told, unintended consequence of the government's amendments which would ensure that native title could be extinguished on national parks and conservation reserves. The government is seeking to redress that situation to ensure that 23B does not have that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are concerned about is that, even if you were to remove 23B(4) and (5), you would still have 23B(3) there. We are asking the government to consider removing (3) as well. Our concern is that the only real effect that (3) may have is that native title may be extinguished over land or waters vested in bodies which expressly or impliedly have a right to exclusive possession conferred. The only direct effect of that would be to extend what is taken to amount to exclusive possession.

You may have a situation, for instance, where land is reserved for government purposes, for defence purposes. A licence or a permit is given in respect of occupation. If a right to exclusive possession can be inferred from all the circumstances of that licence, permit or other interest, then subsection (3) will affect extinguishment. We are concerned that subsection (3) is so vaguely worded that, in order to achieve your stated objective of allowing claims in respect of national parks and conservation reserves, you may have to delete that as well and maybe amend it.

I flag that at this particular stage. I think the government's advisers should take a few moments to consider the point we raise. In any event, we would like the government to consider moving amendment No. 5 to delete not just 23B(4) and (5) but also (3). If our officers can actually discuss this during the next 15 or 20 minutes, we may not have to move a further amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you are concerned about the word `impliedly'. If there is a vesting of a right of exclusive possession, that is, as a matter of law, no different from the grant of a right of exclusive possession. In terms of `impliedly', I suppose it is ultimately challengeable in the court that the necessary implication is not there. We certainly do not see any reason to delete that provision.
—I ask you, Minister, to see if your officers can consider deleting the word `impliedly'. That might satisfy the concern that we have.

—The legal advice is that it is often the case, even in freehold, that you must examine all the terms of the grant to determine that exclusive possession has been granted. Sometimes these things, because they were not forecasting native title, do not expressly say that it is a grant of exclusive possession. You have to construct that. Of course, that is what the courts do. So we do think you have to leave the word `impliedly', otherwise it could be inoperative. It still remains the case that it can be judicially heard. You can challenge the provision on the basis that there is no implied conferring of exclusive possession, but it is the case that even grants of freehold sometimes do not expressly `confer' exclusive possession.

—Minister, can you confirm, though, that the intention of the government is to ensure that the capacity to claim native title is not to be extinguished in respect of national parks and conservation reserves in the circumstances provided by this particular provision?
—Yes, that is our intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what the minister has basically indicated is that, when they are not sure, instead of saying, `Where there is any doubt, we have extinguished,' what he has just said is, `Where we are not sure, we will extinguish.' That does seem to be the case. He said the uncertainty is creating the need to extinguish, and that is certainly not what he has been saying in the media.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly in this debate it is coming out that, where the common law judgment left it open where the previous act clarified—Senator Harradine even voted in 1993 that Crown to Crown grants, for instance, do not extinguish native title—but where the government said there is uncertainty—that is, where they have not checked to find out whether or not extinguishment applies—they are saying, with total injustice, with a stroke of the pen, `We're not going to bother checking. We're not going to look at these in their reality. We're simply going to extinguish.' How can you justify that?
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 9, page 16 (line 24), omit "extinguishes", substitute "suspends".
(3) Schedule 1, item 9, page 16 (line 30), omit "extinguished", substitute "suspended".
(4) Schedule 1, item 9, page 17 (line 1), omit "extinguishment", substitute "suspension".

PARA.TAB: Note: The heading to section 23G is altered by omitting "partial extinguishment " and substituting "suspension ".

SPEECH.PARA: I am most concerned that the word `suspend' be included in that particular area of 23G as per my amendments. As I indicated to the government, I would hope that they could see their way clear to support that. The word `suspension', as Senator Cooney mentioned, is one of those words that is more appropriate, having regard to what 23G does. It is not going to make much difference at all on the ground, but I think it is an important principle that those words be used rather than `extinguishment'. I would hope the government might support the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, for the purposes of clarification, you said you were moving your amendments Nos 2 to 4. Has No. 1 been dealt with?
—No, I think the government has an amendment to No. 1 which is on a slightly different matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the committee further on this, but these are moving in a positive direction. I think, quite frankly, the best way would have been to oppose the schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you look at the next block of amendments, 211 deletes the definition of extinguishment as permanent. That should probably be handled together with the amendments below that—that is, 15, 215, 216 and 352. Those amendments delete division 2B, delete section 249A in respect of community purpose lease definition, delete the schedule of interest and delete schedule 4 itself. What I am suggesting is that we move them altogether. As indicated by Senator Margetts, our preferred position obviously was to delete these provisions. Senator Harradine has moved an amendment, and had it carried, that instead of `extinguishment' we are talking about `suspension'. I must say I prefer the word `suspension' to `suppression'. It is a much more desirable and appropriate reflection of what happens. I do not need to say anything else about these amendments. We have had this discussion already.
—Senator Bolkus, just to clarify, the effect of the amendments you are proposing is to oppose items. Therefore, the question will be that the schedule stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make the point that you would have to put the two motions that the schedule stand as printed separately. You cannot put them together.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 45 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that schedule 1, item 9, division 2B, item 49, sections 249A and 249C and schedule 4 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (216A) Schedule 1, item 49, page 133 (lines 2 to 9), omit subsections (1) and (2), substitute:

TAB.TAB: A Scheduled interest is anything set out in Schedule 1, other than:
(a) a mining lease; or
(b) an interest, in relation to land or waters, of a type declared by a regula tion for the purposes of this paragraph not to be a Scheduled interest.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the opposition amendment which has the effect of addressing the problems with the regulation power that the government seeks to give itself. As we said in the debate, we not only have a schedule, but we also have in the legislation a capacity to add to that schedule without any definition of what could be added. We think that is over the top. The amendment we have moved permits the removal of things from the schedule by regulation but does not allow matters to go on to the schedule by regulation. As I say, we have had the debate about this and I do not need to speak any longer with respect to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of this particular amendment, it is very important to have the parliament play a role in this area. As I indicated to the chamber, I am supporting the government in its retention of the schedule and the list in the schedule. But I do believe that giving the government, in effect, the power simply to add to the list without it effectively coming back to the parliament—either the House of Representatives or here—is a problem.
