SPEECH.PARA: I know the government is going to say that we do have the disallowance power, but at this point I feel that it would be best if the matter did come before the parliament in a positive way by way of a bill being introduced either here or in the House of Representatives so that the matter can be dealt with in that more thorough fashion. I know it is a very important issue for a lot of people. Under those circumstances, I would be opposing the regulatory power being confirmed by this legislation upon the government in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point Senator Harradine is making. We do think that, as the common law develops and in the event that particular types of leases are found to be grants of exclusive possession based on court cases as they develop, then the capacity to confirm that they are grants of exclusive possession should be available. Any regulation can be disallowed by the parliament, so I guess it is coming at it another way. I understand the point you are making that parliament retains the ultimate control over the matter, so we do think our position is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next batch of amendments 5, 213 and so on all would have been relevant had we been successful in removing the schedule and division 2B. Having lost that vote, I do not think we need to move those now.
—Can I ask a question about that last vote? I presume what we voted on were opposition amendments Nos 15, 215, 216 and 352?
—No. Down the bottom of the page—216A on sheet 838.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5A) Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 13), after item 5, insert:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 11A Extinguishment of native title on freehold land

PARA.TAB: (1) For the avoidance of doubt, but subject to subsection (2), it is expressly declared that native title is extinguished on land that is freehold land.
(2) The non‐extinguishment principle applies to freehold land in the following cases:

TAB.TAB: (a) where an Act of the Commonwealth (including this Act), a State or Territory provides that native title is not extinguished, or that any extinguishment is to be disregarded;
(b) where a grant of land registered as freehold title is made by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity;
(c) where a grant is made by or under legislation that grants freehold estates only to or for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders;
(d) where this Act otherwise provides that the non‐extinguishment principle applies.
Note: For some applications of the principles in these sub‐sections see ss 47A, 47B and s.229 read with ss 15(1)(d), 232 and 253.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the amendment that triggered rather lively debate last night. It is the amendment that can be described as the Hills hoist heritage provision of 1993. It is the amendment that protects one's backyard when you do not need to protect one's backyard because the common law is quite clear. It is an amendment that was circulated in my name last night and one that the opposition thinks is important in order to try to, once again, put some calm and sense in the debate that has raged on uncontrollably and without any rational reason with respect to people's backyards. We know they are safe. The government knows they are safe. The High Court on three occasions has determined seven‐nil that they are safe. You cannot get any more certain than a seven‐nil decision in the High Court. In fact, it is more certain than an act passed through this parliament because, at the end of the day, it is up to the High Court to decide whether acts passed in this parliament are constitutional. But we move this provision and we hope it gets support in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as a matter of form, given that we have just voted that 2B stand as printed, I do not understand how your amendment can be moved. That would be an amendment that would presumably have been moved if 2B had been knocked out.

—In terms of form, what I have been given is a revised 839, which would provide that after item 5 we insert 5A. That 5A would be to include after section 11 extinguishment of native title on freehold land and then there is a consequential amendment as well. That really covers the concern you have, Senator Minchin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I am unclear of the purpose or intent of this given that 2B has been confirmed to stand as printed. It does what the opposition amendment purports to do. This is an unnecessary amendment. Presumably it was going to be moved if 2B went down. It has not, so I do not see how this amendment adds anything, given that 2B does what the ALP amendment purports to do.

—On the basis of the argument the government has put forward that you need to legislate to confirm certainty, then legislating twice doubling confirms certainty. I do not think there is any problem with putting this amendment in.

—I cannot let it go by without comment that the opposition did say that there was no need for this amendment. They did go into the public arena saying that there was no need for this amendment but, having decided this amendment is required, they now need to defend a position that is somewhat redundant. In any case, I would like to ask Senator Bolkus about the situation, for example, where a person dies intestate with no definable beneficiaries. Is it the intention of the opposition that in that situation the nature of freehold there cannot be questioned and that there is no possibility that native title claimants would have an opportunity to assess whether a claim ought to be put forward or not? We are talking about a very large part of Australia. We are talking now about the opposition's determination that extinguishment be put in black and white into this legislation. I put forward this case and ask if there are no doubts in the opposition's mind that this can lead to anomalous situations where there may be an opportunity for native title in the future which has been now extinguished by the opposition's move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any question as to the certainty in respect of private freehold, Senator Brown. The uncertainty comes from the actual interest rather than the person who holds it. Can I fully quote Chief Justice Brennan in the Wik case; I think the government has partially quoted him, but I will give the full and relevant quote. In respect of whether you equate freehold land with questions over native title on leasehold lands, which is the position pushed by the government, Justice Brennan said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . such a theory is inconsistent with the fundamental doctrines of the common law.

I do not think your concern there is a relevant one; we are not extinguishing. This particular amendment, I must say, has been developed only because of the generation of what I try to calmly call a scare campaign that has been embarked upon, but it has been worked out with the particular stakeholders that would be affected by such a provision. They, of course, are indigenous Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would again just make the point that division (2)(b) has been supported by this committee and stands as printed. Therefore this amendment, which was clearly designed to be put in the event that (2)(b) was removed, is redundant and should not be part of the bill because what it purports to cover is already covered.

—I think the amendment has been seen somewhat as the John Laws amendment. That aside, the question that I put to Senator Bolkus a moment ago was: what happens when freehold is lifted? For freehold to exist there needs to be a person who has the title. What happens when that situation ceases? Aren't you, through this move, extinguishing the possibility that a native title claim could be made to such land?
—Senator Brown, if you read subclause (2) of the amendment you will see the circumstances in which the non‐extinguishment principle applies.
—Those provisions do not cover the situation which I put to you earlier.

—As I understand it, Senator Brown is saying that if somebody holds a property under freehold title and dies intestate then you would have to go to the particular state that you are looking for. There are provisions under the various laws of different states as to what happens to that. As I understand it, you are saying that the freehold stops being freehold, but I don't think you are making it quite clear to Senator Bolkus what you say will eventuate from somebody dying intestate—all sorts of things can happen. I think you probably need to know what happens, after that person dies intestate, to the land before we could give a sensible answer to it.

—I can see what the opposition is seeking to achieve by this amendment. I can see that it would be very difficult for the government to vote against this amendment considering all the things that they have said and all the things that they have accused the opposition and everybody else of doing. But I would like to indicate that the nature of the amendment, considering the Greens' position, is that we actually believe that the terra nullius argument clearly means that in justice it should be other property owners in Australia seeking rights of land from the traditional owners. In the ethics of the argument I am unable to support the amendment before us. We know what the legal arguments are, we know what High Court judges have said, but I am unable to support the amendment in the way that it is put forward.
—To simplify the question I was putting to the opposition, what is the situation where freehold reverts to the Crown?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, Senator Brown, it is provided for in subclause (2) and that is the best answer you will get this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 9, page 13 (lines 30 to 34), omit subsection (9), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (9) An act is not a previous exclusive possession act if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) it is an act of the Commonwealth (including this Act), a State or a Territory that provides that native title is not extinguished or that any extinguishment is to be disregarded; or
(c) it is a grant of land made by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity; or
(d) this Act otherwise provides that the non-extinguishment principle applies to the act.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment on sheet 841 is actually one of the `In Case of Fire: Break Glass' amendments. It is an amendment regarding the non‐extinguishment arising from previous exclusive possession acts on native title on freehold land. I think it goes to the nub of what this debate has been going through over a couple of hours last night and today.

The government's proposed confirmation of extinguishment provisions will extinguish native title wherever there has been a grant of a previous exclusive possession act in the past. This will include grants from the Crown to itself or to a Crown owned statutory authority. Proposed section 23B of the bill confirms that the grant of various estates, including of freehold, to any private person should extinguish native title. While the grant of a freehold estate to a private person extinguishes native title in accordance with various decisions of the High Court, it is unjust and contrary to the common law that extinguishment should apply to all crown to crown grants.

In Mabo No. 2, Justice Brennan expressly—this is interesting because Senator Minchin has often quoted Justice Brennan in the last day or so—left open the question of whether the creation of certain crown interests in land such as a national park extinguish native title. In view of the principles adopted by the court in Wik, it is likely that crown grants to itself or a corporation wholly owned by it will not necessarily extinguish native title. The government's confirmation of extinguishment forecloses this question against indigenous interests without any definitive ruling in support.

In some states and territories, most particularly the Northern Territory, grants of freehold to a statutory corporation owned by the Crown have been used as a specific device to prevent claims under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The government's amendment would compound that injustice. There is no principle whereby a national park, for instance, created by a freehold grant to the parks service should extinguish native title where a permanent dedication of that land does not. The proposed amendment does not prevent interest granted to third parties within those areas from extinguishing native title if there are previous exclusive possession acts.

Proposed section 23B(9) of the bill exempts Aboriginal owned land from the extinguishing effect of the confirmation provisions. Similarly, section 23(2) of the Native Title Act, which the government has not amended, exempts validated freehold crown to crown grants which were past acts from any extinguishing effects. Aboriginal land is also exempted. This principle should apply to all such acts. What we have asked is this:
Schedule 1, item 9, page 13 (lines 30 to 34), omit subsection (9), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (9) An act is not a previous exclusive possession act if:

TAB.TAB: (a) it is the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) it is an act of the Commonwealth (including this Act), a State or a Territory that provides that native title is not extinguished or that any extinguishment is to be disregarded; or
(c) it is a grant of land made by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity; or
(d) this Act otherwise provides that the non-extinguishment principle applies to the act.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that there are many ways by which the government has allowed extinguishment to take place. We know that the actual acts and the use of this land are being used for extinguishment. We are saying that it is not unreasonable for the Commonwealth in this bill to make sure that the sheer act of granting or vesting, or crown to crown grants per se, without any effort being made to see whether they do or should permanently extinguish native title, is not good enough. We want to see justice better served. I could not say that in any way, shape or form under this bill justice is served. Justice would be better served if there were an effort to find out whether the use of land does extinguish native title. As it is currently written, I would have to plead with the Senate to support the amendment put before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Margetts in this. As with all parts of this bill, this is another of those very important issues. All advice available indicates that the government's proposed section 23B(3) constitutes an unacceptable risk. The majority in Mabo and Kirby J in Wik stated that the issue of whether a statute extinguishes by necessary implication depends upon the language, character and purpose which the statute was designed to advise; that is at page 283. Nevertheless, the government is proposing to confirm extinguishment where there has been an existing, expressly or implied, exclusive possession.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no requirement to analyse the legislation in order to determine whether the statute intends to extinguish native title. For example, state or territory legislation which vests land in local authorities could be said to imply a right to exclusive possession. Certainly local authorities may be empowered to make grants over some or all of the land within their control of exclusive possession or lesser interests, such as one listed in proposed section 23B(2). However, such legislation could not be said to be designed to extinguish native title.

As stated in the recent native title report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner released in August this year, the bill's focus on the issue of exclusive possession does not accurately reflect the common law, particularly for statutory titles. The questions put to the High Court in Wik linked exclusive possession to necessary extinguishment. In Justice Gummow's view, the proposing of a question in those terms may have distorted the essen tial issues. Earlier in his judgment he had explained that attention is to be focused on the terms of the legislation and to the instruments themselves. In that examination, the term `exclusive possession' is of limited utility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make certain the committee understands that we have moved the amendment to proposed subsection (9), which I think has been passed. It is on the bottom of page 13 and deals with the exclusion of acts benefiting Aboriginal peoples, et cetera. We have widened it to include these three subclauses:

PARA.TAB: (9) An act is not a previous exclusive possession act if it is:

TAB.TAB: (a) the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) the grant or vesting of any thing to or in a person to hold on trust for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(c) the grant or vesting of any thing over particular land or waters, if at the time a thing covered by paragraph (a) or (b) is in effect in relation to the land or waters.

SPEECH.PARA: That is to give the widest coverage for land granted to Aboriginal peoples, in view of the obvious desire to ensure that they can claim native title. But with other crown to crown grants it is, in the government's view, a much more difficult area, because you are talking about thousands of housing trust homes which are on crown to crown grants if it is a housing trust authority or something like that.

The embrace of land held by that Crown in the right of the Crown by any statutory authority, or something like that, includes a whole host of properties of that kind—thousands and thousands of housing trust houses. If you do not do this, it means that claims can be accepted and ultimately have to be tested. Obviously, where there is exclusive possession, the claim will not succeed, but you again put everybody into litigation for no purpose at all.

That will mean that, instead of resources going to where native title may have survived, housing trust housing will potentially be subject to claims. We think that is a serious matter. Where there is a grant of freehold, it does not matter who actually holds the title. To try to devise a system of law that depends not upon the rights granted but to whom they are granted, with the exception of Aboriginal people, is to invite considerable legal uncertainty—something which this whole act is designed to remove.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is some discussion in regard to the best wording of this amendment. In the interests of making sure that the best wording is put forward to the Senate, I request that this amendment be deferred so that we can discuss the wording and come up with something that is acceptable to the majority of the Senate.
—We agree with that.

—Is it the wish of the committee that the matter be deferred? There being no objection, it is so ordered. Before we move off page 2, Senator Bolkus, amendment No. 229, which is at the top of the page, was postponed from a previous time, and I believe it is no longer relevant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think amendment No. 229 relates to the intertidal zone, and we lost the substantive vote in respect of the right to negotiate on the intertidal zone. I seek leave to withdraw amendment No. 229.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendment withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now turn to page 3 of the running sheet, to the Democrat‐Greens amendment on sheet 836. It refers to schedule 1, item 49.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a brief statement before Senator Margetts moves the amendment. This is an amendment which provides that in schedule 1, any reference to a state or terri tory act or ordinance is to be read as a reference to one that was in operation at the commencement of this act. With this amendment, I think Senator Margetts is trying to ensure that there is no blowing out of arrangements. I wonder if she would be prepared to consider an amendment to put a specific date on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The time between now and the commencement of the act may be a whole year, and we would not want that arrangement to allow for uncontrollable acts of enthusiasm by state governments. I suggest that the best date to put there would probably be the date of the Wik decision—23 December 1996. I suggest that as an amendment to Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that is a very helpful suggestion, which I will accept. I therefore move this amended version of Democrat‐Greens amendment on sheet 836:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 49, page 133 (after line 9), at the end of section 249C, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) In Schedule 1, a reference to a State or Territory Act or Ordinance is a reference to the Act or Ordinance as at 23 December 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I think your amendment No. 6 is next.
—It is actually amendment No. 7. It is amendment No. 6 on the running sheet, but No. 6 was consequential on amendment No. 5 being successful, and amendment No. 5 was not successful.
—So we are now dealing with your amendment No. 7, are we?
—I am sorry. I take the point that is being made. This is really into the next group on pastoral leases and diversification. I apologise to the chair and to the committee.
—So your amendment No. 6 is not being proceeded with?

—No. And I point out that my amendment No. 1 has not yet been put or dealt with, but I understood that the government had an amendment to put to the committee in respect of the subject matter of my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has just been pointed out to me that the amendment which was just passed—Democrat-Greens amendment No. 836—could have the effect of not conferring exclusive possession on current grants under past legislation. I think it is very important that the committee be well aware of that consequence of that provision, because it contradicts what the committee has already agreed in relation to the confirmation in relation to existing grants.

SPEECH.PARA: By dint of that particular amendment, current grants granted under past legislation are then not so confirmed. I think that is a very important and significant matter, which I am not sure all members of the committee had in mind when this matter was put. It has only just been drawn to my attention. I would seek leave to have that Democrat-Greens amendment put again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—I would like to give Senator Margetts the opportunity to speak on the matter if she so wishes. What is happening here is that the government wants Democrat‐Greens amendment No. 836 recommitted because it has found some difficulties with it. The outcome of getting that amendment up is one that we would like to see prevail.

—Without indicating that I am giving leave for our amendment No. 836 to be recommitted, could the minister explain the purpose of revisiting that amendment? Why are we going back to something that the Senate has decided on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am putting to the committee that not all members of the committee appreciated the full consequences of this provision, given the committee's decision to support division 2B. Amendment No. 836 completely contradicts a key part of division 2B, in that current grants of exclusive possession issued under acts that have since been repealed would not be covered by these provisions as a consequence of this amendment. That is a very significant matter and one that I think is quite proper for all committee members to have in their minds when they vote on this amendment, because it does run counter to the position already taken by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: When an amendment is passed which is contrary to a position already adopted by the committee, it is proper that it be voted on in full conscience and consideration of the consequences of it. Of course, it remains open for the committee to confirm its decision, but I do expressly seek leave to recommit on the grounds that it was not made clear what the contradictory consequences of the amendment were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to note here that, were we not to accept an amendment like amendment No. 836, we would be in a position where, by accepting an opposition amendment earlier which had the effect of not allowing additions to the schedule by way of regulation by the Commonwealth government, we would be providing a different regime for us than we would be for state authorities and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern here is, as Senator Minchin says, that this may not cover amendments after that date. But the important point I think Senator Margetts wanted to establish was that, up until that date, we will ensure that what the government wants can have effect. But after that date we do not want a situation where states can have a blank cheque. We are saying to the states and territories that, in respect of anything since 23 December 1996, be on notice that you have to take into account interests of indigenous Australians.

I think that, by adopting Democrat-Greens amendment No. 836 that we did adopt earlier on we are essentially saying that past things have happened, but we are saying to you that, if you want to play around with schedule 1, then as from 23 December 1996 you have to take into account the interests of indigenous Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the whole point. I am not sure that there is an understanding of the effect of this particular amendment—Greens‐Democrat amendment No. 836. It effectively rules out current grants made under legislation made prior to 23 December 1996 that may have since lapsed or been repealed even though the grants are current.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I understand what you are trying to achieve, but I think the important point is to make very clear to the committee the effect of that amendment. If the act itself were not in effect on 23 December 1996 by way of it being repealed the day before or something like that, all the grants made under that legislation stand as grants and to the extent that they are grants of exclusive possession, which this committee has already decided should have confirmation upon them, they would all be wiped out. So it runs totally counter to the decision already made by this committee about division 2B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously that was not brought to my attention when the matter was put forward. What about the point that was made by Senator Bolkus? If we have adopted an approach in the federal sphere, what about actions taken by the state governments in respect of similar matters? I would like some clarification on that as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point, Senator Harradine, that `previous exclusive possession act' is defined as being a previous exclusive possession act if it were a grant that took place on or before 23 December 1996. So we covered that. That is the point; we are talking about the grant. If you then take it back and talk about the legislation under which the grant was made—and, of course, in states legislation can be repealed, changed and that sort of thing—you destroy the purpose of what we have already agreed on. This issue of the date is covered by providing in the definition that it has to be a grant that took place on or before 23 December 1996.

—Basically, we are saying that this is what we would like to see if the legislation lapses. What the minister is saying is that he did not like the outcome of the vote. He may have perhaps let some justice escape from this legislation. Are you saying that if any justice has managed to escape which you have not been able to control then you are asking the Senate to reconsider until you make sure that no justice is allowed to escape as a result of this legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not sure whether that was a rhetorical question or a deliberative question, but my point, which I have already made, is that an unintended consequence of this amendment is to negate a part of the decision already made by the committee in relation to the standing of division 2B. I assert that the consequences and effect of that division and how it ran counter to what has already been decided by this committee was not clear to all members of the committee.

—I think there are many elements within this debate that we would like to revisit. Perhaps we can do that now. Perhaps we could now return to all those elements within the debate on which we think the arguments were not fully and justly put, including the justice of the intertidal zone and the manner in which the government has removed the rights of indigenous people, and indicate that the vote was taken because incorrect, insufficient or not enough information was provided to the committee. Perhaps we could do that now if what you are doing now is saying that each time you feel you have not got your way you are going to want to go back to a vote because a tiny weeny bit of justice has potentially escaped.
—Leave of the committee has been sought to recommit the Democrats‐ Greens (WA) amendment that appears on sheet 836.

—I do not know whether there is any lingering confusion. I was of the view—and still am of the view—that it was important to draw the line somewhere. Amongst the implications of being a schedule is, for instance, a privileged position in respect of the freehold test. If other senators would like to take time out for legal advice then that might be a course of action that we can take. I have not been persuaded by Senator Minchin's argument. I do recognise that some may want time out on this particular issue.
—I think the basis upon which any leave is granted is that consideration of that section be deferred.
—Leave has been sought to recommit the Greens‐Democrats amendment that appears on sheet 836. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.
—I ask that further consideration of the amendment be postponed.

—Is it the wish of the committee that consideration of the amendment be postponed? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed. Senator Bolkus, are you proceeding with amendment No. 284?

—We may, because we all have that amendment. It deletes the definition of extinguishment from the table. I think we have actually inserted a new definition of extinguishment pursuant to one of Senator Harradine's amendments. It may very well be that we need to carry this one as a consequence. The advice I am getting from the Clerk is that we do not have to, so we will run with that advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that what Senator Bolkus has stated is not correct. We did not change the definition.
—Okay, we won't proceed.

—I have a procedural amendment that I would like to move, which I gather has been discussed between the advisers, as a result of our amendments and others regarding the definition of scheduled interest in section 249C, item 49, page 133. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 49, division 249C, at the end of subsection 1, add:
(c) an interest created by or under legislation that creates interests only for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) an interest held by a person on trust for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(c) any other interest created in relation to particular land or waters, if at the time an interest covered by paragraph (c) or (d) is held in relation to the land or waters.
There are puzzled looks from the other side, but I am assured by my advisers that that has been discussed. I ask that further consideration of the amendment be postponed:

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no objection, it is so ordered. There are now three matters which have been deferred from running sheet revised 18 which the committee will revisit at a later time. We will now proceed to running sheet 19, which deals with the Racial Discrimination Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of and together with the Democrats, the Greens (WA) and the Australian Greens, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 3), after item 2, insert:
Repeal the subsection, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) This Act is intended to be read and construed subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment has been agreed upon and is on page 832 as circulated. This is an important amendment for all of us in this place who have an interest in observing the principles of non‐discrimination. At the end of the day when one visits this debate over the last 40 hours that we have been in committee, people will find that quite often concerns have been expressed as to whether the government's legislation is in conformity with the principles of non-discrimination.

For us it is important that at the end of the day this Senate be judged on the basis that, with all those concerns and doubts and with all the advice coming to us, we were prepared to take a position that said in the interpretation of the legislation the principles of non-discrimination should be applied. The best way to apply the benchmark of non-discrimination is to apply both the domestic and internationally accepted benchmark, the Racial Discrimination Act as it applies in the International Covenant on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

Principally, the effect of what we are doing is to use sections 9 and 10 of the RDA. Section 9 deems racial discrimination to be unlawful and section 10 deems that one has a right to equality before the law. The effect of these provisions would be not to render any law invalid, but to offer and confer on persons who have been discriminated against on the grounds of race, colour or national or ethnic origin the same rights as are enjoyed by persons of another race, colour or national or ethnic origin on whom there are conferred superior rights.

It is a provision which ensures that the principle of non-discrimination applies. It is not merely a provision which invalidates other laws. It is an act of the Australian Parliament which confers the concept of equality and confers specific rights on individual Australians.

As I say, there have been concerns throughout the debate on this bill as to the discriminatory nature of so many provisions. Whether it is the confirmation of past extinguishment, the upgrading of rights, the validation of crown granted titles at the expense of native title, the winding back of the freehold test, the absence of a special measure which is necessary—all these matters are of important concern to members in this place.

They are not just of concern to people in this place. We are not alone in our concerns. We know, for instance, that the Chief General Counsel of the Commonwealth has expressed concerns as to the potential for discriminatory impact of at least three of the government's important provisions in its legislation. We have had reams of evidence from a whole range of organisations expressing concern as to the discriminatory aspects of this legislation.

I do not want to go through them all. In the past I have published a list of organisations that have expressed concerns as to the discriminatory nature of this legislation. I have shown that list to Senator Minchin. It will include Aboriginal views, a range of church views and views from archbishops and social justice commissioners and so on. There are legal views from Alex Shand QC, the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Human Rights Commissioner, former members of Liberal governments and the Race Discrimination Commissioner. There are independent views and there are also a range of views from people associated with the conservative Liberal side of politics, including Ian Viner, Neville Bonner, Alex Shand, Ian MacPhee and Fred Chaney. There are also Labor views. It is important that the record show those views and I will seek leave at the end of my contribution to have those views incorporated on the record.

The importance of this provision is to make it clear that we have taken into account the views expressed by such a strong body of opinion. We have also taken into account the fact that the government has not seen fit to provide the views of the Chief General Counsel and has not been prepared to make those views public.

The joint parliamentary committee on native title and the Senate legal and constitutional committee inquiring into the Native Title Amendment Bill had views expressed to them from a whole range of eminent people expressing concerns as to the discriminatory nature of the legislation. Ron Castan QC, Jacob Fajgenbaum QC, Mark Mochinsky QC, Father Frank Brennan, the Law Institute of Victoria, John Basten QC, Alex Shand QC, and Jennifer Clarke from the ANU Faculty of Law are some amongst many who have expressed concerns.

We as a parliament need to take those concerns into account. For this reason, we have been having discussions over recent days and I am pleased to say that those discussions have led to a combined and consensual opinion on behalf of the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats. I am pleased to be able to speak first in moving this particular amendment. I also seek leave to incorporate the list of quotations in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Quotes suggesting the Wik amendments are discriminatory

SPEECH.PARA: This is a law of the Commonwealth Parliament that the Law Reform Commission has said is racially discriminatory, and he has got to answer now to the Australian people as to why he is championing legislation in the Commonwealth Parliament that is racist.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Noel Pearson, Chairperson, Cape York Land Council, 7.30 Report, 5/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: There are very strong views now being expressed by Noel Pearson of infringement of racial discrimination under this amendment, and rightly so.
I support Noel Pearson, I support the churches, and I think it is getting ugly and it's becoming a racial issue.
Well, what else can you call it but racist, and what else can you call it but detrimental?

PARA.EMPHASIS: Neville Bonner, former Liberal Senator, P.M., 29/10/97

SPEECH.PARA: Parts of this legislation are racially discriminatory.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Bishop Kevin Manning, Australian Catholic Social Justice Council, Canberra Times, 15/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: And I think legislation that minimises the rights of Aboriginal people and enhances the rights of pastoralists simply isn't fair and, given that the distinction is based on race, it's racist.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Anglican Archbishop of Perth, Peter Carnley, A.M., 7/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: It stabs the nation in the heart and it is a signal to the world that we once again are prepared to suppress a minority people.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Bishop Saunders, Australian Catholic Bishops Committee for Aborigines, SMH, 6/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government is prepared to proceed with legislation that is quite clearly discriminatory and which is going to wreak huge injustice to the Aboriginal people who've already suffered from great injustice through their initial dispossession.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Liz Curran, Social Justice Commissioner, Catholic Church, A.M., 5/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: What this legislation does is go as far as it can towards increasing the rights of non‐Aboriginal people against the rights of Aborigines. We have to end the whites take‐all policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Rev Dr John Brown, Uniting Church in Australia's
spokesperson on relationships with Aboriginal People, SMH, 6/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: We need to recognise how close we are to crushing one of the oldest civilisations on the face of the earth.
If the Government pursues this proposal it will be the most dastardly racial discrimination imaginable, made possible only by an undeniably racist act the amendment of the Racial Discrimination Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Alec Shand Q.C., Letter to The Australian, 31/12/96

SPEECH.PARA: As such, the Commission believes that this provision of the bill will likely infringe the prohibition of both direct and indirect discrimination on the grounds of race of s9 and s9(1) of the RDA respectively, as well as s10(1) which provides for the right to equality before the law.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian Law Reform Commission submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that it has a racially discriminatory effect and for that reason could‐‐and probably would‐‐be in breach of provisions of international treaties.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chris Sidoti, Human Rights Commissioner, Estimates Committee Hansard, 13/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, the (Law) Institute (of Victoria) asserts: `The new legislation does not merely codify common law rights but it takes away right and proposes statutory provisions which may be unconstitutional.' But the ultimate condemnation by the Institute is to agree with the commission and other objective expertise that the Bill violates the Racial Discrimination Act and Australia's obligations under international human rights conventions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Ian McPhee, former Fraser cabinet minister, The Sydney Weekly, 11‐17/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has failed to produce any official legal advice to contradict the numerous opinions of eminent lawyers that the Wik Bill is racially discriminatory and will breach Australia's human rights obligations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Zita Antonios, Race Discrimination Commissioner, The Australian, 17/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: Very clearly it's racially discriminatory because it seeks to wind back rights which have been found to exist by the High Court on the basis of race. There can't be any doubt that the Bill is racially discriminatory.

And I could at least speak for the Jewish community when I say that we will not be mute, we will not maintain a criminal silence in the face of continuing attempts of genocide against indigenous Australia, even if it is genocide by stealth.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Peter Wertheim, President, Jewish Board of Deputies, A.M., 6/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: The Howard plan `is discriminatory against a minority because it's a move to limit by statute common law rights of a minority group of Australians.'

PARA.EMPHASIS: Warren McLachlan, former Cattleman's Union rep at the NFF, SMH, 15/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: According to human rights law experts, The Native Title Amendment Bill may have ramifications for racial discrimination in that is seeks to establish different property rights based on race in the form of lesser rights for indigenous Australians.
. . . this is a disaster for the nation, to have a Government so deliberately prepared to divide the community on a racial issue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Ian Viner, former Liberal Aboriginal Affairs Minister, SMH, 8/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: Well, what else can you call it but racist, and what else can you call it but detrimental?

PARA.EMPHASIS: Neville Bonner, former Liberal Senator, P.M., 29/10/97

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government pursues this proposal it will be the most dastardly racial discrimination imaginable, made possible only by an undeniably racist act the amendment of the Racial Discrimination Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Alec Shand Q.C., Letter to The Australian, 31/12/96

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, the (Law) Institute (of Victoria) asserts: `The new legislation does not merely codify common law rights but it takes away right and proposes statutory provisions which may be unconstitutional.' But the ultimate condemnation by the Institute is to agree with the commission and other objective expertise that the Bill violates the Racial Discrimination Act and Australia's obligations under international human rights conventions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Ian McPhee, former Fraser cabinet minister, The Sydney Weekly, 11‐17/11/97

SPEECH.PARA: The entirely appropriate concern for the property rights of miners, the entirely appropriate concern for the property rights of pastoralists, the entirely appropriate concern for the rights of all citizens to enjoy publicly reserved lands ought to be matched by a similarly appropriate concern for the proper protection of Aboriginal property rights.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Fred Chaney, former Liberal minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Alan Missen Memorial Lecture, 27/8/97

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister wants to know what we think of his legislation. We think it discriminatory‐‐‐and we think it discriminatory on racial grounds.
What the Government is trying to do with native title is lazy, discriminatory, unconstitutional.
It's racially discriminatory and therefore it's racist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment before us concerning the Racial Discrimination Act goes to the very core of the deliberations in this place and what sort of country it is that we want to live in. I doubt if anyone here would assert that they are openly racist, but I further doubt whether most people in this place really understand what racism is or are able to look in their own hearts and understand prejudice, for in some ways all of us are prejudiced.

SPEECH.PARA: A cursory look at the Racial Discrimination Act will give us some neat, legal definitions, but what it will not do is show us what discrimination is like when you are at the receiving end. Despite my extensive experience of working with Aboriginal people, I have not had their experiences, I have not walked in their shoes, I do not know what it is like to be treated as a foreigner in my own country. If any senator does not know that this is the almost daily experience of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country, then I wonder if they have met an a indigenous person or have taken time to listen to their life experience.

If anyone in this chamber wanted to think that this racial discrimination legislation does not affect indigenous people, they merely had to look up into the public gallery over the last few days to see the faces of Aboriginal and Islander Australians watching this debate. Their faces were streaked with tears, their eyes were often sad—sometimes angry—and, apart from a solitary cry of `Shame', they were silent. They were the faces of people who are being racially discriminated against.

I have already spoken about the story of Johnny Koowata, which is a quite famous one because it went as far as the High Court. I have mentioned that even though he won his case in the High Court the Queensland government took action to make sure that he never obtained justice.

I could speak of some of my other experiences—or rather, not my experience but what I was able see of others' experiences by walking alongside them. I am going to put some of them on the record. These are daily occurrences. When I worked in the Uniting Church as the Director for Social Responsibility in Queensland I had responsibility for a number of Aboriginal churches in Brisbane and other places. We had a pastor named Keith Warner, an Aboriginal man. We were wanting to shift him into an area, so we had to get him some accommodation. I looked up the various places for rent, phoned up and said, `We have a pastor of our church, Keith Warner. He is looking to rent a place.' They said,`That's good. That'll be great. Send him along and we will see what we can do.' I said to Keith, `It's all fixed up. Away you go.' Off he went. As soon as he walked in, he said he could see the reaction on their faces. Would you believe that all of sudden that place had already been let? So he came back and told me what had happened. I let about an hour go past and then I phoned again, to discover that miraculously that rental place was still on the market. This is not an isolated occurrence. This happens all the time.

I finally got rental for Pastor Keith Warner, now the Reverend Keith Warner. When he had finished there after two years and he was to shift to another place, he asked for his bond back. He was refused, and they told him the place was dirty. I went to have a look. It was spotless. It had been cleaned from top to bottom. I said to Keith, `Go back and ask for it.' He said, `Oh no, we never get our bonds back.' And he just would not pursue the matter. This happens every day to Aboriginal people in Australia.

Even people who are well intentioned—I know I have done it myself—often do not understand their actions. My wife took a number of women who were very much committed to the work that we were doing amongst the Aboriginal people to one of our Aboriginal churches in Brisbane to have lunch with them. A number of the women from the white church took their own lunch and did not understand what it was that they were doing or understand the effect that had.

Even language is something. Until we can begin to see something through the eyes of Aboriginal people we do not understand what we are doing. For instance, in Sunday school we grew up with the expression `Sin is black'. Have you any idea what that kind of language means to an Aboriginal person? But it never occurred to me until one day an Aboriginal person finally pointed that out to me.

Deep down, I suspect that the hysteria around freehold land, despite the assertions otherwise, lie deep in the psyche of this nation. It is an institutionalised fear in this country. Some people really are scared. The National Farmers Federation, most notably Dr Wendy Craik and Mr Donald McGauchie, have done nothing to alleviate the situation. They have poured time and money into turning up the heat with campaigns of misinformation and scaremongering such as the TV ads. Their contribution has not been helpful, to say the least.

I spoke this morning when Senator Boswell was here about the outrageousness of De‐Anne Kelly's assertions yesterday. And yet I suspect that the fear is this: some people in this country are absolutely petrified that Aboriginal people may treat them in the same way that Aboriginals have been treated.

My colleague Senator Bartlett touched, as I will touch, on this issue in his contribution when he asked the question, `Who would like to be treated like Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are treated every day?' I do not see a lot of people in this chamber queuing up to join what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) referred to as the `Aboriginal industry'.

This amendment is being moved jointly by the Australian Democrats, the WA Greens and the Australian Labor Party and indicates for us on this side of the chamber at least that we do know something, even though we can never absolutely enter into that experience of how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are treated in this country. We would not want it for ourselves or our children, and we are not prepared to accept it for anyone else. The Racial Discrimination Act should not only apply to this legislation but also, as is the view of the Australian Democrats, be a constitutional prohibition. The question remains: why is the coalition government of this country not prepared to support this amendment? Perhaps, if I put it in the positive, I may appeal to them in fact to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just forewarn Senator Bolkus that I would not mind his explaining this quite innocent question: what is the difference in the wording between the original ALP amendment on this issue and the new amendment? I would like to know, and I think the committee should know, why the wording is different, the effect of the wording and what is being sought with the new provision as opposed to the old one.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with this whole area is that we can all indulge in the political rhetoric of accusing each other of being racially discriminatory and saying that each other's legislation is just that. It becomes an endless political roundabout. In this parliament, we have to worry about the legal effect of the decisions we make. We are not here to just commit expressions of political intent and goodwill and make ourselves all feel good. We pass laws which directly affect the lives of every Australian, have significant legal consequences which give rise to legal rights and result in those rights being pursued in the courts of Australia, and have, as I say, dramatic impact upon the legal rights and obliga tions of every Australian. So this is much more than all of us getting up and making ourselves feel good.

We are most concerned about the legal effect of this provision, and I can point to no greater source for the concern we share about the considerable uncertainty which such a proposition would entail than the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee when it investigated the Native Title Bill 1993, which was chaired by none other than Senator Barney Cooney, who I regret has left the chamber. It also had Senator Chris Evans on it, Senator Jim McKiernan and Senator Margaret Reynolds. They are all Labor senators, and were then, and were the majority on that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Distinguished group.
—Distinguished men and women, particularly the chairman, Senator Cooney, a fine lawyer. They considered this question very carefully, and recommended in 1.86 that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government give consideration to amendments in the following areas.

(a) The Bill should be amended to make clear that it is the intention of the Parliament that the Bill is consistent with the RDA and constitutes a special measure for the advancement of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.
They went on to say:
This should not provide that the Bill is subject to the RDA—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order, by way of a clarification. We have been travelling along doing these batches of amendments by speaking to the batch. It was a bit rude of the minister to actually deal with the specifics of the amendment whilst the rest of us in the committee have not given our general consideration of the amendment. He is debating the issue whilst, as we have been going along, we have been debating the general batch of amendments and then dealing with the specifics. I am just wondering why the minister has not thought to be polite enough to consider that.

—There is no point of order, Senator Margetts. This batch of amendments actually consists of only one amendment. Senator Bolkus has moved the amendment, and I thought the minister was merely getting up at that point in time to make a technical point. That is why I called him instead of you. I will give you the call next, before Senator Bolkus answers that initial question that was asked of him, if that is the wish of the committee.

—I will continue my remarks because we have been having cognate debates about these matters and speaking to the subject matters raised. As has been pointed out, quite rightly, there is only one amendment in this batch, so I am putting the government's position on this as a general issue and, obviously, by implication, on the amendment itself, and there is only one. I will requote what the committee—that is, the Labor majority—said on this committee:

SPEECH.PARA: This should not provide that the Bill is subject to the RDA because of the uncertainty that would create—contrary to one of the very basic objectives of the legislation.

I do not think I could have put it better than Senator McKiernan and Senator Evans, who are in this chamber right now. They thought it was `contrary to one of the very basic objectives of the legislation'—that is, it provides certainty—to make the bill subject to the RDA, no doubt because they, then in government, acted quite responsibly in recognising the extraordinary legal uncertainty that flows from having one piece of federal legislation subject to the provisions of another piece of federal legislation in the way this amendment suggests.

I really would be fascinated to have Senator Evans, Senator McKiernan and Senator Cooney—regrettably, Senator Reynolds is still overseas—explain exactly why they can now support an amendment which they, in 1993, said should not be done because of `the uncertainty it would create—contrary to one of the very basic objectives of the legislation'. I remind you that the ALP has said repeatedly that certainty is one of the basic objectives that it wishes to bring to the consideration of this legislation.

I would also point to other legal opinion on this proposition. Professor Tony Blackshield was reported in the Australian of 26 November as saying that the outcome of parliament adopting Labor's RDA clause would be for the judges to give the present bill little or no legal effect. He said it would be:
. . . a very odd consequence, but I still think it's what would follow.
Then we have S.E.K. Hume QC saying that the Labor RDA clause would produce `profound uncertainty' and tie up parts of the bill in the High Court for decades. He said:
I very much doubt if anyone can see an advance of the outcome of each of those situations where conflict might exist.

I have no doubt that the Labor members of the committee in 1993 recognised that very point. You suggest that the position would then be that you go through all the provisions of the Native Title Act, you ensure the validity of whatever you propose to do in relation to a future act—be it mining, residential development, fishing licences or whatever—you comply in every respect with the NTA, but you then have a situation where anyone can challenge the validity of that act on the grounds that it may be inconsistent with the RDA. What we are talking about here is giving grounds for legal challenge to everything done under the Native Title Act which otherwise is the mechanism by which you determine whether things can validly be done that impact or affect native title. It would be a disastrous proposition. It would render useless the Native Title Act as a mechanism by which the Commonwealth parliament is attempting to provide certainty in relation to the doing of future acts on land on which native title may have survived.

The Labor Party clearly understand that. This is a political exercise that is now being proposed. It is not one that they were prepared to pursue in government, quite properly and responsibly, but with the luxury of opposition they are now indulging in the politics of this issue rather than dealing with the hard‐core issue of passing legislation that does provide certainty to Australians. So I think this should be seen for what it is. It would be an absolutely irresponsible amendment for this parliament to pass because of the legal effect of it.

BREAK.PARA: As we have repeatedly stated, in a democracy like this you can have political arguments about whether something is racially discriminatory or not forever and a day. We are absolutely resolute in our view that this bill taken as a whole is not racially discriminatory, and what we have done is maintain the relationship between the bill and the RDA that is provided for in the current Native Title Act on the recommendation of such esteemed men as the chairman of the committee and Senator Evans—that nothing in this bill shall affect the operation of the RDA. That was the appropriate arrangement deemed to be proper by the previous government. We have kept that provision in the act. I do not want to get into the political debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—No, I think we should stick with what we are doing here—that is, making laws. We are making laws that affect the lives of thousands of Australians. We are not here just to indulge in political rhetoric.
—Oh!

—Well, we are making a law here and we have to make a law which provides certainty to all Australians. To make this bill subject to the RDA will have exactly the consequences which Senator McKiernan and Senator Evans forecast, and therefore it is unacceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is almost unbelievable in his approach. He is railing against the fact that the government is not able to do what it wants and that people are not jumping into line to do whatever racially discriminatory things the government wants to do. He says that anybody arguing against that is involved in political arguments. I thought that was our job actually—to support the community and to vote according to the principles upon which we are polled. That is our job. I am not sure what the minister's job is.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to acknowledge the Jennifer Clarke article, `The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 : A different form of uncertainty', published by the Centre for Aboriginal Eco nomic Policy Research in November this year for forming the foundation to my introductory comments on this very important issue. The issue of racial discrimination goes to the very heart of this debate—and that has been mentioned by other senators. It is the issue which most caring Australians believe makes this bill completely unacceptable. It is one of the legal issues upon which this bill has been continually questioned, and it is the issue which the international community will focus on as they condemn Australia for many years to come if this despicable piece of legislation is passed.

The extent to which the bill discriminates against native title holders may be measured in a number of different ways. Firstly, a law is discriminatory if it prefers the rights of non-Aborigines over those of Aborigines. It is unusual in Australian law for private rights to be removed or suppressed for the benefit of other private land‐holders. However, this bill benefits other land‐holders by extinguishing some unextinguished native titles and by giving preference to intermediate period acts, primary production activities and private water and fishing rights over the native title which those rights suppress. The bill's title upgrading provisions extend in time the preference given to other land‐holders over native title holders in the Native Title Act.

Secondly, a law may be discriminatory if it fails to provide the property rights of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders with protection approaching the protection given other landowners. The bill does this in a number of ways. For example, the bill's confirmation of past extinguishment, validation of intermediate period acts, expansion of primary production activities and privileging of private water and fishing rights are achieved without native title holders' consent in circumstances where other landowners' consent would have been sought.

In the case of validation of intermediate period acts, native title holders' compensation entitlements may be set at a discriminatory level. The bill authorises on native title land, mining and fossicking which would not be permitted on private land but deprives those native title holders of both landowners' objection rights and the right to negotiate. Similarly, native title holders whose right to negotiate is cut off by ministerial intervention are denied both sets of objection rights.

The bill sometimes requires native title to be treated like an inferior right to land. This is the case under those amendments which allowed substitution of the right to negotiate by state laws applicable to current or former non-exclusive freehold, leasehold or public use reserves. It is also the case under amendments allowing the use for primary production activities of off‐farm land subject to native title.

Finally, discrimination should also be measured by the bill's failure to provide substantive equality via appropriately different treatment of unique aspects of Aboriginal culture. A right to negotiate is an important response to the special relationship between Aboriginal people and land. Its time frames should make allowances for considered and unhurried Aboriginal decision making processes, and its content should reflect something of the Aboriginal sense of obligation to land and the need for participation in traditional land management.

The right should not be made inaccessible in an unduly strict registration test or rendered meaningless by ministerial intervention, nor should it be wound back by reference to non-Aboriginal concepts of land history or significance—for example, the distinction between towns and other areas or the distinction between land previously reserved or alienated and other crown land. Similarly, protection of the intertidal zone should reflect something of the significance to that area to Aboriginal people, not its insignificance in non-Aboriginal culture.

There seems to be no doubt to us that this bill is inconsistent with the international law standards embodied in the Racial Discrimination Act. Even if this inconsistency does not raise constitutional issues, it does raise international law issues and important questions about the credibility of assertions that the bill and the Racial Discrimination Act are consistent.

This discrimination could generate successful complaints to United Nations human rights bodies, with associated negative international attention. Once again, we will see the government attacking the United Nations. Further, although international law will not prevent parliament enacting the bill, the bill will operate as an implied repeal of the Racial Discrimination Act. Assertions about the `consistency' of the bill and the Racial Discrimination Act should be assessed in this context: the two will only be consistent because the bill runs down the Racial Discrimination Act standard, allowing discrimination against Aboriginal property rights under both Commonwealth and consistent state and territory laws.

As the Greens have stated repeatedly over the last month, in order to encourage genuine non-discrimination—as opposed to opportunistic political use of non-discrimination law concepts—the Commonwealth government should withdraw this bill and commence meaningful negotiations with indigenous groups regarding future amendment of the Native Title Act. Unfortunately, this most reasonable course of action was considered too time consuming by the government and perhaps, more importantly, the mining industry. Therefore, Australia will stand forever labelled as a country which refuses to pay even the most cursory respect to its first peoples.

We have heard Senator Minchin attempting to explain, in his now familiar double-speak, how this bill is not racially discriminatory, despite all the evidence to the contrary. Besides, why shouldn't the government be able to make laws in any way it likes? Senator Minchin, if this is the case, you have no reason not to support the Racial Discrimination Act amendment being proposed by the non-government parties. If you are so sure, if you are prepared to stand before the people of Australia and say that this bill is not racially discriminatory, then back up your words with support for a proposed section in this bill which makes it subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act.

The amendment has explicitly excluded the validation provisions that this Senate passed in an act of shame. I would like to place on the public record that, in agreeing to support this amendment, I do not condone the validation provisions. Their exclusion from this amendment in itself proves that the validation provisions are discriminatory, and I in no way, shape or form support this massive extinguishment of native title rights. However, the political reality is such that in order to reach some level of non-government consensus on the issue of including a Racial Discrimination Act provision, it has been worded in this form.

It is unfortunate that the government has not seen fit to offer anywhere near the same level of compromise at any stage in this debate. Quite frankly, we are going to continue having this debate on legislation. We are going to see governments on both sides pushing the limits of the High Court from time to time until we start mentioning in Australia what it is necessary to have in a constitution leading into the next century. We need to have a constitution which does ensure the rights of indigenous Australians. We need to have a constitution which is quite clear on human rights and things like ecological sustainability.

Until we do this, we are going to continue to have this kind of awful legislation put forward and shoved through. Groups like indigenous Australians, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, will be used as a political football in this scapegoat, politically opportune method of dealing with the concerns of people in the bush. Their concerns, in reality, have nothing whatsoever to do with native title. Their concerns are real, but their viability has nothing whatsoever to do with native title and, in reality, the government know it. What are they going to do when they run out of excuses?

So I would like to commend the amendment which is in the combined names of the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. I think there really is no reason why the Senate should not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are a few points that need to be answered. Senator Minchin asked some questions, and I think there are some other items that need to go on the record as well. Senator Minchin asked what the difference was in respect of this particular amendment and the previously circulated Labor amendment on this issue. I think the only difference of substance is that this amendment applies to the whole act as amended, whereas the previous amendment only applied to the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: So what we are doing is importing the beneficial aspects of the previous legislation and the previous special measure regime. In fact, we are being generous to the government's bill in that we allow that bill to be judged in the context of the whole act and the whole arrangement at the time. So I think it does something which is of benefit to the government's interests. If the interest is solely certainty, it does that as well.

We have always argued that the initial act was in accordance with the Racial Discrimination Act. With respect to the High Court in Western Australia and the Commonwealth, on page 483 of the judgment, the six judges say:
In the first place, it is not easy to detect any inconsistency between the Native Title Act and the Racial Discrimination Act.

I think it lays an extra plank of foundation under the government's legislation to have the RDA apply in the broader context of the amended act rather than just in respect of this particular bill, which the previous amendment was to target.

You make the point also as to why we did not do it when we were in government and why we ask now for it to be done in this particular circumstance. I think there are a number of things to be said in respect of that. I do not think the concern at the time was anywhere near as strong as it is now. Indigenous Australians, for instance, were in agreement with the measures. That agreement was also quite important in the courts' consideration as to the non‐discriminatory nature of the previous legislation. Compare that with the widespread concerns about this legislation and its non-adherence to non‐discriminatory principles.

Secondly, we did try in 1993. The High Court in that very same case took the view that, although we did try, we obviously did not try enough. I think it is fair to say that in 1993 we should have been a bit clearer about what we meant by section 7. I do not deny that. My view at the time also was that we could have been a little more forceful in our non‐discriminatory section 7 of the act at that time. But I do go back to the point that, at that time, there was nowhere near the concern that there is now as to the nature of the legislation.

In terms of that concern, the concern seems to emanate only from the grounds of uncertainty. I did make the point at the start that the effect of this provision would be twofold. As we know, Commonwealth laws override state laws as to any inconsistency under section 109 of the constitution. Obviously this provision would have an impact on what the states are allowed to do under your legislation. I think that is an extremely important safeguard to put in place here. It has an important role in ensuring that states, in the devolution of power from the Commonwealth to the states, act in accordance with non‐discriminatory principles. It is the best guarantee we can provide from this level to ensure that.

In respect of Commonwealth legislation, what this provision would do would be not to strike out that legislation, but to have that legislation read in accordance with non‐discriminatory principles. Your concerns as to uncertainty are a little overblown in this circumstance. It is important for us—when we give the states the capacity to set up tribunals, the capacity to set up mechanisms for regimes for extinguishment, and so much say in the process—that we have the safety net that this legislation does not allow for discriminatory practices to take place.
This is not a political exercise. Senator Minchin said a rather curious thing. He said, `Let's get back to law making and let's get away from political exercise.'

TALK.START.PARA: —We heard and we were all amazed.

—We were all amazed, but the point that cannot be left unchallenged is that when we passed the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975 we were making a law. That law made it very clear that we expected people in this diverse society to act in a non‐discriminatory manner. Law‐making does include essential legislation such as the Racial Discrimination Act. It does not just extend to the Buffalo Slaughter Levy Bill 1997 for instance. It does not extend purely to just admin functions like raising excises and taxes. It does go to matters such as this. Don't try to argue that this is purely a political exercise and that we ought to go back to the real men's business of making law. Let's give it a break. Let's acknowledge that one of the most important laws passed in this parliament this century was the 1975 Racial Discrimination Act. It has governed the behaviour of parliaments and of governments since, and it needs to go on governing the behaviour not just of parliaments but of all of us in this place and, hopefully, in the place across the way.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating a fundamental issue. It is fundamental as to its symbolism. It is fundamental as to the protection it gives on the ground. It is also fundamental as to how this parliament, particularly this Senate, is seen by history. We have been warned time and time again that the provisions that we have adopted may be discriminatory. This Senate has a choice between picking up a lot of those amendments and dismissing those concerns, though sometimes with a degree of anguish. We will be held accountable. The matter will go to courts and courts will make a judgment on us. The matter will go to international tribunals and international tribunals will make a judgement on us.

The matter will be discussed in international fora and those fora will make a judgment on us, as we have made judgments on them, and we have made judgments on them in accordance with the regime of the convention on the elimination of racial discrimination. It is a regime that we were quite fundamental in formulating in the early days of the United Nation. We were there at the birth of this particular convention. In fact, we were probably one of those major parties responsible for it. The rest of the world will say to us as a nation, `It `s your principles that we're applying, but your parliament has not even seen fit to apply those principles that have been universally accepted for some decades now to your legislation.' They may expect that of our Prime Minister and they may expect it of the government, but I for one do not want to be besmirched in an international assessment of these issues by being associated without distinction with the government of the day on this matter.
