It is important that when we make this law we should recognise that we have a stake—a historic stake and a future stake—in making sure that this law conforms with the standards that we expect of the rest of the world and the standards that we have set for the rest of the world. This is one of those occasions where they will be looking into our backyards. Unfortunately, if we do not pass this provision, the backyard they will be looking into will be the Senate, and we will all be judged accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support this amendment. Basic and fundamental to all parties in this debate is being sure that the nature of the legislation which results from this debate does not infringe the rights of any Australians on a racial basis. Let us remember here that, if that is to be the case, there should be no fear that this amendment has been moved to ensure that the Racial Discrimination Act prevails where it may be infringed by the provisions of the legislation that we are debating at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us also remember that this is simply not a mechanism to protect Aboriginal interests. It is a mechanism to protect the interests of all racial components of the Australian community and, as such, there should be nobody who either fears it or believes that it should not be very clearly stated as part of this legislation; that is, that the Racial Discrimination Act has precedence. I want to read a letter from Professor Tony Blackshield of Macquarie University, which encapsulates the argument here very succinctly. He states:

An essential element in the negotiations surrounding the Native Title Act 1993 was the assurance given to Aboriginal negotiators that the full effect of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 would be preserved. But the clause included for that purpose (section 7 of the 1993 Act)—
which Senator Bolkus has referred to—

BREAK.PARA: was ineffective. The High Court later said that "It is difficult to identify the legal purpose which this provision is intended to serve".

In 1997 the present government has again given assurances that its amendments to the 1993 Act will not be inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act. To make those assurances meaningful it is essential that a mechanism be provided to ensure that the new amendments—
that we are dealing with now—
cannot operate in any way that would infringe the Racial Discrimination Act.
Professor Blackshield goes on to say:
In the absence of such a mechanism the Racial Discrimination Act would be infringed by any amendment—
to this legislation—
detrimental to the common law rights of indigenous Australians. However, the effect of that impairment would simply be that the new amendments would take effect—
that is, would be discriminatory—

and to that extent the Racial Discrimination Act would have been repealed. This is because when the courts are faced with two inconsistent Acts of the same Parliament, the normal rule is that the courts will give effect to the later Act. The earlier Act will be regarded as impliedly repealed to the extent of the inconsistency.
That is, if there is a conflict between what we are passing here today and the Racial Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act is, in effect, repealed. Professor Blackshield continues:

Since the government's position is that it does not intend to repeal the Racial Discrimination Act, it is essential that it includes a mechanism to avoid the possibility of an implied repeal. That is the intention of the Greens' amendment.

The proposed mechanism is going to be workable. The effect is that through this amendment we are making it clear that the Racial Discrimination Act is not repealed. We have heard no argument from the government that would counteract that. I do want to say this: right across this nation decent Australians will see the merit in this amendment. Right across the country people who are of good faith on all sides of the argument will see the justification in us insisting that the Racial Discrimination Act not be repealed in so far as this legislation is concerned but be confirmed through this amendment.

It would be a statement in itself were the Senate to fail to pass this amendment. You cannot get around it, Senator Minchin. If you believe, as the Prime Minister has said, that the Racial Discrimination Act will not be infringed by this legislation, then you ought to support this amendment. You can have no fear of it. Anybody who sees the government failing to support this amendment has the right to infer from that that the government does inherently believe that there is the risk, if not the clear reality, that this legislation will infringe the Racial Discrimination Act.

The government has throughout called for certainty. It has used the word `certainty' as a foundation of its argument for its 10-point plan and for this legislation. Above certainty, Australians do not want to see discrimination against people as an outcome. That is why this amendment is so important. It says: let us not leave any doubt and let us not cavil about our commitment to ensure there is no discrimination. Worse still, let us not mince our words. But let us be clear, direct and simple in uniting in this place, all of us, to make it clear that we do not want racial discrimination as an outcome of this legislation in any way. We want to make it clear not just to the courts and not just to those people most affected by this legislation but to this nation that there is no way this legislation will be allowed to discriminate against any Australian, not least the original indigenous Australian people of this country.

It is an extremely important amendment. I would expect the government is going to support it. It is a matter of great principle that the government does support it. With that, I commend the amendment and I, again, say that the nation will watch this amendment as an indication of the intent of not just the government but all components in this debate as we move towards its conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Act in 1993 did not contain a provision that expressly vindicated the Racial Discrimination Act within its terms. As I saw it, I thought the 1993 act worked well. Then we had Wik. Since then, there has been in some cases a very violent reaction to Wik, and there has been debate that has had at least a racial overtone, or could be interpreted as such. May I say this, Minister: whilst lots of things have been said against you, I have never, on any occasion, seen that you have in any way argued in a racist way or have taken a racist approach in this matter. But the bill itself has become symbolic of the supposed divide between the races. We have heard talk about a double dissolution which will mean that there will be, as people argue, an election where race will be a symbolic issue in one sense and part of the meat of the meal that we will make of that election.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that, given the history since 1993, given the fact that this bill has become a symbol, and given the fact that there could be an election where the racial issue is a very big one, we, as a parliament, ought to say quite clearly now that no matter what other people might say about the history of this bill, or what other people might say about any coming election, we do not in any way tolerate racial distinction. It might be, therefore, proper for us to put this in this bill that we are about to make an act. Given the history of what has happened since 1993, given the history of the debate about this issue, and given the fear that the coming election has for people, and properly so, it seems to me that we might have a racial divide in the community. It is incumbent upon this parliament to put something in this bill to indicate that we will stick by the Racial Discrimination Act no matter what.

A lot of issues have been raised about the difficulty of administering this bill if it became an act because the bureaucrats administering it would have to worry about the act all the time. I want to say a couple of things about that. First, in recent times we passed the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 . This legislation, in effect, set out mission statements such as: we want public servants to be honest, we want them to be polite to people, and we want them to do their job in a proper way. All of these objectives, which were very vague and which you would think would be very hard to administer, passed through this chamber without any trouble. We say that they are aspirations that you ought to aspire to. Even though these objectives are not expressed in detail, nevertheless they give a flavour to the way that people administer the regulations when they are written, which will make things better. We set out certain principles for the Public Service. Although those principles may be vague and general, we did not have any worries about them being difficult to administer.

I have consulted the person in Australia who, perhaps, best understands native title. That is Ron Castan. He is a man of great integrity, as everybody agrees, and great generosity. But it was not those qualities that I was looking for; it was his legal mind. I think everybody agrees that he has a great legal mind and knows this area of the law perhaps better than anyone. Indeed, he would adorn the High Court—not in any partisan way, but because of his mind. He says that the insertion of a provision vindicating the Racial Discrimination Act is essential and would not interfere with the proper administration of the act. I am very conscious of the need for the bill to be framed in such a way that it is able to be used properly. I know there are some great concerns about that. But when you have the precedents of the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 and the opinion of someone like Ron Castan, I think the answer to our problems is to insert this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —To take up the point that has just been made by Senator Cooney: he sees this as a means of keeping the states honest and keeping them on the track. That is something that has exercised my mind considerably. Various bodies are to be established in the various states and clearly Commonwealth law overrides state law to the extent of any inconsistency. If the RDA proposal that is put before us goes into the legislation then that would serve not so much as a block but as a threat overhanging the states in respect of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether that is the way to do that. I would have thought the way to do it is to have a vigorous Commonwealth minister who is going to ensure that this measure operates effectively and a politically aware constituency in the various states to make sure that the relevant responsible state ministers act appropriately and properly. They can ensure that the measures we have decided upon in this legislation and in the 1993 legislation are given proper effect to, as we want them to be.

I have approached this matter, as no doubt everybody else has, with a mind to what the RDA says to ensure that this measure is not a discriminatory measure based on racial discrimination. I have approached every one of the amendments and all of the legislation that has come before us on that basis. A different view has been expressed by Senator Margetts in this debate. She indicated in her contribution that she is of the view that this measure that we will finish adopting today is inconsistent with the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. That is the view that has been strongly stated here. If Senator Margetts has made that statement, I assume that it is the view of a number of people. She indicated that she consulted a number of people on these matters. I respect her views.

I am saying that this measure we have before us today is really a huge invitation to constant, endless litigation. It is not going to do anybody any good. If that is the outcome of placing the RDA provision that has been moved by Senator Bolkus into this legislation, it certainly will create widespread uncertainty, which we do not wish to have. People will not be able to, with confidence, go ahead and implement this measure. Nobody can deny that this measure is, overall, for the benefit of the indigenous people.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—Nobody can deny that this is a special measure designed to benefit the Aboriginal people overall.
—No. I will deny it any time.
—You can deny it, if you like.
—You might be happy with it, but I don't think a whole lot of other people are. I'll deny it. Don't speak for me.
—Order!
—I apologise. You deny it.
—You cannot use the word `nobody' if you are speaking for yourself, Brian.
—I deny it, too.

—Thank you very much. Senator Bolkus denies it. That is the proof of the pudding. In putting the RDA provision in here, you want a lawyers picnic. You do not want to have a degree of certainty. You are inviting the government to say, `This measure is totally unworkable'. That is what they will say. They will say, `This measure is totally unworkable. We ought to scrap it completely.'
—Is that what you're fearing?

—It is not a fear. It is an educated conclusion. That is precisely what they will do, and they would probably be justified in saying precisely that. It is unworkable because every provision in the legislation will have to be subject to the RDA. There will be endless litigation about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Why did we not put it in the 1993 legislation? For the very reason that we ought not be putting it in here. The Labor government at that time knew that it was a nonsense to put a similar provision in the Native Title Act. If the Labor Party faced up to the real world now, they would realise that it would be, and is, not an appropriate thing to do if you want to have the legislation work for the benefit of indigenous people—native title holders—and in fairness to the rights of other persons. Under those circumstances, I do not intend to support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to read what it is that we are debating. The opposite of it is something I cannot contemplate. We are debating that this act is intended to be read and construed subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. The opposite of that is that this act will not be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. I cannot contem plate any act of this parliament which is not subject to the Racial Discrimination Act. If that is what Senator Harradine is saying, I do not know what my response is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning, Senator Harradine told us that he had moved to accept 90 per cent of the Howard government's position on this. He also said that he had made a decision two weeks ago to adopt the minimalist position—that is, the same thing. I read that as meaning that he has made a decision to go as far as the government requires to let this legislation go through, whatever the cost might be to the indigenous people of this nation of getting this government legislation through.

SPEECH.PARA: When we get down to the nitty‐gritty, the question is: are we legislating in a way which discriminates against the indigenous people of this country? I maintain that any member of this committee who cannot support the Racial Discrimination Act prevailing where there is uncertainty about that matter is courting discrimination as an outcome.

If you are worried about that, you put the lid on. You do not worry about the political consequences, and you do not argue about what the opposition did in government or the government did in opposition. Senator Minchin said that we should put this above politics. We have heard talk, as Senator Cooney said, about the possibility of a race based election. Great fear has been expressed about that by political leaders, including the Prime Minister.

If you were going to ensure that people had some confidence that this legislation was not racially discriminatory, you would accept this amendment. That is simple logic. That cannot be countermanded. For Senator Harradine, or any members of the government opposite, to say that the Racial Discrimination Act ought not be clearly invoked as the arbiter of whether or not any component of this legislation is discriminatory, flies in the face of logic and the standard of commitment to the indigenous people of this country to a fair go and to making sure that we do not have discrimination, as I would expect in this place.

Involved in this is an effort at all costs by the arbiter, Senator Harradine, to meet the government at a point where this legislation may get through. The big losers in this at‐all‐costs move are the indigenous people of this country. I do not think it is a matter of goodwill to the indigenous people that we say in a majority here, as it appears the vote is going to be, that we cannot defend you through the Racial Discrimination Act.

Senator Harradine, I do not buy the argument that you can leave it to good ministers, particularly at state level. I do not buy this bringing in of the states rights issue as a means of defeating the rights of anybody to be protected from racial discrimination. The High Court has already said that the previous attempt to protect indigenous interests in the 1993 legislation was ineffectual. Senator Harradine and the government are saying here, `Let's leave it ineffectual.'

If you are a fair‐minded person and, in particular, if you are a member of the indigenous community in this country, how are you to read that? You read it this way: this legislation is inimical to your interests in some ways. We know that. You have said through your representatives that you do not want the government's legislation adopted. You have enumerated the ways in which it discriminates against your interests but, in this pivotal moment in this debate, Senator Harradine is failing those interests, and the government is failing those interests. Let that go on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to say much more on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:

That the order of the Senate of 28 November 1997, as varied on 4 December 1997, relating to the hours of meeting and routine of business for 5 December 1997, be modified to provide that matters of public interest commence immediately and continue for no longer than 35 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that there is a time understanding, so I will ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that I wish to raise in this afternoon's matter of public interest debate concerns an article entitled `Lawyers trim the truth to join the backyard scare campaign' that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday. The article makes the assertion that a number of lawyers in this place were engaged in trimming the truth in relation to the issue of freehold title.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that there can be genuine differences of opinion in relation to the legal consequences. But it is unacceptable for not even commentators—advocates—to start writing in the terms that were submitted in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday. To make the assertion that some lawyers in this place, including me, knew different from what we were arguing about is unacceptable and demeaning of the profession of journalism. In making the attack, not a single word was printed in inverted commas as to what we actually said.

The article deliberately left out the views of other senior lawyers that were well known to the writer of the article. People such as John Greenwood QC do not rate a mention. What about the views of his Honour Chief Justice Brennan of the High Court in his dissenting judgment in Wik on page 30? It must have been known. But, no, we cannot put the other side because, if we were simply to put the other side in the debate, it would suggest to the public that there were two sides to the argument that could be rationally and genuinely argued.

I do not say that the view I have been putting in relation to freehold title is necessarily right. What I am saying, and what the government has been saying, is that there is the possibility. If there is that possibility, then there is uncertainty within the community. If you have that uncertainty, what better way to get rid of it than by having legislation to ensure that what everybody allegedly asserts is the law is simply enshrined in the law.

Can I quote a letter to the editor of John Greenwood QC in the Daily Telegraph of 2 December 1997. May I just add for the record that this Mr Greenwood QC acted for the Thayorre people in the Wik case, arguing in favour of the ultimate decision that arose in Wik. His letter reads:

The present position seems to be that, although Australians can be confident that a grant of freehold extinguishes native title, it is not a 100 per cent certainty and will not become a 100 per cent certainty until the reasoning in the US and some Canadian authorities . . . is rejected by the High Court.

Everybody who has argued the Mabo and Wik decisions acknowledges that a lot of the jurisprudence which has now been introduced into Australian law has its foundations in the developments of the common law of both Canada and the United States. In both those jurisdictions, the Supreme Courts have found the possibility—and made actual findings—of native title actually existing on freehold title.

If we are following down that course of jurisprudence in developing our common law along those similar lines, then it stands to reason that one day a similar finding may be made by the High Court. It is interesting that, in this article in the Sydney Morning Herald, we are told:
Lawyers know how to read a High Court judgment. They know the basis of Mabo is that white freehold—
I have not heard of black freehold; I am not sure what is meant by that, but nevertheless—
extinguishes native title.
It is a very clever piece of advocacy but it completely and utterly ignores the development in the Wik case.

Who wrote the main judgment in the Mabo decision? None other than Justice Brennan, as he then was. Who wrote the chief dissenting judgment in the Wik decision? None other than Chief Justice Brennan. He said this on page 30 of his decision, in disagreeing with the Wik decision:
And, if leases were of that character, an estate in fee simple would be no different.

So the logic in the mind of Chief Justice Brennan is this: that the logic of the majority decision of Wik, if logically followed through, could well mean that freehold title could be similarly affected; and, at the moment, I doubt that the High Court would make that decision.

But I say to the Senate that Justice Brennan in the Mabo decision doubted, as everybody else at the time doubted—including then Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Bob Collins and the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating—after the Mabo decision that native title could be found to exist on pastoral leases. But, with a change of personnel in the High Court, we have different people deciding things differently—which they are quite entitled to do. We got a different and, indeed, unexpected decision in the Wik case.

Where is the guarantee to the Australian people that, with further changes to the personnel in the High Court, the logical consequence which the Chief Justice pointed to will not arise? I do not mind journalists and other people putting forward their point of view, just as long as they fairly report the argument that the other side are putting forward. They can put their own spin on it at the end and then let the readers decide. But not to allow one word of the authorities that were being relied upon is dishonest or trimming the truth.

As time is short, I cannot make all the points that I wish to make. In conclusion, I indicate that I have responded to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald by way of letter to the editor. Part of my letter reads as follows:
Without the hyperbole, the facts are:
1. The High Court is not bound by its own decisions, ie. they can change them at any time and do so;
2. Coalition MP's were accused of "lying" and "misrepresenting" the Mabo decision when the question of native title on pastoral leases was raised during the Native Title Bill debate in 1993;

3. Noel Pearson interestingly said on 10 November 1993 at the National Press Club: "As to litigating (over pastoral leases) on the basis of native title, it would be as fruitless as pursuing native claims in relation to valid freehold titles."

Seeing they have now succeeded on pastoral leases, does it not follow, according to Noel Pearson's logic, that they must therefore also be successful on freehold titles? I then quoted Chief Justice Brennan, who I have already referred to. The fifth point I made was as follows:

5. The common law developments of native title in Australia was guided by overseas jurisprudence especially in Canada and the U.S.A. In both those jurisdictions native title has been found to exist on freehold title;
6. Who can guarantee these developments will not occur in Australia?;
7. Who can guarantee the High Court will not alter its view?; and,
8. If the position is so cut and dried why doesn't Labor agree to the government proposal to legislatively confirm what—
it allegedly—
"knows to be the truth"?
And for the record, the freehold debate only started because Labor refused to support the government's amendments confirming what Labor . . . assert as a self evident truth.

We have had an interesting development overnight, as you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President. The assertion made at the very end of the article was that all the government had to do was make a simple statement, `freehold backyards are absolutely safe.' And then it was pondered, `Would the government make this statement later this week or not at all?' The interesting thing is: guess who have changed their mind? The Australian Labor Party, by introducing an amendment to say exactly that.

We were not stared down by the campaign of misrepresentation. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, got himself into big trouble yesterday on radio and, in doing so, had to do what we have now called the backyard backflip and has now come very much closer to the Liberal point of view on this.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The other day, senators may remember I asked a question of the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. In fact, that question had to do with some events that had taken place in South Australia a few years ago. In essence, the germane part of the question was whether or not Senator Minchin, who is now responsible for the Electoral Act, would outlaw overseas donations—that is, that donations to political parties that are sourced outside Australia would be banned as a matter of course as soon as amendments to the Electoral Act are dealt with in this place and the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred the other day to a document from Senator Minchin, which I will read into the record shortly. But before doing so, I want to say that the question posed the other day was an accurate, straight‐up‐and‐down question about the source of overseas donations—not something that we in the Labor Party have generally had much problem with. Indeed, when I asked that question I noted that Senator Ferguson, who had been the president of the South Australian branch, had been roped in as well. The preamble to the question indicated that there was some difference between Senator Ferguson and Senator Minchin on these points.

I inform the Senate that that was wrong; that part of the question was not correct. Senator Ferguson—and I apologise to him for this—in fact was not the President of the South Australian Liberal Party when the Catch Tim and Moriki donations were made.

We now have more information on this matter, because one of the obvious things that happens when you ask a question in this place or somewhere else is that various members of the Liberal Party make sure you are kept up to date with all sorts of information. They want to make sure that you know exactly what is going on, so I have another document which I will read into the record after I have read the Senator Minchin document.

At this stage, I want to make it crystal clear to the Senate that Senator Ferguson was an innocent party who got wrapped up in the whole thing. The only sin he committed was to be President of the Liberal Party—something which I hope he has confessed at the appropriate time, when he has gone to church—but he was in no way connected with any of these overseas donations.

As I understand it, Senator Ferguson ceased being the President of the Liberal Party in August 1992. The donations actually came from much closer to home. As I understand it, the money was washed through Hong Kong—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to revisit all this? You want to start a new war on all this rubbish, do you?
—You can have your turn. I do not get blackmailed or frightened by any of those sorts of comments. If you want to do that, that is fine; go right ahead. Just put yourself on the speakers list.

SPEECH.PARA: The events surrounded donations which were supposedly sourced in Hong Kong and Singapore. Indeed, as I understand it, the source of the money was much closer to home. This memorandum to the state executive from Nick Minchin had as its subject `Catch Tim/Moriki Donations Affair', and was dated 5 April 1995. I quote:
Today's Advertiser contains an article . . . in which an anonymous Federal Liberal MP seeks to blame me and Grahame Morris for the Catch Tim/Moriki donations debacle.
The article says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: A Federal MP, who did not wish to be named, said yesterday any move against Ms Chapman would be "met with mirth".

SPEECH.PARA: And there is a quote within this article:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "It is the people who were the agents (State Directors) of the Party at the time of the donations who should be blamed for any problems, not Ms Chapman" the MP said.

SPEECH.PARA: I am dismayed by this extraordinary and gutless attempt to divert the blame for this debacle onto me and Grahame Morris, who were the respective Directors at the time the donations in question were received, and I am exercising my right to refute this attack.
The attack on Grahame Morris is particularly stupid, given his current role as political adviser to John Howard.
The relevant facts are these:

I was State Director at the time the Moriki Products donation was received in February `93. I was succeeded by Grahame Morris in May `93, who was State Director at the time the Catch Tim donation was received in November `93.

In February `93 I was occupied full-time with running the Federal Campaign in SA for the March election. The President and Treasurer, with the Finance Committee, had responsibility for the fundraising that took place during the campaign, and subsequently took credit for the amount raised. I was not involved in fundraising during the campaign. (It should be noted that most of the money raised in SA for the Federal campaign was raised through the "Hewson for PM" campaign when Alan Ferguson was President and James Porter the Acting Treasurer).

That is why the other day we assumed they were the two relevant gentlemen at that particular point. In fact, that is not so. In the case of Alan Ferguson, as I have said to the Senate before, I certainly apologise for roping him into the question. It goes on:

When I was advised in February `93 that $50,000 had been donated by a Singapore company called Moriki Products, I naturally asked about the donor and the reason for the donation. I was assured that it was "a Gerard Industries donation".

Given my campaign responsibilities, I accepted the explanation and did not make further inquiries. While very uncomfortable about overseas donations (this being the only one I was aware of in my 8 years as Director) I accepted Mr Gerard's right to donate to the Party via a Singapore entity.
In my 8 years as State Director, I never knew of the existence of, let alone met Mr Bill Henderson, who we now know apparently obtained the Moriki and Catch Tim donations for the Party.
That is under the hand of Senator Minchin, who clears not only the role of himself in this particular matter but also the role of Senator Ferguson.

Senator Minchin, in my experience of him, has always been an honourable man. Indeed, he had nothing to do with the overseas donations. Any imputation that people have against Senator Minchin because they think he may have been the conduit for these questionable overseas donations—they were quite controversial when they were declared—and may have had an association should not be taken because Senator Minchin had nothing to do with it. In fact, he makes it quite clear in his communication that he did not want anything to do with it.

The other document we have here is under the hand of the Minister for Justice, Senator Amanda Vanstone. We start to find out what was happening on 5 April 1995. I will quote from a memo to state councillors from the minister. It reads:
I am writing to you to express my concern at some recent press reports in relation to the so-called Catch Tim matter. I am writing to you because I am unable to be at State Council.

You may have seen an article by John Ferguson in The Advertiser on Saturday. I have attached a copy in case you missed it. I've also attached a copy of an article by Philip White from several weeks ago.

Both these articles demonstrate only too clearly that we still have people amongst us who are not prepared to work together as a team. Rather than playing as a team, they background and leak information to the press that is designed to damage fellow Liberals, in this case, Vickie Chapman and Dean Brown.
Everyone knows who Dean Brown was. Vickie Chapman was the President of the Liberal Party's South Australian division when the donations came in. It continues:
The temptation is of course to return the favour and once that spiral starts, any semblance of unity is lost.
No-one need imagine that Catch Tim was an issue in the last fortnight of sittings in Federal Parliament, nor that the idea for the article came like a bolt out of the blue to John Ferguson.
Equally, with respect to the Philip White article, what kind of person would bother to give that kind of detailed information to a gossip columnist?

Perhaps you can imagine how depressing and frustrating it is to see these sorts of articles. To me, it's just another example of a limited few who speak with forked tongues. Their calls for unity appear to be nothing more than a smokescreen behind which they can go on with their endless pursuit of personalities, who they, for one reason or another, have a gripe against.

For most of the ten years I have been in Parliament, State Councillors and Branch Members have bemoaned what has appeared to be a lack of unity in the Party. No-one needs to be reminded how damaging disunity can be.

Unity will only come in reality when people actually demonstrate their preparedness to work together for the common goal of winning. That's why in any leadership contest, I have always looked to who I thought would do the best job, rather than whether they were a personality from any one particular viewpoint in the Party.
The letter goes on to bemoan the whole thing. In fact, this was the article that was quoted in the Adelaide Advertiser of that particular day.

BREAK.PARA: I can understand why the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, got up in such a hurry to have this particular issue put down and have the question ruled out of order. What was really going on—we did not realise it until we were fully briefed afterwards—was that it was Senator Hill's side of the Liberal Party that was trying to shove the Catch Tim-Moriki donations onto poor old Senator Ferguson and in particular Senator Minchin.

What the Amanda Vanstone letter was seeking to do was to say that it was the Dean Brown side of the equation—that is, Dean Brown and Vickie Chapman, who was then the president of the division. It was seeking to say—when they received the money—that it was really the fault of a past president and it was really the fault of a very uncomfortable state director at that time and his successor, Grahame Morris, who would have to take the wrap for these particular donations. In fact, it was nothing of the sort.

It was Amanda Vanstone's very good friend, Mr Gerard, from Gerard Industries—under various names and aliases which we took several months to track down—who was responsible for the donations and it was the Dean Brown crowd that took pleasure not only in announcing how much money they raised for the 1993 state election but also that particular crew had to wear the publicity and the storm that went through the party and the media when all this came out. Then on 5 April, they obviously tried to unload this particular bucket of excrement all over innocent parties.

The other day the question we asked, from very limited documents, indicated that we had, in part, thought there was some truth in the proposition that Senator Minchin and Senator Ferguson were involved in it. They were not involved in it at all—very far from it. Senator Hill quickly got to his feet. Senator Hill is a very quick, sharp and shrewd man and I have a great deal of respect for him. He understood where this was going and knew, far better than I, where it was going—right to the heart of the little clique that ran the Liberal Party in South Australia at that time and surrounded Premier Dean Brown and his good mate from just over the other side of the railway lines at Gerard Industries. They were picking up as many dollars as they could from whatever questionable sources.

In fact, had they not been so cocky and called the thing `Catch Tim', I do not think they would have drawn anyone's attention to it. I guess that will be something, when the next lot of donations come out, at which we will have to look more closely. I am sure some people have learnt a few lessons in the meantime.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.24 p.m. to 1.35 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the joint amendment on sheet 832. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening fairly closely to this part of the debate and I give my congratulations to those of you who have had to stick through every detail of this entire bill. I have listened closely to this stage because I think it is a very important one. The joint amendment of the Democrats, opposition and green parties is one that I think a lot of attention is being paid to. I think it is important that the arguments on both sides are clearly put and able to be understood, regardless of what actual view each of us has about the merits of our own position. Certainly, when I go back to my electorate, I would like to be able to explain in a reasonably clear way why various decisions were taken, particularly on this one, because it is an important one.

SPEECH.PARA: We are actually debating whether or not a line should be put in to specify that this Native Title Act is to be construed as subject to the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. I would like to ask Senator Harradine one or two questions so that he can elaborate on his previous comments. I did listen closely to the explanations he was giving, but I was not totally clear on a couple of bits and I wanted to get clarification.

There were two main points. One was his concern about the potential for a lawyers picnic if this amendment was agreed to. Certainly nobody wants a lawyers picnic but, on my understanding of how this would operate, putting this clause in would not necessarily mean that a whole lot of extra court cases would suddenly appear with people challenging the act. I would have thought that this would operate as a guide to the courts and tribunals when they are considering the operation of the Native Title Act in all the various ways that it is going to operate in the future. I am not sure why this particular clause would generate a whole lot of extra legal contests. I would have thought it would be a useful guide for legal issues that are going to happen anyway. I would appreciate some clarification on that, and perhaps from the minister as well.

The other point was my understanding of what Senator Harradine was saying about the alternative approach which would work if we had vigorous ministers—I think that was his phrase—or ministers who were vigorously pursuing and monitoring the operation of things to make sure that indigenous interests were upheld. If my understanding of that is correct, I seek an indication from Senator Harradine that he is confident that the ministers at the federal level will be sufficiently vigorous in pursuing that. Even if that is the case, I do not know what the state ministers are like in Tasmania but I certainly would not be highly confident of the relevant ministers at state level in Queensland putting a lot of energy into ensuring that indigenous interests are protected. In this debate, my colleague Senator Woodley has spoken a number of times about things that have happened in the past, which I think would indicate that my concern is reasonably well founded, particularly under previous National Party‐led governments but also, to a lesser extent, under the previous Goss administration. So I would like to get some clarification, at least, about the rationale behind the alternative position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the opportunity to respond to what was at least inferentially a question to me as well about the legal difficulties of this proposal. I did outline them in my first remarks on this, but you have to remember that the Native Title Act is a Commonwealth piece of legislation which applies now to 79 per cent of Australia in effect—more if the Greens were to have their way. Everywhere that native title may have survived, the Native Title Act applies. It is the relevant law. Anything done on 79 per cent of Australia that does not comply with the Native Title Act in some way or other is potentially invalid.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the most massive federal intervention ever in the land management systems of Australia by the Commonwealth parliament. Everything that is proposed to be done on 79 per cent of Australia must comply with that act or it can be asserted to be invalid. That is why the act is so big. It has to allow for so many different circumstances. This is a nation of 18 million people with a highly productive economy and with things going on in that land all the time. Everything that is done must comply.

The point of the Native Title Act, and the reason why you have to have a native title act, is to provide the requisite certainty as to what is valid and invalid with regard to native title. It is the rule book with which everybody who operates on land must comply—all the governments, every mining company, every farmer and everybody who does anything on land. If you do not comply with it, then your actions are invalid. If the mining industry, for example, were about to invest in a multibillion dollar mine it has to know that there is no sovereign risk to its investment. It has to know that the title it secures is a valid title, otherwise its whole investment is at risk, as is everything it does.

This applies right across the board to everybody doing anything on that 79 per cent of Australia where native title may have survived. There must be a certain rule book. As I mentioned before, the ALP recognised that in 1993. Their own Senate committee said that subjecting the provisions of what was then the Native Title Bill to the Racial Discrimination Act should not be done because of the uncertainty that would create, contrary to one of the very basic objectives of the legislation.

The uncertainty derives from the fact that everything otherwise validly done under the Native Title Act is challengeable, as a matter of law, as being inconsistent with or not complying with the Racial Discrimination Act. Anyone who is unhappy about anything done validly under the Native Title Act has a cause of action in bringing a challenge to that otherwise validly issued title on the grounds that it breaches another Commonwealth act, the Racial Discrimination Act. It is not a rule book per se—it is a broad set of principles based on the principle of non‐discrimination.

Anybody who seeks to do things or invest millions is faced not only with all the normal hurdles—environmental regulations, heritage, state approvals; there is quite a myriad of approvals that are required before you can do anything—but also has to make sure that their actions are consistent with the Native Title Act. Not only that, once you have got all that approval you cannot get a tick off on the RDA. You are then simply subject to the potential of someone bringing a court action against you on the grounds that what you did—no matter that it is entirely valid under the rule book, the NTA—is challengeable on the grounds that it is somehow inconsistent with the RDA, and you must wait for a court to make a determination on that matter. That is why the Labor senators in the Senate committee of 1993 said it is an impossibility. That is why we believe it is an impossibility and it would render this whole bill unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we broke for lunch, Senator Harradine expressed his confidence in vigorous ministers and in particular he mentioned Commonwealth ministers. I actually have not noticed—
—If you have that impression, I am sorry. That is not what I meant.
—This conversation would be better if it were actually heard by everybody, I suspect.

—Yes, certainly. I certainly did get the impression that the bill, or the rights of indigenous people, could or would be defended. Somehow or other, there was the impression that the bill was acceptable to the Senate—and I would say, acceptable to the majority of the Senate, it might in the end be. But I certainly do not believe you can make that sweeping statement.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time Senator Harradine said that nobody would disagree that this bill is not for the benefit of indigenous Australians, I did interject and say, `Well, this person does,' and I heard a couple of people more say the same thing. There are vigorous ministers. But it is not possible under the constitution, at least for federal ministers—for instance, federal ministers for Aboriginal affairs—to protect indigenous rights after this bill has been enacted, without the Racial Discrimination Act in place.

We are leaving indigenous Australians to the whim of state governments. And we know already what is in the preamble to the Queensland native title bill—it is basically rubbing its hands with glee. We know that the state government in Western Australia has helped to draft this bill, and it has everything in place ready to go. We do not know the half of what regulations will come out of this bill. In reality, under the constitution, under the powers that exist, if this bill goes through without the Racial Discrimination Act amendment, there is no federal minister who can protect the rights of the indigenous Australians.

The Racial Discrimination Act provision is not to invalidate the Native Title Act as amended but rather to ensure that indigenous people's rights, under the Native Title Act, are lifted to the level of protection offered by the Racial Discrimination Act. In my opinion, if this act is reducing the rights available under the Racial Discrimination Act, one would have to ask why.

This will not bring uncertainty. In fact, it is the only certainty that indigenous people can have that they will not be discriminated against on the basis of race. What other assurances have they been given in all of this debate we have had over the last week or so?

If we are unable to do this, if the votes in the Senate are such that the Racial Discrimination Act amendment before us is not supported, the government and Senator Harradine will be sending a message to the world. That message is that Australia supports racial discrimination; that Australia supports the fact that, when a government gets into government, it should be able to do whatever it darn well likes because it is government; that, as long as the government uses the words `jobs' and `investment', whatever rights it trammels, whatever cultural practices, environmental standards, people's feelings and government inaction, it could and should do whatever it likes.

Senator Harradine on many occasions has stood proudly on the issue of human rights—not just in Australia, but also in other parts of the world. Sadly, most of the bill that the government proposed is still standing; some minor changes have been made to it. But, in terms of human rights, there is no way that anybody could or should stand in this chamber and say that there is nobody who disagrees that this bill is not for the benefit of indigenous people.

All around this Parliament House, we have representatives from various indigenous bodies and individuals from right around Australia. If we cannot believe them when they say that the bill is not for their benefit, it might be construed as paternalism. If we cannot believe indigenous people when they say that the bill is not for their benefit, who in the end do we believe? Who sets whether or not a bill is of benefit for indigenous people?

Do we say that only a government can decide whether a bill is of benefit for indigenous people? Remember, that is the way Australia has operated certainly up until the sixties, and many say beyond that. Somebody in government was the one to say what was good and what was bad for indigenous people. That is paternalism.

All we have the right or ability to do here is to try to represent the views of those in the community who are saying, `No, we cannot allow this injustice to go through unspoken.' We cannot stand in this chamber and say, `The government knows best. Indigenous people don't know what's good for them. What's good for them is to have their rights taken away.'

Given a choice of having their rights taken away or going to an election, what do you think indigenous Australians are saying to me? They are saying, `Let's have an election.' That is what they are saying to me. I am getting calls, I am getting letters. People are coming to me all the time. If we are talking about their rights and what is good for Australia, what choice would indigenous people make if asked whether they would like their rights taken away or to go to an election? They are saying, `Let's have an election.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given this further thought, and I have been conscious of what we did in 1983. What we did in 1983 was to include in the Native Title Act provision 7(1), `Nothing in this act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1995.' Let me just put a couple of things to rest, first of all.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great deal of concern around the place that there is a new regime, and that much of the power will be devolved from the state. As people know who are speaking about this matter, the argument yesterday was over an issue that I was rather concerned about. That is, that there should be—and right throughout this debate I have been concerned to ensure that there is—conformity of administration decision‐making right throughout Australia, whether of the NNTT or of the state bodies.

I did express yesterday, or the day before yesterday, in various conversations with various people my concern about that need and how that could best be achieved. One of those ways is this question of the legislation being subject to the Racial Discrimination Act. I thought that perhaps that might have been too much of a reflection. What I thought I said this morning before lunch was that, if that was not going to be done, one of the ways to ensure that the legislation operates in a proper fashion is by an effective federal minister. I do not know whether you thought I said state ministers. I also said that at a political level in the states it would be important to ensure that the message gets across to the various state ministers. That is the point that I was making. The biggest point this morning was that I had come to the conclusion that, if we did what is being proposed in Senator Bolkus's amendment, the federal government would regard this measure as totally unworkable.

I suppose I was encouraged in that belief by what Senator Margetts has been saying on this issue. She indicated in her speech that she believed slabs of this legislation—she did not use the word `slabs', but whatever word she used—are inconsistent with the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. I could envisage under those circumstances that there would be huge numbers of cases and endless litigation, and that would do nothing for the certainty that we are trying to achieve here.

What I said this morning was that this measure was beneficial to Aboriginals. It is beneficial to indigenous native title claimants, because it is better for all stakeholders—whether they be indigenous people, pastoral leaseholders, miners or whoever—for this to be done in a way according to statute, which has processes which would be able to achieve results years and years before similar results could be achieved in the courts. Nobody can say that that is not the case, because that is the case. This legislation is important to ensure that these measures are properly determined in accordance with the statute with as much certainty as possible. Otherwise, you leave it to the common law and you leave it to the courts, and that would do nothing for any of the stakeholders. It would mean interminable delays and so on.

I had regard to the contribution of my colleague Senator Cooney prior to the suspension of the sitting. I was very interested to hear what Senator Cooney said in view of the fact that he was one of those on the legal and constitutional committee that made the recommendations which were adverted to by Senator Minchin. After having given that consideration, after having regard to what Senator Cooney said and having had further discus sions and considerations over lunch, I am coming to the view that, unless we do what is being proposed—that is, to have the bill read and construed subject to the provisions of the RDA—we may be sending the wrong messages to the whole of Australia and to all Australians—not only indigenous persons but also other people who are likely to require the provisions of this act to resolve problems and issues in a sensible, ordered fashion that I believe is contained in this measure.

I feel that it would be unwise for the government to maintain the view that it would be unworkable. The view I had come to was that the government would regard it as totally unworkable if the RDA provisions went in. I hope the government will see that, in the end, it is probably better to have the RDA provisions there. We tried it in 1993 in subsection 7(1), which states:
Nothing in this Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.
If we do not have some exceptions for this particular measure here, things like validation could be regarded as being contrary and inconsistent with the RDA provisions.

As has been expressed around the chamber, subsection 7(1) of the RDA was found by the High Court to be less than operable. That is the message that has been given to us by the High Court. Perhaps we ought to heed that message and include what is being proposed by the opposition in this bill. Otherwise you could have efforts by some people to overturn this measure by stating that the measure is not constitutional under the race power.

I would rather stick with having cases run pursuant to legislation that this parliament has passed rather than having court cases based on the constitutional race power which might overturn the whole lot. So I do apologise to the committee and indicate now that I am supporting the amendment proposed by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that there is all that much need for more debate, but I would like to put two things on the record from this morning's debate. First of all, in introducing this amendment I indicated that we were making this clause apply to the whole act as amended rather than the bill. I think much of Senator Harradine's argument and Senator Cooney's argument this morning flowed from that as one of the basic points.

SPEECH.PARA: At one stage Senator Harradine was asking who did not believe that this was a special measure. I do not know what message got down here or what message came from up there, but a number of us might have been identified in the Hansard as indicating that it was not. The point I was making this morning before that part of the debate was that, by applying this particular clause to the whole act, then you would be triggering the special measure provisions that could prevail and were recognised in the High Court in WA and the Commonwealth as doing what Senator Harradine has just said they would do.

With this provision, you have a mechanism in place where the bill as a whole would be assessed, not individual clauses. When assessing the bill as a whole, the fact that it has already been recognised by the court as having a capacity, I suppose, to constitute a special measure is something that we should take into account. The beneficial nature of the package the first time around, as I said this morning, would also be taken into account. So in the interests of both justice and certainty, I think Senator Harradine's position as he has just spelt it out is spot on.

I say to Senator Harradine and others who might be listening to this debate, we have been going for over 41 hours. I think we have probably made a fairly good job of what we have done. We are dealing with both technical legal points and arguments—highly contestable arguments, political arguments and social arguments. The fact that all of these arguments come together in the legal points that we were discussing before lunch and now should be recognised.

In that being recognised, I think people should go to the substantive point that we are going to here: certainty and justice do demand this sort of provision. We got it wrong the first time round and it was not strong enough. This time we are looking at revising that position of 1993 but also doing it in a manner which, under this amendment, gives the government a bit more capacity for its legisla tion to be upheld than would otherwise prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say briefly that Senator Harradine spoke with profound wisdom prior to lunch about the legal uncertainty that would flow from adoption of this amendment. I am not sure what he had for lunch, but after lunch that has all gone. I retain my respect for Senator Harradine, but he was right before lunch and he is wrong after lunch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been somewhat of a roller‐coaster, but from the point of view of thinking about the indigenous interests and, indeed, the wider interest of Australians who are concerned that we do not end up with a discriminatory provision, the roller‐coaster, which was somewhat on the downward, has come up again.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the conscience that Senator Harradine does apply to matters like this and also the merit of debate in this place has to be acknowledged. It is not easy. This is a matter of great moment. It has long-term significance. Senator Harradine also has at a moment like this, taking into account very difficult measures under great pressure, quite clearly the bigness to change his mind because he thinks that is in the interests of the country as a whole, and I accept that.
Amendment agreed to.
An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We now proceed to sheet 20.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —To those who might be following this debate, I point out that there is one more topic to go after this one and then we have a degree of housekeeping. We are in the home straight. This is an important part. I suppose we had to have something to follow on the unity of the opposition parties in the previous debate. Let us now go to one where we will not be agreeing with each other; we will go back to the three‐way spat that we had on one other issue yesterday. It has to be noted that of the 21 different parcels we have only had substantive disagreement on two.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are dealing with here is the government proposal to allow a range of activities to take place on pastoral leases going beyond traditional pastoral uses. This will occur without compulsory acquisition and without the native title holders having the right to negotiate, as would have been the case under the 1993 legislation. The activities that are allowed to go beyond what are current legally available rights to pastoralists have the potential to give them a windfall gain at the expense of not only indigenous Australians but all of us who may have to pay the ultimate burden of compensation due to the impairment of native title.

The bill proposes changes which materially diminish native title rights which have been reflected in the Mabo and Wik decisions. In doing so, we think they fail the test of certainty and workability. I am sure, in respect of some of these changes, the government will have to look at amendments in the not too distant future.

The Labor Party proposes an alternative which gives certainty but also gives a degree of justice to indigenous Australians, which is an important consideration in this debate. Our proposal is three tiered. If the pastoralist simply wants to engage in traditional pastoralist activities—that is, activities and property developments necessarily incidental to the raising and movement of livestock, including pasture improvement, cropping, on‐farm use, sowing of exotic grasses and partial irrigation—the legislation should expressly remove any possible uncertainty about the pastoralist's right to engage in those activities. As a consequence, no question would arise about notification or rights to negotiate and the like.

The second level would cut in where a pastoralist wanted to go beyond traditional uses to engage in activities like intensive cropping, land clearance, gravel taking, commercial culling or the like. In these circumstances, we propose, as opposed to the government's proposal of giving pastoralists open slather, a regime which ensures a capacity to do what pastoralists can legally do and have a capacity to legally do at the moment and which also allows for flexibility to ensure that critical native title interests are promoted and pastoralists cannot go open slather, but, at the same time, they do have a right to keep on doing exactly what they have been doing in these respects in the past.

The elements of the plan are that an application would be made by the pastoralists in these circumstances to the relevant state or territory authority as he or she does now and he or she would ask for the permit in the normal way. The granting of the permission or the interest in question—whether it is a licence permit or the like—by such bodies would not be challengeable if done in good faith on familiar agricultural, environmental or planning policy grounds.

Notification of the application would be given to rep bodies and registered native title claimants to allow representations to be made on the heritage or other potential significant adverse impacts of the permission sought. It would be made clear that permitted diversification activities would not include major regional irrigation projects, like the proposed Fitzroy River scheme—a scheme which would significantly change land use over a wide area. Diversification activity would not be permitted under these provisions if it meant that the dominant purpose of the lease was no longer pastoral.

We would provide that native title would not be extinguished, but suspended, to use Senator Harradine's word, for the duration of inconsistency, reflecting what we believe will be the common law. Also to the extent that permission or interest granted did adversely impact on native title rights, appropriate compensation would be obtainable from the relevant state or territory. I say the relevant state or territory because it is important to put on them an obligation to be responsible in these matters. In those circumstances the pastoralist would not be personally involved in any way at all.

We then have a third level. In those circumstances where a pastoralist sought a formal upgrading of title to, for instance, a perpetual lease or a freehold type status, the Native Title Act should continue to apply.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that our proposal allows pastoral activities, gives flexibility to allow authorities to permit further diversification in circumstances where native title holders are holders of procedural rights of notification and objection and provides a good balance. We think the government's plan goes too far. It has problems in terms of discrimination, and particularly with reference to the just terms provisions of the constitution. It takes the definition of pastoralists too far. It goes as far as primary production, which we think is too much of a grab. It goes further than the Wik case in terms of the upgrades. Our concern also is that the taxpayer will pay.

The definition in the tax act of primary production we think is too broad. Off‐farm activities allowable under the government's scheme are too expansive. We have a qualification on them to ensure protection against excessive overreach. In terms of grants to third parties, the government proposes to allow them to do acts on non‐exclusive pastoral or agricultural leases. This, for instance, can include giving a third party right to cut and remove timber, extract or remove gravel, quarry, remove rocks or whatever. We believe there should be some control there. We note that the most recent government amendment clarifies the position in respect of some off‐farm activities, but all it really does is indicate that you cannot do them without formal permission. We do not reckon that is good enough.

We do have a number of concerns. We do not believe that the compensation just terms provisions of the constitution are met. In terms of notification, the provisions there are not good enough. We do not see that there are adequate procedural rights in the government's proposal. Without those adequate procedural rights, the government will have immediate constitutional problems under the just terms provisions.

The other problem we have is that once again here we have the government allowing the removal of the right to negotiate by states. Proposed 43A allows the states to propose an alternative regime to the right to negotiate on leased areas, including pastoral leases. We have to be concerned as to what sort of open slather use that would give the green light to.

We do oppose the government's proposals. We do have an alternative constructive proposal before the chamber and we look forward to moving that at a later date. I do say to the government once again that it spent the last debate arguing that we need certainty and constitutionality. Unfortunately, in terms of at least the just terms provision, if not the racist power, the government would have some problems with this particular proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the hour, I am not going to speak at great length on this section. But it is probably the most important section because the people most affected by the Wik decision are of course Australia's farmers. As we know, they operated on the assurances given to them by all that pastoral leases extinguished native title and that their leases were secure. That is what they were promised in 1993. The Wik case completely changed that by its decision by a bare majority that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguish native title.

SPEECH.PARA: The farmers of Australia said to us, `That is completely unacceptable.' Here we have a bare majority of the court making a decision with profound implications for 42 per cent of Australia and so many of Australia's farmers and the security of their titles and businesses in which they have invested their lives. They said to us, `You have to do what Keating promised us. He said in 1993 that our leases are secure. That is what we want. That is all we ask for. What you promised us in 1993.'

In effect they asked us to implement the decision of the architect of Mabo, Chief Justice Brennan in the Wik decision, where, of course, Justices Brennan, McHugh and Dawson all found that pastoral leases do extinguish native title. We said after much consideration and debate that that was not a position we could adopt. We as a government could not move to extinguish native title on pastoral leases now that the High Court had found by a four‐three majority that leases did not necessarily extinguish native title, but we did say to Australia's farmers that we would put together a package which, while respecting the common law right to seek a determination of native title on pastoral leases, would give Australia's farmers the certainty they need to continue their businesses which have been the backbone of this country for so very long.

Australia's farmers do work hard for this country in the most extraordinarily difficult circumstances—the driest, hardest conditions in the world—and have been and are the most efficient farmers in the world. They deserve the security which this package delivers them. We believe that we have found the right balance between delivering them that certainty, but at the same time preserving the common law right to claim native title in accordance with the Wik decision.

I think we are supported by the Australian people in that. You will have seen in the recent Bulletin poll that 81 per cent of Australians say that farmers should be guaranteed that they can use their land as needed. There are recent surveys showing that the Australian people believe that the Australian farming industry is the most important industry in the country and, of course, for much of our history it has indeed been our most important industry. The Australian people recognise both the sacrifice and the contribution that farmers make to the economy, livelihood and security of this country.

Our package gives them that security; the security to get on with their businesses to generate the jobs, income and livelihoods upon which so many of us do depend, but, at the same time, on the basis of the non‐extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases and full compensation wherever native title is impaired.

A lot of people say, `But the Wik decision was that pastoralists' rights prevail, so what is the problem?' The problem is that the Native Title Act was written on the presumption that it would not apply on pastoral leases. Therefore, it took no account of the fact of the Wik decision saying that native title can survive. It was written on the presumption that it would only apply on vacant crown land and Aboriginal land, and therefore it makes no allowance whatsoever for its application on pastoral lease land and the interaction of pastoral lessees and native title holders. The operation of the act, because it was written in that way, is what matters, not what the High Court said.

The High Court by its Wik decision triggered the application of the Native Title Act on pastoral leases, so that everything done on a pastoral lease has to comply with the Native Title Act and it does not allow for the Wik decision to be implemented. It does not actually allow the proposition that the statutory rights of the pastoralists prevail over the common law rights of the native title holders, which is of course what the Wik decision.

Our package gives effect to the Wik decision. It does ensure that farmers can continue to engage in primary production on their pastoral leases. It does ensure that, wherever native title rights are found to coexist, they are subject to the rights of the pastoralist. It does ensure that additional grants of primary production rights on pastoral leases cannot extinguish native title, but shall only prevail.

In fact, we are doing more than the common law position, because in common law it is quite clear from the Wik decision that governments can grant rights that extinguish native title on pastoral leases. We are saying, no, that is not the case. Additional rights can be granted, but they shall operate on the basis that effectively they suppress—or suspend, as Senator Harradine would put it—the native title; they do not extinguish it.

The only way in which native title can be extinguished is if there is a compulsory acquisition, as under the current act, and that acquisition can only occur in a non‐discriminatory way for genuine land management reasons where there is a change of purpose and where all the rights in relation to the relevant area of land are acquired compulsorily in a non‐discriminatory way.

We believe it is the right package and the right balance. It is a sacrifice on the part of Australia's farmers. They do not like this. They have asked us to do much more than we are doing, but we believe we have struck the right balance and we are asking them to compromise. They are compromising in the acceptance of this and we ask the parliament to accept this as the right compromise that does ensure farmers can carry on their businesses with some certainty, at the same time ensuring that native title claimants and holders can pursue their common law rights and exercise them in accordance with the Wik decision.

On the basis that we believe after much long, hard discussion and work and taking account of all the expressions of opinion put to us over many months on this issue that we have the right balance, we are not in a position to accept any of the amendments proposed by the other parties. This is a delicate balance which does strike the right chord, and we ask the parliament to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to make a long speech about this. I think that most of the issues have been debated at such great length now that we all know what they are. I have checked the amendments on the running sheet where it says there is conflict between ALP amendment 222 and Democrat‐Greens amendment 189. They are identical, so if there is some conflict as you say, Senator Margetts, it would be helpful if you could point out where that is. I will make some further comments as we come to the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the elements of this package is that I guess each of them works in with the other. There is an agreement obviously between the amendments of the Australian Labor Party in relation to their amendment 50 and Greens (WA) amendment 45, which basically removes the government's definition of primary production. In section 24GA the government is suggesting that pastoral leases can involve primary production including the following:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) cultivating land;
(b) maintaining, breeding or agisting animals;
(c) taking or catching fish or shellfish;
(d) forest operations (defined in section 253)
(e) horticultural activities (see section 253 for the definition of horticulture );
(f) aquacultural activities;
(g) leaving fallow or de‐stocking any land in connection with the doing ofanything that is a primary production activity.

And mining is excluded from that. The difference in the position taken by the Australian Labor Party and the Greens-Democrats amendments supported by the National Indigenous Working Group is that there is a very narrow definition.

It was a difficult decision, I guess, in terms of upgrades, but the definition supported by the Greens, Democrats and National Indigenous Working Group under these, I have to say, compromise amendments is to limit the level of activities to those supported by the current definition under the Northern Territory native title act. It is in their future act regime. That is actually an important mechanism. Unfortunately, I think there is too much scope in what is proposed by that of the opposition, certainly in cases like in Western Australia where substantial amounts of other activity might be considered to be acceptable without the right to negotiate. I think this is a major problem still.

We know that the government's position is as I have read out—basically that pastoral leases equals farms—which I think many people in Australia would think was outrageous, considering the expectation, certainly in Western Australia, that pastoral lease largely means the ability to run sheep or cattle. Whilst there are very few limitations on off‐farm activities, the Greens and Democrats amendment is opposing off-farm activities being included. The opposition amendments do allow limited off‐farm activities. So it is still leaving what could be a substantial door open for the removal of native title rights.

In my opinion and in the opinion of many of the groups who are supporting the rights of indigenous Australians and also supporting the wider issues of what might be considered a substantial land grab, this is part of the other agenda that has come into this debate. I guess the agenda in support of the mining industry but the sweetener for the pastoral industry was the promise of upgrades and changes to pastoral activities to include what in states like Western Australia generally is not included in the definition of pastoral lease. So there still is a substantial difference in relation to upgrades between the opposition amendments and those of the Greens and Democrats. The wording is very similar, I have to say, but there has been a lot of careful work to find out exactly the meanings of each word and unfortunately the gap is still unacceptably wide, in my opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 9, section 24GA stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Margetts on this that there is a very considerable difference. Senator Minchin said that this was one of the most important provisions, if not the most important provision. Let us put it this way.
