There is a large pastoral lease which indigenous people enjoy traditional to and rights on and the cultural connection to the land on which has been a cattle lease since it was issued. In the future we can expect that many such leases will be subject to what is called upgrades. That means that the leaseholders will get permission to go ahead with development other than just cattle grazing.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are the rights of the indigenous people in this? We say that, while not having a right to a veto that is accepted, they ought to have a right to be able to negotiate about the change that is going to occur on their traditional land, the land of their attachment. But the Labor and government position is that that right to negotiate will not be given. Labor says that the indigenous people ought to be informed and consulted but, at the end of the day, that means far less than having a proper negotiating right.

Let us look at such a leaseholding with the Labor amendment, or, no less, the Liberal amendment, in law. If the leaseholder wants to put half of the land involved under cropping—let us say, cotton cropping—the indigenous people have no right to negotiate on that under these amendments. If to clear the land for the cotton grazing either the leaseholder or a third party cuts down all the trees in the savanna woodlands for woodchipping—let us say, in an area like the gulf or Cape York—under the Labor amendments the indigenous people have no right of negotiation or consultation and under the government amendments they have nothing.

BREAK.PARA: If there is then a damming of a river nearby and an irrigation canal brought across to irrigate the crop, under provisions variously in here, the indigenous people have no right to negotiate. If a third party is brought in to create a large gravel extraction or soil extraction works on this leaseholding—all these things eat into the traditional enjoyment of the land by the indigenous people—the indigenous people get no right to negotiate. So you have half the region totally transformed, totally unavailable to indigenous people as they knew it. It is cutting across their access, cutting across their traditional pursuits, changing the land, transmogrifying the land, with no right to negotiate with the positions taken by either the government or the opposition.

Yes, Senator Minchin, this is a heart matter here. Yes, this is core. You can envisage this is occurring on only one leaseholding here or another one over there or one somewhere else. I do not. I face the reality that next century is going to see huge changes to the face of the land of this country, and that change is going to be greatest across the north of the country where this question of native rights, indigenous rights, is most important. So, serially, under these provisions, we are going to see enormous changes to the traditional lands and the ability of people to maintain that time‐honoured attachment with the lands, including that spiritual attachment. It will all be taken away with no right to negotiate.

That is manifestly wrong. That is manifestly insupportable. That is a great retreat on the rights of the indigenous Australians. It is a great derogation of those rights. It is going to cause continuing frustration to say the least to the indigenous people, the people who are out there today who do not know what the fine print of this legislation is, but we in here do. We are making a decision here as to whether we are going to cut the indigenous people of this country out of the right to negotiate on the thing that most changes the land, the broadscale changes to these massive leaseholdings.

I reiterate that there is nothing in this legislation that says that the process cannot proceed, that the leaseholder cannot change half of his or her land to cotton crops, cannot put a dam on the river, cannot divert the river and cannot do other things like cut trees down. Nowhere have the indigenous people the right to stop that. Surely they ought to have the right to negotiate to be able to make the outcome have a lesser impact on their interests.

Make no mistake about this: this is the serial erosion of their time‐honoured rights and attachment to the land, that core thing for indigenous people right around the world—the relationship with the land, the bonding with the land. This is the serial erosion of that written into the law for the future. That is why we take the position which has been taken by negotiators for the indigenous people themselves that at least there ought to be this basic right to negotiate. That is why I will not be supporting either the opposition amendment or the government in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question of Senator Bolkus. Do the ALP provisions allow for compensation where native title rights allow for upgrade provisions?
—The answer is yes.
—I would like a bit more detail about the nature of it. Is it just terms compensation that is being dealt with?

—It is just terms. In terms of the just terms requirements, as we have always said, it is not just a matter of the actual value. It is actually a matter of process as well. Our procedures do provide for adequate procedural rights for native title claimants to be able to exercise their rights in a timely manner.
—I would like some further advice, please. Could Senator Bolkus point out to us in what part of his amendments these just terms provisions apply?

—The document is revised sheet 828. The specific reference to compensation is under 10. We interpret that as meaning just terms compensation. As I say to you, that is the compensation aspect. If you were interested in supporting that, then obviously we would be prepared to insert the words `just terms' before `compensation' to clarify any concern you might have, but we believe it is not necessary because it is covered in 53A. We do not propose a two-tier approach; compensation for the purposes of the act would be just terms under 53A. If you think there is any gap there, obviously it can be rectified.

—I would also like to ask a question of Senator Bolkus in relation to amendments 64 to 66 and 68 in relation to the rights to harvest timber, quarry for gravel and rocks and so on. What would be the impact of those acts on the ability to enjoy native title rights?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What I have said is that there are a number of effects in the legislation which are relevant to this question. Firstly, you have the notification and the advance consultation requirement. That is fairly critical because under the government's proposal there is an inadequate regime of notification and engagement with indigenous Australians. Secondly, we are concerned that it not be open slather. For instance, under our proposals, one cannot change the dominant purpose of the lease in a backdoor way. Thirdly, there is protection in respect of sacred sites.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall effect of those three measures—together with the indirect effect of having pressure put on the states not to do so freely at will, but to show some responsibility in the process by imposing on them the actual cost of the compensation that may flow from impairment of native title—is important. We believe that, if you were to allow the states to do this without some consequent responsibility, they would just be doing it at the national government's expense. The best way to put it on the states is to ensure that, if they are going to go and embark upon some of these matters with careless disregard for native title, they should also have to pay some of the bill for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of procedure—and we have been doing this with some other sections—I just wonder whether the government amendments could be put first so what we are dealing with is the government bill as amended, to the extent that the Senate accepts those amendments. Then we can deal with that bill in relation to the opposition amendments, because there are some that delete some of our things. So it would seem to be sensible to move them and have them dealt with. On that basis, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Schedule 1, item 9, page 48 (line 17), omit "farmstay", substitute "farm".

PARA.TAB: Note about Schedule 1, item 9: The heading to subsection 24GB(2) (page 48, line 14) is replaced by the heading "Farm tourism included ".

SPEECH.PARA: (20) Schedule 1, item 9, page 48 (line 23), omit "farmstay", substitute "farm".
(21) Schedule 1, item 9, page 48 (line 26) to page 49 (line 2), omit subsection (4), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (4) This section does not apply to a future act if:

TAB.TAB: (a) where the lease covered by paragraph (1)(a) is a non‐exclusive pastoral lease covering an area greater than 5,000 hectares—the act has the effect that the majority of the area covered by the lease is used for purposes other than pastoral purposes; or

(b) in any case—the act converts a lease covered by paragraph (1)(a) into a lease conferring a right of exclusive possession, or into a freehold estate, over any of the land or waters covered by the lease.

PARA.TAB: Note: If such an act is done in exercise of a legally conferred right, it could be covered by section 24ID. A lease conferring such rights or a freehold estate could be granted after a compulsory acquisition of native title under section 24MD or under certain indigenous land use agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Schedule 1, item 9, page 49 (after line 15), at the end of section 24GB, add:

TAB.TAB: (a) the primary production activity mentioned in subparagraph (1)(d)(i) or (ii) is forest operations, a horticultural activity or an aquacultural activity; or
(b) the lease mentioned in paragraph (1)(a) is a non-exclusive pastoral lease and the primary production activity mentioned in subparagraph (1)(d)(i) or (ii) is an agricultural activity;
before the future act is done, the person proposing to do the act must:

(c) notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters covered by the non‐exclusive agricultural lease or non‐exclusive pastoral lease that the act, or acts of that class, are to be done in relation to the particular land or waters; and
(d) give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Schedule 1, item 9, page 50 (line 13), after "interests", insert ", but does not extinguish them".
(24) Schedule 1, item 9, page 51 (line 2), omit paragraph (d), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (d) the future act is not:
(i) the grant of a lease; or
(ii) any act that confers a right of exclusive possession over land; and

SPEECH.PARA: (24A) Schedule 1, item 9, page 51 (lines 3 and 4), omit "an activity", substitute "grazing, or an activity consisting of or relating to gaining access to or taking water,".
(24B) Schedule 1, item 9, page 52 (after line 6), at the end of section 24GD, add:

TAB.TAB: Notification

PARA.TAB: (6) Before the act is done, the person proposing to do the act must:

TAB.TAB: (a) notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters that will be affected by the act that the act, or acts of that class, are to be done in relation to the land or waters concerned; and
(b) give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may very well be. I am just trying to make sure we accept all the government amendments.
—If I can help, we are discussing government amendments 19 to 24B.

—I do not know that I need to debate this more; maybe other senators do. Senator Margetts might have some problems, but what I will be suggesting at the appropriate time is that we put a lot of the opposition amendments in one block because they all relate to the regime that we are proposing. Senator Harradine has some amendments to the same areas and Senators Margetts and Woodley have amendments as well. So in terms of process, if we clear the government's amendments out of the way, it might be appropriate to go to the Margetts and Woodley amendments first, then ours and then Senator Harradine's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the connections between the lines of arguments, I was hoping to just ask a few more questions that actually link the various amendments before we go into the specific arguments on the amendments. These follow up the questions I asked Senator Bolkus earlier. It appears that under the ALP's proposals up to 50 per cent—whether it is in relation to the definition of primary production—
—The government has the benchmark of 50 per cent. We have dominant purpose. It's different.

—Vaguely. It really still leaves it fairly wide open. The definition of `dominant purpose' still can mean, for instance, that there is no right to negotiate in relation to planting of some crops. In Western Australia, anybody who knows what some of the major environmental issues are on pastoral and rangelands would understand that the issue of planting crops on rangelands can be a major problem. It can actually affect species and even affect the enjoyment of native title rights because it basically means that things like buffel grass and leucaena become a major environmental issue within the area. That would certainly affect the values within the area for traditional uses and for the plants and animals in the area. I know the government would pretend that environment has nothing to do with the enjoyment of native title rights, but I am sure many indigenous people think differently.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus indicated that they were prepared to put in the words `just terms', but I am wondering what happens to the right to negotiate during this process for substantial changes and the loss of the enjoyment of native title rights on things like areas with quarries, the removal of remnant bushland and so on, which I would think would be contrary to many people's ideas of what is smart these days. Why would Senator Bolkus think that would not warrant a right to negotiate?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is that those sorts of activities, to the extent that they are allowable under the second tier of our third-tier approach, would have to not be formal upgrades. They would have to not change the dominant purpose. They would have to respect indigenous native title areas if, on the basis of our provisions, they need to be taken into account, as do heritage sites. The right to negotiate, as we have made clear in our proposal, will apply only in respect of formal upgrades but not in respect of that diversification which is allowed under tier two. We have to take into account the fact that, quite often, we are talking about those activities which, under some state regimes, are allowed on basic application at the moment.
—Senator Bolkus, do Labor's amendments remove section 24GE? What are the impacts of 24GE?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a great question. We are about to find out the aspect of 24GE. I do not know that we actually do remove 24GE. In amendments Nos 64, 65, 66, 67, 68 and 69, we essentially modify the procedures for grant of rights to third parties on pastoral lease land, and we ensure protection of cultural heritage. That is 24GE.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have a problem with government amendments Nos 19, 20, 21 and 23. Amendment No. 22 goes to an area which our amendment No. 63 attempts to cover, as do 24, 24A and 24B. So can I suggest we put amendments Nos 19, 20, 21 and 23 at this stage?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will follow that course, Senator Bolkus. The question is that government amendments Nos 19, 20, 21 and 23 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that government amendments Nos 22 and 24 to 24B be agreed to.

—I ask that Senator Minchin seek leave to defer those until the appropriate time in the debate. They do relate to opposition amendment R63, which covers a similar area. If our R63 were to get up, we would not be supporting your 22, 24A and 24B. I seek leave to move that they be deferred until the relevant time in the voting process.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no objection, it is so ordered. The question is that schedule 1, item 9, section 24GA stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(222) Schedule 1, page 138 (after line 12), after item 58, insert:

TAB.TAB: Insert:
pastoral activity means:
(a) the pasturing of stock for sustainable commercial use of the land on which they are pastured; or

(b) agricultural or other non‐dominant uses of land that are essential to or inseparable from the activity specified in paragraph (a), including the production of agricultural products for use in stock feeding; or
(c) farmstay tourism activities (but only so long as they are incidental to the dominant use of the land and that dominant use continues to be an activity referred to in paragraph (a)); or

(d) for things done on leased land, an activity that was necessary, reasonably incidental or reasonably ancillary to the use or development of the land or waters for the purposes for which the lease was granted or, for a lease grant ed before 1 January 1994, the lawful purposes of the lease as at that date, even though the lease, when it was granted, did not permit, or prohibited, the doing of the activity;
but does not include mining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have checked this one and I reaffirm that they are identical, unless I have the wrong sheets.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.
Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(51) Schedule 1, item 9, page 47 (line 18) to page 49 (line 15), omit section 24GB, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 24GB Acts permitting pastoral activities on non‐exclusive agricultural or pastoral leases

PARA.TAB: (1) This section applies to a future act if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a non-exclusive agricultural lease (see section 247B) or non-exclusive pastoral lease (see section 248B) was granted on or before 23 December 1996; and
(b) the grant was valid (including because of Division 2 or 2A); and
Note: As at the commencement of this section, grants before 1 January 1994 that were invalid because of native title have been validated by or under Division 2.
(c) the future act permits or requires the carrying on of a pastoral activity (see section 253) while the lease (including as renewed on one or more occasions) is in force.
Farmstay tourism included

PARA.TAB: (2) This section applies to a future act that permits or requires a farmstay tourism activity in the area covered by a lease meeting the requirements of paragraphs (1)(a) and (b) while the lease is in force (including as renewed on one or more occasions).
(3) However, this section does not apply to a future act permitting or requiring farmstay tourism if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the act permits or requires tourism that involves observing activities or cultural works of, or observing places because of their cultural significance to, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) the act permits or requires the construction of buildings or other facilities that:
(i) are not additions or alterations to a homestead used for the purposes of the lease; or
(ii) extend more than 500 metres from such a homestead.
Lease conversions not covered

PARA.TAB: (4) This section does not apply to a future act that converts a lease covered by paragraph (1)(a) into a lease conferring a right of exclusive possession, or into a freehold estate, over any of the land or waters covered by the lease.
(5) This section also applies to a future act if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the act permits or requires the carrying on of an activity that:
(i) is the pasturing of stock for sustainable commercial use of land; and

(ii) is limited in time so that it takes place while the freehold estate, agricultural lease or pastoral lease (including as renewed on one or more occasions) covering the land on which the stock are usually pastured is in force; and
(iii) is to take place in an area adjoining or near the area covered by the freehold estate, agricultural lease or pastoral lease; and
(iv) does not prevent native title holders in relation to the land or waters in the area in which the activity will be carried on from having reasonable access to the area; and

(b) the act is limited so as to permit or require the activity in circumstances of a temporary emergency in which the continued pasturing of the stock on the freehold, agricultural or pastoral lease is not reasonably practicable.
Example: An example of an act covered by this section is the conferral of a right to graze cattle in an area adjoining a pastoral lease in circumstances of flood, bushfire or other act of God.
Validation of act

PARA.TAB: (6) If this section applies to a future act, the act is valid.

TAB.TAB: Non-extinguishment principle

PARA.TAB: (7) The non-extinguishment principle applies to the act.

SPEECH.PARA: (16A) Schedule 1, item 9, page 19 (line 10), omit "primary production", substitute "pastoral activities".

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers that were given earlier by Senator Bolkus indicated that he believed there would be heritage protection for sites. Given the changes or the lack of ability of the Senate to approve any of the National Indigenous Working Group requests for specific heritage protection under this act, can Senator Bolkus still be certain, considering the statements he made during the heritage protection debate, that his proposed amendments will in fact ensure heritage protection when these upgrades take place?

—The importance of our proposals in respect of heritage protection is that you actually get notice at the time the matter is being considered by the permanent granting authority. That notice gives you a capacity to trigger the exercise of rights under existing heritage legislation. That is the important aspect of it. Without that particular right, people would be very much in the dark. The matter could take place and permits could be granted and whatever when it is much too late. A capacity to be able to protect your sites at the appropriate time is something that our notification mechanism provides for.

—Senator Bolkus, I am once again referring to section 24GE—granting rights to third parties, et cetera, on non‐exclusive agricultural or pastoral leases. This is not actually specifically upgrades of existing leases. I think there is a minor change that the ALP have asked for, but there is nothing in here which does actually provide those protections. Why is that acceptable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think those provisions basically go to people who get year‐to‐year permits. The important thing to note there is that it is an ongoing activity in a sense. When it is a new activity then, because of advance notification, claimants would have the capacity to trigger the exercise of available rights under heritage legislation. I do not know that there is much more I can add to that, Senator Margetts. It may not satisfy you.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be moving amendment 8 because that covers another area. I have been convinced not to move that by everybody around the place and, listening to what has been said, I do not think I would have got one vote for that. Senator Minchin said, `I don't know what he ate for lunch but he was for us before lunch and against us after lunch.' I know what I ate after lunch—a heap of craw.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment No. 7 relates to schedule 1, clause 24GB. It is only a minor amendment which implements what is the common law anyhow. It is necessary that pastoralists be guaranteed the right to diversify activities on their leases post‐Wik as they could pre‐Wik. But the diversification regime should not be so loose as to allow the diversification of leases into activities not permitted by the lease. You could say that that is the law anyhow but, in order to have this matter clarified in accordance with what is the common law, I am moving to insert an additional paragraph at the end of 24GB. I move:
(7) Schedule 1, item 9, page 48 (line 11), at the end of subsection (1), add:
; and (e) the future act could lawfully have been performed (with or without authorisation) on the lease prior to 23 December 1996.
Clause 24GB refers to:
Acts permitting primary production on non-exclusive agricultural and pastoral leases
This section applies to a future act—

and it nominates a number of criteria. All I am doing is moving (e) to ensure that the future act could lawfully have been performed with or without permission on the lease prior to 23 December 1996. I think that gives you certainty. I would think that that would be unexceptionable around the chamber.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to opposition amendment 49 et al.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all consequential. Since our substantive amendment was not successful, I do not need to move them now.
—Similarly with 219 and 220?
—That is right.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) not agreed to:
(61) Schedule 1, item 9, page 50 (lines 3 to 8), omit subparagraph (ii), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (ii) if the activity is or involves farmstay tourism, it takes place pursuant to a valid act (including one that is valid because of section 24GB); and
(d) the carrying on of the activity would be valid if it did not affect native title rights and interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now have government amendments Nos 22, and 24 to 24B to be dealt with which were separated from the earlier amendments. The question is that those amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think at this stage we can indicate that we are not opposing the rest of the government amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(57) Schedule 1, item 9, page 49 (line 27), omit "after 23 December 1996 and".
(64) Schedule 1, item 9, page 52 (line 21) after "lease", insert "or a mining lease".
(65) Schedule 1, item 9, page 52 (line 26), omit subparagraph (iii).
(66) Schedule 1, item 9, page 52 (line 27), before "sand", insert "rocks,".
(68) Schedule 1, item 9, page 53 (lines 9 and 10), omit the note.
(357) Schedule 5, item 17, page 339 (lines 8 to 13), omit the item, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 17 Application of Subdivision G and section 44H

PARA.TAB: (1) Subdivision G of Division 3 of Part 2 of the new Act applies to acts done after 23 December 1996 and before the commencement of that Subdivision.
(2) Section 44H of the new Act applies to the grant, issue or creation of a lease, licence, permit or authority at any time, whether before or after the commencement of that section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers I have received to my questions to Senator Bolkus have not left me feeling that there is any real protection. It would be extremely difficult for me to vote for a provision which allows the removal of gravel, timber, rocks, trees and so on on pastoral leases without the right to negotiate, and to allow the reduction or the removal of the enjoyment of native title rights. At the very least, I will abstain here because I do not feel I can vote for this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, could you confirm that amendments 61, 62, R63 and 17 are not being moved? They were consequential.
—That is right.
—We will move to Senator Harradine's amendment R9 on sheet 837.

—Are we working to topics or are we just jumping around? The reason I am asking is that we were asked to vote on opposition amendments 64 to 66 and 68. There are other amendments in that section. If we are going to be jumping around from one topic to another, that is fine as long as we know. Otherwise, we should try to keep to topics, I would have thought.
—The reason for that is that Senator Bolkus moved all of his amendments together. So the opposition amendments have now been dealt with. We are now moving to Senator Harradine's amendments.
—R63 has not been dealt with and that is to the same section as Senator Harradine's revised 9 applies to.
—R63 was withdrawn. It was not moved. Senator Bolkus confirmed that he would not be moving that.
—That was probably the only amendment that actually had some protection in it.
—Senator Bolkus confirmed to me only a few moments ago that he was not moving R63 or 17.
—It was the only amendment that had some protection measures in it and the ALP has withdrawn R63.
—Sorry. I said I confirmed the withdrawal of whatever we had withdrawn earlier as consequential amendments. R63 is, I think, a live one. I do not think it was in the batch that was withdrawn.
—So you want to deal with R63?
—Senator Margetts can move hers first.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 9, section 24GD stand as printed.

—This section deals with the ability to include off‐farm activities. It obviously can have an impact on activities that are related to, for instance, pastoral activities but in fact may impinge on native title rights off the property. I am really not sure why the logic is in support of that, but it would be the Greens (WA) preferred position to oppose that section and not to leave it in the bill. Therefore, I urge support for the removal of section 24GD.

—In line with the proposal I put forward earlier in respect of three tiers, opposition R63 actually rewrites 24GD to provide for future acts which allow diversification of use of non-exclusive pastoral leases provided that the dominant purpose of the lease remains pastoral. This is what I was talking about earlier. Diversification under major regional irrigation schemes is not included. This provision of ours provides native title holders with notification, procedural rights where a government authority proposes to do a future act which permits diversification activities on non-exclusive pastoral leases. This was, as Senator Margetts rightly said, the provision that does provide protection against excesses, against change of dominant purpose, and does provide for process protection for indigenous claimants.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 9, section 24GD stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) not agreed to:
(63) Schedule 1, item 9, page 50 (line 24) to page 52 (line 6), omit section 24GD, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 24GD Acts permitting pastoral lessee to use land for agricultural purposes

PARA.TAB: (1) This section applies to a future act that permits or requires the lessee of a pastoral lease to use the land or waters covered by the lease for agricultural purposes (including the planting and growing of trees, vines or vegetables) or acquacultural purposes or to cut and remove timber or remove rocks if the purpose or effect of the act is that the dominant use of the lease will continue to be the pasturing of stock for sustainable commercial use of the land on which they are pastured.
(2) In deciding whether the dominant use of the lease will be the pasturing of stock for sustainable commercial use of the land on which they are pastured:

TAB.TAB: (a) if the lease was granted before 1 January 1994 and has since been subdivided, or since been the subject of a renewal or regrant that would have the effect of subdividing the lease had it continued—the area of the lease as at 1 January 1994 is to be considered; and

(b) if the lease was granted after that day and the land the subject of the lease was not substantially the subject of a lease or leases on that day—the area of the lease as at the time of the grant is to be considered.

PARA.TAB: (3) This section does not apply to a future act if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the future act takes place under or as part of a scheme for the development of a region involving a significant change of land use over a large area; and
(b) the development involves a more intense use of the land than pastoral activities; and
(c) the scheme includes, but is not limited to, activities that are related to or result from water storage or water reticulation.

Note: The approval for the use of all or part of a pastoral lease for agricultural purposes as part of a major regional development based on a large dam or irrigation system is an example of an act excluded by this subsection.

PARA.TAB: (4) The authority responsible for the act must notify any registered native title body corporate, representative body and registered native title claimants for the areas of land or waters that may be affected by the proposed act of the intention to do the proposed act and of terms of the proposed act.
(5) If the act is not a legislative act, any of the persons notified under subsection (4) may object, within 60 days after receiving the notification, to the doing of the proposed act.
(6) If an objection is made, the authority must consider the propriety of doing the proposed act and the scope of the proposed act in light of the matters raised in the objection.

(7) If, after considering any objections made within the period referred to in subsection (5), the authority intends to proceed with the act (whether as proposed or subject to modifications), the authority must enter into consultations with the persons notified under subsection (4) with a view to:

TAB.TAB: (a) ensuring that any possible impairment of native title rights and interests will be minimised; and
(b) seeking to reach agreement as to the compensation payable for the act.
(a) the authority is required to notify persons about the proposed act under subsection (4); and
(b) there has been no approved determination of native title in relation to the land or waters concerned;
the authority must:
(c) notify in writing any representative body and registered native title claimants for the land or waters concerned of the intention to do the proposed act and of terms of the proposed act; and
(d) place notices, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister for the purposes of this paragraph, on any land concerned, advising that the act is to take place; and
(e) notify the public in the determined way (see section 252) that the act is to take place.

PARA.TAB: (9) The non‐extinguishment principle applies to the act.
(10) The native title holders concerned are entitled to compensation for the act in accordance with Division 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (R9) Schedule 1, item 9, page 51 (line 16), at the end of subsection (1), add:

TAB.TAB: ; and (f) the future act takes place on land which has not been the subject of an approved determination of native title in respect of which the native title rights and interests include a right to exclusive possession of the land.

SPEECH.PARA: The point raised by Senator Margetts, the Labor Party and a number of other people as well has been giving me some concern. I will first of all describe what it does. I have moved a new subclause (f) to 24GD(1). This section applies to a future act if the future act takes place on land which has not been the subject of an approved determination of native title in respect of which the native title rights and interests include a right to exclusive possession of the land.

The government has indicated—I think it may have already done so in what we have just voted for—amending section 24GD to limit off‐farm activities to grazing and access to and taking of water. If a pastoralist wishes to undertake those activities on freehold land, the pastoralist would need the consent of the landowner. The section, as currently worded, is discriminatory if that same pastoralist would not have to obtain the consent of the native title holders.

Native title may encompass a broad range of rights from rights to access through to rights of exclusive possession, as was found to be the case in Mabo and in fact at Crescent Head. Where a native title is the latter kind, that is to say in the exclusive possession kind, it would be particularly discriminatory if pastoralists on adjacent or nearby properties could agist their cattle or sheep without the consent of the native title holders.

This amendment is designed to ensure that native title holders whose native title rights are determined to include a right of exclusive possession are not subject to section 24GD. I am sure that eventually the government would understand the purpose of this. It is carefully worded to apply only to those native title holders who are not claimants for exclusive possession but are determined to have a right of exclusive possession. Under those circumstances, I think everybody would reasonably expect that those holders of that sort of title should be given the same courtesies as freehold land owners.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to Senator Harradine's amendments Nos 11 and 12.

—I am not sure whether these amendments are consequential. I think they may be consequential amendments on 9 being successful. The original 9 was not successful—that is, we did retain 24GD in the legislation on my vote. The reason I voted for that was so I could then amend it. So I do not think amendments 11 and 12 are necessary.
—We now move to amendment No 10, to be moved by Senator Harradine.
—I am not moving that amendment. It relates to the compensation matter to which I referred previously.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 9, section 24GE stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, we have not as yet put opposition amendments 64 to 66.
—They have been dealt with.
—When was that?
—Amendments 64 to 66, 68, 357 and 57 were dealt with together.

—I seek the indulgence of the committee with respect to them. I think we might have said at some stage that they were consequential but, on further examination, they are not. Amendment 64, for instance, is an important provision. We have already discussed the right to negotiate with respect to mining on pastoral leases, and we have taken a substantive decision on that. Provision 64 is in many ways a flow-on from that decision. It means that the future act provisions do not provide to exclude the right to negotiate with respect to mining on pastoral leases. I think it is important in terms of consistency with the decision we took last night that 64 be accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments 65 and 66 have the effect of allowing removal of rocks, for instance, as a future act, but not allowing the establishment of a quarry. I think that is part of the balance that we in this place would like to strike. I seek leave to have amendment 64 recommitted and then amendments 65, 66 and 68 put separately from 64.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to make the point that 24GE already specifically excludes mining in 24GE(1)(e)(iv), where it talks about obtaining and removing sand, soil or other resources except so far as doing so constitutes mining. So we believe we have covered the concern that is addressed by this opposition amendment, and therefore it is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern is also that, for the sake of comprehensiveness, from time to time in this debate we have seen the issuing of a licence or a lease as the act as opposed to the actual act of mining. In order to maintain that consistency, and since Minister Minchin says there is no real major extraneous effect to what he has anticipated already, adding the words `or mining lease' after `lease' in (d) would provide the consistency that is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 64 agreed to.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments Nos 65, 66 and 68 not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I think you regarded amendments 61 and 62 as consequential and you were not going to move them.

—Amendments Nos 61 and 62 relate to the issue of farm stay tourism. We propose that there be a capacity for such. I think there was at some stage an amendment from Senator Harradine in respect of farm stay tourism. We have not seen it in the last day or so, so I presume that it is not going ahead. What we provide in our amendments Nos 61 and 62 is to allow farm stay tourism. In No. 62, we provide compensation for activity undertaken under the lease, not just the granting of the lease. It ensures that individual pastoralists are not liable to pay the compensation. I think No. 62 is consequential to the three-tier regime we put up, which was inappropriate. Having another look at it, I think No. 61 is also consequential. We will not proceed with either of those amendments.
—Senator Margetts, are you going to move your amendment No. 165?
—I was going to check whether the ALP's revised amendment No. 51 was moved. If so, what happened to it?
—I was just going to go to that. Amendment No. 51 was moved and negatived. Senator Harradine's amendment No. 7 was adopted as an alternative.
—I believe that amendment No. 165 is a consequential amendment, so I do not think there is any point in moving it now.
—We now move to sheet No. 21 and opposition amendments Nos 179 and 182.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Sheet No. 21 goes to statutory access rights on pastoral leases. The government proposes a scheme which ensures that, once a native title claim over all or part of an area covered by a non‐exclusive agricultural or pastoral lease is registered and one or more native title claimants regularly have physical access to the land for the purpose of carrying out traditional activities as at 23 December 1996, the bill provides a conditional statutory right of access to those areas while the claim is in progress. The rights of the leaseholder are deemed to prevail over statutory access rights. Additionally, while the statutory right of access applies to any part of the lease, no person can enforce any native title interests or rights in relation to the whole of the land covered by the lease. That is a particularly important provision that needs to be noted.

SPEECH.PARA: The access rights apply where native title holders have not previously been excluded from entry. There is an absurdity in the provision in that it will be unnecessary for claimants who already have access to the land, but it is, in a sense, probably unhelpful for those who do not.

We have some criticisms of the government's position. The provision has been described by the Kimberley Land Council as one of the cruelest hoaxes in the bill. The working group comments in its submissions to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund that the provision of a very limited benefit is likely to be difficult to enforce and precludes the exercise of common law rights of access. If it is of benefit to indigenous people at all, which they claim is doubtful, the benefit is likely to be entirely marginal.

We believe that the registration test is too onerous. It demands physical access. However, throughout history, we know that many Aboriginal people were forcibly removed from their lands as part of government policy. Aboriginal people are, in some instances, denied access to their traditional lands by pastoralists. There is a lot of evidence before the parliamentary committee in respect of that.

Another concern is that if the native title claimants did not enjoy or were refused regular physical access until 23 December 1996, the statutory right of access is not available to them. The question of what constitutes regular physical access is some thing that is not answered. We are concerned that the effect of the statutory right would be to suspend over the whole of the lease area a capacity to claim, even if one individual claimant is entitled to statutory access rights under the subdivision.

Another concern is that, if a determination of native title is made, no compensation is payable for the suspension of the native title rights in this respect. So, once again, we have the all-pervading questions of constitutionality and discrimination. We believe that the suspension of rights in this way would constitute an acquisition of property, giving rise to just terms claims.

There is also a particular irony arising out of this in that, for the conditional statutory right of access to apply, there needs to be a native title claim lodged. This would be a matter concerning pastoralists. In effect, Aboriginal people who have access and have had continuing access are now being encouraged to lodge a native title application to gain a statutory right of access, which is a right they have exercised for some time. It is a provision that will ensure that a whole range of claims will be lodged in order that people can protect their current position. In lodging those claims, we will be scaring the life out of people who are coexisting quite well at the moment. So we have some amendments, and we look forward to moving them at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to remember what the Wik decision was. It was that pastoral leases in Queensland do not necessarily extinguish all native title. There was no finding that the Wik people hold native title; it was simply the removal of the previously considered block to the claim. That is, as a pastoral lease had been issued over the land, the Wik people now have to seek a determination that they have maintained their traditional connection to the land. That has to be heard through the judicial process. Some people seem to think that Wik decided that all Aboriginal people automatically have access over all pastoral leases across Australia. That is not what was decided in the Wik case. It provided that people can seek a determination that they hold native title in respect of particular pastoral leases.

SPEECH.PARA: I come from a state where all Aboriginal people have had statutory access rights on pastoral leases virtually since the inception of the concept of pastoral leases. In South Australia we are very proud that our pastoral leases have that statutory access right provided. It is set down in the statute, it is part of the lease, and it describes those rights, who is able to exercise them and under what conditions. We are dealing with a different concept here.

Having made the policy decision that it would not extinguish native title on pastoral leases, in this positive policy proposition the government wanted to ensure the preservation of access being exercised as at the date of the Wik decision. We genuinely wished to respond to any move by anyone on a pastoral lease to move against those who may have been exercising access rights—whether under a statutory right, as we have, or informal access arrangements—when the Wik decision was handed down.

Obviously, some pastoral lessees—and I do not know of any, but it is possible—may have reacted with fear to the decision and sought to go back to a position where no access was granted in order that any subsequent native title claim may not succeed. This was a positive move by the government to confirm and guarantee existing access arrangements as at the time of the Wik decision and to prevent that sort of removal or denial of access that had been exercised as at the date of the Wik decision. We think this is one of the positive elements of the bill.

The statutory access rights that exist in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and South Australia continue, and in many respects they are very wide access rights. There have not been access rights in some other jurisdictions as of right, but there have been casual and informal arrangements where pastoralists, by and large, have no difficulty whatsoever with Aboriginal people being on the lease. We wanted to preserve and protect that and make sure that those access rights could continue to be exercised.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to see where the government is coming from on this. From our point of view, the policy proposition involved is not something that was an automatic consequence of the Wik decision. Wik did not decide that this should be the case. We see it as a very positive element in the bill and one that makes a lot of sense. It does not impose something on pastoralists by statute, except that they are not able to deny access where it was being exercised on 23 December 1996.

The question of what native title rights as such may be on the lease is a matter for the courts to determine in respect of claims. We hope that, through our agreements mechanisms, agreements can be reached without necessarily going to court over access. That would obviously be a much better approach. There has been a very significant move by the Liberal government in South Australia to put in place these sorts of comprehensive agreements over access on pastoral leases to cover things like gates, guns, driving, fires and so on so that there is effective, practical and manageable coexistence on pastoral leases. We applaud that.

It is important to note why we put this in, and the way it is to operate. It is an interim statutory access right, pending the outcome of the native title claim and what rights are determined as a consequence of the native title claim; so it is a right for those Aboriginal people with access to the land who have a native title claim registered to guarantee that interim statutory access right, pending the outcome of their native title claim. Their native title claim may result in their being granted rights greater than the access rights they were exercising, or it may find that they do not have native title to the pastoral lease.

It has been suggested that this should be made much wider than it is. That is not consistent with our policy. It is important to remember what the indigenous land fund was about. That land fund was a recognition of dispossession. That is the parliament's mechanism by which dispossession of Aboriginal people in the past has been acknowledged and recognised. It is one that we support. I remind you that, as the previous government did, we are continuing to put $120 million a year into that fund, so that by the year 2004 it will have a capital sum of $1.3 billion, which will enable Aboriginal people to buy $45 million worth of land every year forever.

That is a considerable sum of money, which is available every year for Aboriginal people to buy land. Indeed, I am advised that the total value of all pastoral leases on Cape York is currently around $50 million, so this land fund would enable every pastoral lease to be bought on Cape York in one year. Those who have suffered dispossession have the enormous benefit of that indigenous land fund in recognition of that and to enable Aboriginal people to buy traditional lands, whether they be under current pastoral lease, freehold or whatever. It is important to remember that in the context of this access rights provision.

We are talking about access on land currently leased by Australian farming families where there is access in place at the time of the Wik decision—it is important to recognise that—but we do not think it is justified to go further, particularly in the light of the policy decisions made earlier, which we support, in relation to the indigenous land fund, and in recognition of the fact that all the mechanisms are there for native title claims, which obviously would involve access rights, to be pursued, and judicial determinations made as to whether the native title has been made out.

We have only one amendment: amendment No. 43 relates to affirming that indigenous land use agreements can deal generally with access issues and that persons may seek the assistance of the Native Title Tribunal in negotiating such an agreement. Obviously, to make access work practically on the ground, agreements are going to be needed as to how access rights are to be exercised consistent with the operation of the pastoral business. I move:
(43) Schedule 1, item 9, page 116 (after line 31), at the end of section 44F, add:

PARA.TAB: Note: Persons wishing to make an indigenous land use agreement about access in general may request assistance from the NNTT or a recognised State/Territory body in negotiating the agreement: see sections 24BF, 24CF and 24DG.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (179) Schedule 1, item 9, page 113 (lines 14 to 25), omit subsection (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) There must be an area (a traditional access area ) of land or waters that, at the commencement of this section, was not subject to:

TAB.TAB: (a) a grant of freehold title other than to the Crown, or to a statutory of the Crown, in any capacity; or

(b) a residential lease, commercial lease, exclusive agricultural lease or any other form of lease (except a pastoral lease or mining lease) conferring a right of exclusive possession over the land or waters concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: (182) Schedule 1, item 9, page 115 (line 6), omit "the person included in the native title claim group", substitute "a person referred to in subsection 44A(3)".

These amendments remove the significance of the date 23 December 1996 in assessing previous access and the need for regular access, and provide a right of access to any person entitled or obliged under law and custom if such person is alive at that date. They also remove the requirement of a person exercising an access right having to be part of a native title group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by Senator Bolkus are precisely the same as the Greens-Democrats amendments. For the record, the only amendments on this sheet which have some differences are amendments Nos 181 and 149, but it is a marginal difference so we are voting in accord with the opposition on the amendments on this sheet.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (180) Schedule 1, item 9, page 113 (line 27) to page 114 (line 5), omit subsection (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) There must be a person who:

TAB.TAB: (a) is included in the native title claim group (see section 253) in relation to a claim for which there is an entry on the Register of Native Title Claims; or

(b) at the commencement of this section, or at a time during his or her lifetime, had physical access to the whole or a part of a traditional access area for the purpose of carrying on one or more traditional activities (see subsection (4)) of the person.

PARA.TAB: (3A) This Subdivision applies to:

TAB.TAB: (a) that person; and
(b) any other person holding rights and obligations under traditional law and custom in relation to that traditional access area or that part of it; and

(c) a person who is a descendant of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) and who is recognised by traditional law and custom as being entitled or obliged to carry on one or more traditional activities on that traditional access area or that part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment removes a requirement that a claim must be lodged before a state right of access is available.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (181) Schedule 1, item 9, page 114 (lines 15 to 24), omit subsection (1), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) At all times while this Subdivision applies, a person referred to in subsection 44A(3A) has a right to enter, travel across or stay on the traditional access area for the purpose of following traditional activities of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders.
(1A) However, subsection (1) doe s not permit a person included in the native title claim group to camp:

TAB.TAB: (a) within a radius of one kilometre of any house in the traditional access area; or
(b) within a radius of 500 metres of a dam, other constructed stock watering point (not being a site of significance) or a shed or outbuilding used for pastoral purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment removes what we think are unreasonable restrictions on the exercise of access rights. Senator Minchin referred earlier to the South Australian provisions. Here we are trying to replace this government's provisions with the provisions based on the access rights specified in section 48 of the South Australian Pastoral Land Management and Conservation Act. There is some protection there to all parties involved. It is an act which Senator Minchin says works well and we think that provision should be applied here.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (55) Schedule 1, item 9, page 114 (after line 5), after subsection (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) For the purposes of paragraph (3)(a), physical access to land is deemed to have been regular up to 23 December 1996 if the person, being a member of the native title claim group as at 23 December 1996, has not had regular physical access to the land by reason of an act of government or the person's having been denied physical access to the land by the lessee or someone acting on behalf of the lessee.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to physical access to the land. It is, I suppose, the locked gate amendment. Honourable senators will notice that this amendment is in a different form to the amendment that was on the sheet originally. The original amendment read:

(3A) For the purposes of paragraph (3)(a), physical access to land is deemed to have been regular up to 23 December 1996 if a government or the grantee of any interest in the land has denied members of the native title claim group physical access to the land.

Somebody pointed out to me that that might be the Bennelong amendment in that you would have trouble working it out over a period of time. But this amendment is drafted in a form so that it deals with a person, being a member of the native title claim group as at 23 December 1996, not having had regular physical access to the land by reason of that act.

This is also the stolen generation amendment because I thought that, for example, Lois O'Donoghue may under the legislation as it exists at the present moment not be entitled to access an area of land which would be her native title claim group area. I believe something like this needs to go in the bill. I commend my amendment to the government and to other honourable senators. I believe it has not got aspects of the Bennelong argument because it is confined to the person who at 23 December 1996 was in that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit concerned about the use of the term `regular physical access'. Although it is talking about a person who has been denied regular physical access, is the other side of the coin in your reading of this, Senator Harradine, that, to gain these rights a person would have to have had regular physical access other than if they had been denied it by the lessee or someone on behalf of the lessee?

—This is an amendment to the government's proposition. I do not know whether the minister heard Senator Margetts's statement, but I think she asked whether a precondition was that the persons would have to have had regular physical access to the land, in any event, to be entitled to access rights. What does `regular' mean?
—I think the Senate is entitled to an answer to that. What does the government mean by regular physical access in relation to whether or not a person can have access rights?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —You take it on its face value. Regular physical access will vary from circumstance to circumstance, but the point is that it is a prima facie legal right. If there is an assertion that regular physical access occurs, then they have that right. It is for someone who wishes to deny it to substantiate that it is not regular physical access. What we are trying to do is regularise and formalise and put into statutory form the right to regular physical access if that was the situation as at 23 December 1996. It does not mean that they were constantly there nor does it mean that they were there once a year.

SPEECH.PARA: What it will mean will depend on the circumstances. It is to formalise the legal practice at the time. As of right, that access is legally enforceable under these provisions if you are a registered native title claimant. It would be for others to seek to prevent it being exercised if there was a view that it was regular. The onus would be on those who sought to prevent it occurring. It has been kept reasonably loose to embrace and ensure that all those with some access to property as at that date would have it confirmed by the statute.

TALK.START.PARA: —The term worries me significantly because I see the image of somebody in society who at one time in their life might be christened or baptised, at another time might take other rights of passage and at another time in their life get married. They might or might not choose to go to the same place. Traditional owners may well have sites where they might go only once or twice in their lives because it is a special site—it could be a site for initiation ceremonies or a site for special women's business. It could be a site which is not regularly visited because of its very nature. It might not be regularly visited by everybody or only visited by people over a certain age. If a young person had not got to that age, you could say that they had not had regular physical access. I am worried about the whole issue of regular access and why we do not actually say physical access. I am worried why the word `regular' is there and what it says or does not say about our understanding of indigenous culture.

—I think there may be a misunderstanding. This is only an interim measure. It is only expressing in legislative form what is the common law right. It has nothing to do with what might happen in the future. This is only between the registration of the claim and its determination. It is in determination that the matters that Senator Margetts is talking about will be finalised. This is only an interim measure.
—I am advised that the determination may take years, even with these processes to speed things up. We might be looking at six years or so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly true that one of the problems with the whole native title process is the delays in courts unless agreements can be reached. We hope our agreements process will short circuit that and agreements for this sort of access can be reached. In that event, may be the claim itself may not need to be pursued.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Harradine said, the government is positively moving to guarantee for those who regularly had physical access and are claimants that they have the right, specified in 44B(1), which states:

. . . to have access, in the same way and to the same extent . . . to the traditional access for the purpose of carrying on the one or more traditional activities in that area in the same way and to the same extent as they were carried on pursuant to the access mentioned in that subsection . . .

That is, their regular physical access. They can have that, as a matter of right under this act, for however long it takes to make a determination of their native title. I would hope that increasingly there will be cooperative voluntary agreements entered into which may well be such that determinations need not be pursued. If satisfactory access agreements are worked out between the parties it would not necessitate pursuing a determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it sufficient that a person makes a statement that they have had regular access? You mentioned that it is up to someone else to prove that they have not. How would you prove that a person has or has not had regular access? Traditional owners from Western Australia have told me that they go quietly on to land, do not make a fuss about it and in most cases the owners do not even know they are there. How would someone be able to prove or disprove that somebody has had regular access to a particular area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have to prove to anyone in the first instance. If they are accessing land, then they have that right prima facie and it would be for another party—
—So how would someone disprove that?

—That is the point. The onus would be on the other to prove that they did not have regular physical access. If they are exercising their rights without anybody knowing, nothing will change. My point is that it would be for those who assert that these access rights are being exercised invalidly under the act to seek to have their position proved. They would have to prove that the claimants did not regularly have physical access as at that date. It is a reversal of onus from your point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will oppose schedule 1, item 9, page 115 (lines 20 to 29), section 44C. We want to remove the suspension of the common law native title rights if interim statutory access rights are pursued. I think I explained this earlier. It is a fairly important amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Schedule 1, item 9, section 44C stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that completes the running sheet, apart from amendment 836 which has been circulated. It is a further amendment to be moved by the Democrats. It adds some words after schedule 1, item 49 page 133, after line 9 at the end of section 249C. I will very briefly speak to it, if I may. I think you need an explanation. It will be quick.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is to avoid any uncertainty about the confirmation of exclusive possession and to close off any prospective loophole that would allow state and territory governments to amend—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, we might put this to one side for a moment and go back to some miscellaneous amendments. As I understand it, they are the ones that were postponed before and we want to try and keep some order in the way we deal with these things.
—Could I have 44C recommitted? This was a matter about which I had concerns and I had overlooked that in the heat of the moment.
—You would like that recommitted?
—I would, with your permission.
—I will put that question again. Senator Harradine has requested that the question that schedule 1, item 9, section 44C stand as printed be put again.
—I thought the government was going to put an amendment to that, but they apparently have not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do believe that section 44C should stand as printed. It is about reinforcing our view about accessing the native title act claim process. It is our view that it is unreasonable to allow native title claim groups to stand back from the Native Title Act processes once they have been triggered by a native title determination application by another native title claim group.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfair to expect parties to a native title determination application under the act—and that includes applicants and respondents—to also be parties to common law native title claims over the land claimed under the Native Title Act.

In our view, it is sensible that a court should determine all the native title rights in relation to an area of land, not just one group's rights seriatim. I know it has been misinterpreted, but it is about ensuring that native title claims are registered and dealt with under the Native Title Act and are brought in under the auspices of the Native Title Act, so that the pastoralist, who in many cases will be a respondent to claims, knows what claims are being made, by whom, when and how and that they are all dealt with in the one proceeding.

Those registered claimants who have been exercising regularly physical access can do so under this act, regardless of the number of claimants, but it may not be all registered claimants who are in that position. But it does seem important to bring under the one umbrella all claimants and have them dealt with in that way, and that common law native title rights per se are exercisable. Once a determi nation is made, the statutory right is exercisable by those who pass this section 44 test, that is, they regularly had physical access as at 23 December 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak at length on this, other than to say that what Senator Minchin wants to do is different to the effect of the act. As a consequence of the effect of the amendment as proposed, people's common law native title rights will be suspended. I do not think we should endorse that unintended consequence at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now move to sheet 844, the amendment from Senator Harradine. It relates to schedule 2, item 63, section 190B to insert the following words after (6):

INTERJECT.PARA: (6A) The Registrar must consider that, prima facie, the assertion referred to in subsection (6) can be made out.
It relates also to topic 18, registration test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2, item 63, section 190B (as amended), after subsection (6), insert:

PARA.TAB: (6A) The Registrar must consider that, prima facie, the assertion referred to in subsection (6) can be made out.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is necessary, otherwise you have a situation where you get a mere assertion, and that is really untenable. I think it would have been unintended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most disappointing decisions by this committee was the significant watering down of the registration test proposed by the government. I thought there was general agreement across the country that one of the most important things to do to improve the workability of the Native Title Act was to put in place a strengthened registration test. It is in the interests of genuine, bona fide native title claimants that that be the case in relation to the effective operation of the right to negotiate to ensure that the negotiations involve bona fide, genuine claimants who have the most prospect of being able to make out their claim.

SPEECH.PARA: You only have to look at the Waanyi case in relation to Century to see the wisdom of that. Indeed, the Waanyi people strongly supported a stronger test and, regrettably, the test passed by this committee has no rigour whatsoever and would not solve those problems. It took out both the prima facie test and the minimal physical connection test. To just require an assertion, of course, is no test at all. Anyone can assert anything they like. The test passed by this committee had no test of that assertion at all. So while this amendment does not restore the test to anything like the degree we believe is a bare minimum, it is a lot better than the current situation. In that sense, the government would support this addition.
Amendment agreed to.
Amendment No. 267, as amended by Senator Harradine's amendment, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now intend to go back to the additional revised sheets so we can go through the postponed amendments. We will begin with additional revised sheet No. 9 relating to item 21, miscellaneous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —These are Greens‐Democrat amendments which the opposition supports. They ensures that for the equivalent state or territory bodies there will be review rights equivalent to those pertaining under the AD(JR). We think it is important for consistency and for justice.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:
(1) Schedule 2, item 71, page 201 (after line 9), after paragraph (b), insert:

TAB.TAB: (ba) the law of the State or Territory will provide for judicial review of decisions of the one or more equivalent bodies (including the provision of a statement of reasons for the decision and procedures for, and grounds of, review) equivalent to those available under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 ; and

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 2, item 71, page 201 (after line 33), after paragraph (f), insert:

TAB.TAB: (fa) members of the equivalent bodies will only be appointed by the Governor or Administrator, as the case may be, and will enjoy no less security of tenure and independence from government than are provided to members of the NNTT under this Act; and

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now move to government amendment 49R on sheet BK215, on additional revised running sheet No. 9, item 21, miscellaneous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (49) Schedule 1, page 125 (line 4), omit "subparagraph 24GE(1)(f)(i)", substitute "paragraph 23HA(a), 24GB(9)(c) or 24GD(6)(a), subparagraph 24GE(1)(f)(i), paragraph 24HA(7)(a), 24ID(3)(a) or 24JB(6)(a)".

I am not sure why these were deferred. They are consequential amendments resulting from the notification amendments which were earlier accepted. They are very technical amendments which are consequential on amendments already agreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember this. This is one that we tried to point out. This was because of the way the amendments were running and bits of the bill did not make sense any more—not that the bill ever did make sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Schedule 1, item 9, page 55 (after line 6), at the end of section 24HA, add:

PARA.TAB: (7) Before an act covered by subsection (2) is done, the person proposing to do the act must:

TAB.TAB: (a) notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters that will be affected by the act, or acts of that class, that the act, or acts of that class, are to be done; and
(b) give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment proposes section 24HA, which provides among other things that a future act is valid if it consists of the grant of a valid lease, licence, permit or authority under legislation in relation to the management and regulation of water. The amendment inserts a new subsection 7 that applies to the grant. In relation to future acts of this kind, new subsection 7 requires that before the future act is done the person proposing to do the act notify in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth minister the persons mentioned in paragraph 7(a) that the act or acts of that class are to be done and give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts. So I would have thought that was an amendment acceptable to the chamber.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 9, subdivision H, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We have now returned to the sections dealing with the regulation and management of water. I would like to put some words on the record in some detail in relation to this issue because it is one of the issues which is, I know, causing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people considerable stress.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens and Democrats have proposed amendments to establish a regime for a full and proper process of consultation with indigenous Australians over the management and regulation of water. The indications are that Senator Harradine so far has not supported any of the amendments put forward by the Greens and Democrats in relation to these issues, but I would ask him to at least consider supporting, at the very least, the ALP amendment which maintains the status quo.

Mabo No. 2 left open a number of major legal issues, including whether traditional rights and interests regarding onshore waters and areas of sea and seabed may be recog nised as native title under common law. The present Native Title Act 1993 leaves these issues to the courts. The Croker seas and Yorta Yorta cases, which are presently before the Federal Court, are expected to clarify the law.

Indigenous fishing rights have been recognised to both onshore and offshore waters in overseas jurisdictions including Canada, the United States and New Zealand. This has included the right to take fish for subsistence purposes and, in some cases, the right to trade or operate commercial fishing ventures. In 1905, the United States Supreme Court held that the Indian tribes were `not much less dependent upon fishing than the air they breathed'. That was the United States v. Winans 198 US 371 of 1905. Over time, this right has developed from a mere access right to a right to avoid licence fees and to include a harvest share.
