In Canada, the Supreme Court has expanded indigenous fishing rights beyond subsistence needs to include ceremonial use and a broader use of fish than mere day-to-day domestic consumption.

Recognition of these rights has enabled indigenous people to negotiate with governments and commercial interests to ensure that they are a stakeholder in the process. This is also ensuring that commercial fishing quotas do not detract from subsistence fishing, that proper mechanisms are in place to protect certain species and that pollution and overfishing are prevented. In some cases, indigenous people have negotiated a significant involvement in the fishing industry such as a share of the harvest of certain species.

At common law, ownership of water as such has never been an issue. It has been regarded as a resource belonging to no-one and, therefore, accessible by anyone. The Crown has long sought to regulate and manage waters to exercise full dominion over water in rivers and lakes and to undertake generally, the conservation and distribution of water. For the attainment of that object, it was not necessary to destroy anybody's rights, but it was necessary to give to the Crown, or some statutory authority, overriding rights to which private rights must, if the need arises, give way.

BREAK.PARA: The amendments that the government proposes permit effective extinguishment of native title to onshore and offshore waters by ensuring that the grant of future commercial and other interests regarding the use of waters or water resources always take precedence. The precise mechanisms whereby this outcome is achieved are contained in schedule 1, division 3, subdivision H. The proposed government amendments remove from indigenous native title holders all authority to deal with natural resources in these areas. They confer that authority on government.

There is no duty imposed on government to take account of the interests of native title property holders in exercising its regulation and management function, an appropriate process of consultation giving sufficient time for full consideration of all issues, particularly the effect on native title rights and interests regarding any relevant legislation which should be required. This should acknowledge the legitimate interests of native title holders as stakeholders in the process. Also, an appropriate mechanism is required to reconcile native title rights and interests and other rights and obligations. A bare statement that the latter prevailed to the extent of any inconsistency is not appropriate. Some kind of right to negotiate is required.

I would like to indicate that I have taken quotes from the National Indigenous Working Group's submission to the Joint Committee on Native Title because it is vital, and has been considered to be vital, to put some of these issues on the record. They have said that any act which constitutes the management or regulation of water or airspace, again, if inconsistent with native title rights and interests, will be valid pursuant to subdivision H. There is an entitlement to compensation but no obligation to compulsorily acquire native title interests and hence no obligation to negotiate. This particular restriction is applicable to both onshore and offshore waters. Again and again, the message that is given to me is that the most important issue here is the right to negotiate.

I would like to address some of the points made by Senator Minchin in this place on Tuesday, 2 December in relation to the future act regime applying to waters. Under the current act, any grant of new rights is subject to the threshold element of the future act regime by which native title holders must be accorded the same procedural rights as they would if they possessed ordinary title.

In the case of waters, all existing rights of the Crown and any existing fishing access rights may be confirmed by the Commonwealth, state or territory. Any grant of new rights is subject to the right to negotiate. The proposed amendments are a significant impairment of existing rights. They will enable effective extinguishment of native title in waters, and they are likely to be in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act because new grants to water or water resources will simply be valid and not attract the right to negotiate.

Native title holders will only be allowed the most minimal procedural requirement available to them before governments take action which may permanently deprive them of their rights to fish or use waters or to prevent desecration of sacred sites in, for example, wetlands, water holes or rivers. Senator Minchin has stated:
To the extent that there is any mining or compulsory acquisition involving water, then that would continue.

This is incorrect in relation to waters. Under the proposed amendments to the future acts regime, governments can make laws to manage or regulate waters. They will also be able to grant interests, such as leases and licences, over waters. The non-extinguishment principle will apply, and compensation will be payable to native title holders for any impact on native title. But the proposed amendments will deny native title holders the right to negotiate and provide only the most minimal procedural requirement available to them before governments take action which may permanently deprive them of their rights to fish or use waters or to prevent desecration of sacred sites in, for example, wetlands, water holes and rivers. Senator Harradine has written in his explanatory memorandum the following:

The right to negotiate is intended to protect native title wherever it exists. As the National Indigenous Working Group rightly points out, the recognition of native title is meaningless without some mecha nism to protect it against arbitrary impairment or destruction.

Senator Harradine is right. We await the outcome of the Yorta Yorta claim to determine if, in that instance, native title exists in those waters subject to the claim. The government amendments seek to remove an important protection for native title before it is known if native title has survived. They must be rejected. I urge Senator Harradine, as he was unable to support the Greens-Democrat amendment, to at least support the ALP amendment in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. We are trying to put in place here a future act regime for one of our governments' most important responsibilities—that is, the management of water on all of our behalf. It is important to remember that the statutory right to negotiate per se does only apply in relation to mining and compulsory acquisitions for third parties. That will continue under these provisions in respect of water to the extent that there is mining on water, which I am not aware of, or compulsory acquisitions, which again I am not aware of. Where those activities are proposed, then as is the case now the statutory right to negotiate would operate, but there is no statutory right to negotiate now in respect of other activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is the doubt as to whether future management rights and management activity can be validly done because the current provisions of the act only talk about existing rights and really do not set in place a regime for management into the future, except that you have the freehold test. That means it can only be done if it can be done on freehold, and that is not a relevant test in many respects in relation to these sorts of activities.

Governments are involved in huge numbers of transactions involving water in Australia. It is one of their primary responsibilities on our behalf. I do not know whether what is being contemplated is a statutory right to negotiate in relation to anything that happens on water but that is an absolutely unworkable proposition, given the thousands of licenses, renewals, et cetera, that are issued across the country involving water.

We have put in place in amendment 25 a notification and regime and an opportunity to comment. We are providing that the non-extinguishment principle applies. We are not talking about extinguishing native title rights. Native title rights can be pursued in court and determined. Nothing in these provisions affects that. All it does is effectively put in place the Wik decision—that native title can, if the court so finds, exist in and on water but, as in Wik, subject to statutory rights granted by our governments in managing water on our behalf. To the extent that those statutory rights—which may well be granted to Aboriginal people—affect native title, then compensation is payable. We think this is one of the essential elements of this package to guarantee the capacity to manage water on our behalf into the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that anything the Senate has said about people's feelings, people's rights and people's basic humanities has sunk into the minister at all in relation to this debate. We heard the double speak. We heard him say that they can establish their rights in court. It means that with a slash of the pen legislatively he intends to remove native title rights, and basically people will be left to the mercy, if they can manage it, to try to fight for any extant rights in court. This is just so basic to Aboriginal cultural and spiritual life in Australia. How can you do that?

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 9, subdivision H, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, I just want to clarify something from when you were speaking before. I think I understood you to say that the Democrat‐Greens amendments 16 and 19 were giving way to opposition amendment 18. Is that correct? We have opposition amendment 18 and Democrats amendments 16 and 19 and it is probably not necessary to proceed with the Democrats amendments now. Senator Bolkus, can you assist?
—Opposition amendment No. 18 obviously relates to the same issue of water.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I believe the statement you made was correct. I am sorry, but we are changing sheets at such a fast rate, it is difficult at this stage to be entirely on top of things. However, I believe the statement you made was correct: that the Greens-Democrats amendment was subsumed into the ALP's amendments. We would prefer our amendment, but we will the ALP's amendment.

—What we intend to do next is go to revised sheet No. 13, item 15, which deals with compensation. After that, we will go to additional revised sheet No. 16, item 13, which deals with the right to negotiate.
—Opposition amendment No. 70 was the critical amendment here, and opposition amendment No. 18 goes with amendment No. 70.
—We have had this discussion.

—We had the discussion yesterday. I will move opposition amendments Nos 18 and 70. The amendment basically removes your proposed subdivision H and reinstates the current provisions in the Native Title Act to ensure that management regimes stay in place, as are now required.
—So, Senator Bolkus, you have moved opposition amendment No. 18?
—I have moved amendments Nos 70 and 18. Amendment No. 18 is more consequential to 70. I do not know why it is not on the list.
—No, it is on the list, but I thought we had dealt with 70, because the question was that schedule 1, item 9, subdivision H as amended be agreed to.
—So then 18 is consequential?
—So amendment No. 70 is done, and 18 is consequential. So are you moving amendment No. 18?
—I do not think we need to move it.
—We will now move to revised sheet No. 13, item 15, which deals with compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments Nos 224 and 254 read:

SPEECH.PARA: (224) Schedule 2, item 6, page 140 (lines 21 to 28), omit the item, substitute:

TAB.TAB: Omit the subsection, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) If an application is made to the Federal Court for a determination of compensation, the Court must, if there is no approved determination of native title in relation to the land or waters concerned:

TAB.TAB: (a) make a direction under section 53A; or
(b) assess compensation and direct that it be held in trust under section 56, or
(c) make a determination of native title as at the date on which the act giving rise to the claim took place.

SPEECH.PARA: (254) Schedule 2, page 174 (after line 20), after item 20, insert:

PARA.TAB: Add at the end:
(2) In determining an application for compensation, the Federal Court must order the Government party to pay all of the applicant's legal costs and disbursements if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the claim is successful in whole or part; or
(b) if the claim is not successful—the Court is satisfied that the prosecution of the claim was reasonable.

PARA.TAB: (3) If an award of compensation is made by the Federal Court under the procedures provided in this section, and there is no approved determination of native title at the time the compensation is payable:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Court may order that the compensation be paid to the representative body for the land or waters concerned to be held by it in trust for those claimants who are entitled to the compensation, and
(b) if there is a dispute between claimants as to the entitlement of any person to share in the compensation, the representative body must attempt to resolve the dispute; and
(c) if such attempts at dispute resolution are unsuccessful, the representative body may refer the matter to the Tribunal for arbitration.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments deal with the power of the Federal Court to deal with compensation when there is no determination of native title. Amendment No. 254 requires the government party to pay all the native title party costs if the application is successful in whole or in part or was otherwise reasonable. We spoke about this last night. Senator Harradine wanted a bit more time to think about it.
Amendment No. 224 not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now move to additional revised sheet 16, item 13, the right to negotiate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Schedule 1, item 9, page 84 (after line 3), after paragraph 26D(2)(a), insert:

TAB.TAB: (aa) the earlier act took place after the commencement of this Act; and

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is an unexceptionable amendment. Amendment No. 25 is a new (aa), which refers to the earlier act. After line 3, on page 84, we are talking about excluded mining acts, earlier valid acts. I wanted 26D(2) to read:
This Subdivision does not apply to an act (the later act) consisting of the creation of a right to mine if:—
and then there are a number of `ifs' listed—
(aa) the earlier act took place after the commencement of this Act . . .
That is, the new act, not the Native Title Act as such. I understood that that was acceptable. I am sorry that I do not have further advice on that.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to amendment 100, Senator Margetts, could you clarify whether that was postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I was originally going to move it. I asked for it to be deferred because I realised it was an introductory amendment. It would have been absolutely wonderful if what we had applied to it also applies to these future acts:

TAB.TAB: (a) an act to the extent that it relates to an offshore place; and
(b) an act to which section 24HB applies (which deals with leases, licences etc. relating to water and airspace).

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has gutted any chance that those things could be in those provisions. I am very sad to say there is no point in moving an introduction which does not apply to what is now left in the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to opposition amendment 142.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —This is consequential. Last night we accepted 124 which omitted 26D(1) which removed the right to negotiate in respect of mining in relation to renewal, re‐grant or remaking. We did that. As the legislation now stands, there would be an inconsistency because subdivision I has the effect of validating such acts and excluding them from the right to negotiate. So we need a consequential amendment to bring subdivision I in line with amendment 124 which we adopted last night.
—I thought we were dealing with 142.
—Yes, we are.

—Right. I will not speak again in respect of 124 when we get to it. Amendment 142 is the result of the fact that last night—I think the clerks were right—we amended a clause which, by the time we got around to amending it, we had actually deleted. What we are suggesting here is that, in order to get the that outcome we got last night, I seek leave for the question in respect of schedule 1, item nine, sections 36A, 36B and 36C to be reconsidered. They were the sections that were actually deleted.

SPEECH.PARA: Once that is put, if it is carried, we will agree with 36A and 36C standing as printed and then we would move 142 to amend 36A and 36C to ensure that the notification period before ministerial intervention at this early stage would be accepted. I think the government finds the course of action I am proposing is acceptable to them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 9, sections 36A, 36B and 36C stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to move the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: (142) Schedule 1, item 9 at the end of section 36, add:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Commonwealth Minister may give notice as to urgency

PARA.TAB: (4) At any time after the end of the period applicable under subsection (1) in respect of an application under section 35 that has not been withdrawn, and before either:

TAB.TAB: (a) the negotiation parties have made an agreement of the kind mentioned in paragraph 31(1)(b); or
(b) the arbitral body has made a determination under section 38;

the Commonwealth Minister may give a written notice to the arbitral body requesting the arbitral body to make such a determination within the period specified in the notice. The period must end not earlier than 30 days after the day on which the notice was given.

SPEECH.PARA: (143) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 14), omit "Relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(144) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (lines 21 and 22), omit paragraph (c).
(145) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 24), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(146) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 27), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(147) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 28), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(148) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (lines 1 to 13), omit paragraphs (2)(b) and (c) and subsection (3), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (b) it is in the national interest to make the determination at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: (149) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 14), omit "34A or".
(150) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 15), omit "34A or".
(151) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 16), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(152) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (lines 20 to 22), omit paragraph (a).
(153) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 24), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(154) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 2), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(155) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 22), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(156) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 27), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(157) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 29), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(158) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 31), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(159) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 13), omit "34A and".
(160) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 17), omit "34A or".
(161) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 21), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(162) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 30), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(163) Schedule 1, item 9, page 100 (line 2), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(164) Schedule 1, item 9, page 100 (line 20), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(165) Schedule 1, item 9, page 100 (line 28) to page 101 (line 5), omit subsection (7), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (7) The Commonwealth Minister must, as soon as practicable after making a determination, and in any case within 15 sitting days, cause a copy of the determination, together with reasons for the determination, to be laid before each House of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I be reminded of the content of those.

—What we have done is to impose a regime where, before ministerial intervention, there needs to be a notification period of 30 days and so on. I think you found that a much more acceptable course to have in the legislation than a total prohibition.
—Senator Bolkus, I do not know that they have been circulated. We do not have a copy of them. It might be appropriate that they are.

—My understanding is that this course of action was acceptable to the minister and his advisers not because it is their preferred course of action but it was preferable to them than having a total deletion of 36A to C. You are right. They may not have been circulated.
—I am just informed that we need them, so we might postpone this.
—So what you are saying is our deletion of 36A to C is not effective at this stage.
—We will just postpone it for a short time and go to page 2. Senator Margetts, are you intending to proceed with Democrat‐Green amendments 134, 133 and A2?

—Amendments 133 and 134 are minor consequential amendments. They relate to 132 to omit subsection 36 which was to remove the provisions for ministerial intervention in arbitration. It went through very quickly, but my understanding is that the ALP just now, without talking about it, recommitted a vote where they reinstated ministerial intervention. Is that the case?

—I think amendments 134 and 133 at least are consequential on what happens to 132; and Democrats/Greens amendment 132 relates to opposition amendment 142. That is the one I spoke to a bit earlier and Senator Minchin wanted a bit more information on it. We discovered that the amendments had not been circulated. It is probably best that, at least in respect of 134 and 133, we defer them until after consideration of 142 and 132. I can assure Senator Margetts that we did not deal with that issue that quickly that she did not see it; we have not finished dealing with it.
—That is what I understand, too. It also relates to my 29, which I did not move. 26A was wiped out, was it not?
—Yes.
—Now we are looking forward to seeing Senator Bolkus's amendment.

—Senator Harradine, what we might do is set aside additional revised sheet 16 for the moment until we get the amendments circulated. If we can go on to sheet 17, we have opposition amendment 105. The subject area is item 10—freehold test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (105) Schedule 1, item 9, page 67 (lines 17 to 19), omit paragraph (c), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (c) the non‐extinguishment principle applies to the acquisition, but nothing in this Act prevents any activity that is done in giving effect to the purpose of the acquisition from extinguishing native title rights and interests if such an extinguishment would occur under the common law; and

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 105 is a provision that omits the government's proposal which is, as we believe, contrary to the common law and the current section 23(3). The Labor position restores the common law in respect of the extinguishment of native title where it is compulsorily acquired at the time or if the activity actually takes place, as opposed in respect of the government, at the grant of the empowering purpose. We had this debate last night. As I say, we believe that the common law says to go to the actual act which extinguishes rather than the empowering permit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the government position is to the contrary. It is the grant of the permit or lease or whatever it is that is the extinguishing act because only the crown, the government, can effect an extinguishment. So we oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed do.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now go to further revised sheet 18. The subject is item 3—confirmation of extinguishment. We have Democrats/Green amendments on the second page—Nos 5, 180, 181, 254, 259, 261, 262 and 264. 196 has been moved and postponed. Senator Woodley, while Senator Margetts is finding documents, you might like to go to your revised 836.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, item 49, page 133 (after line 9), at the end of section 249C, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) In Schedule 1, a reference to a State or Territory Act or Ordinance is a reference to the Act or Ordinance as at 23 December 1996 or to an Act or Ordinance repealed or amended before that date.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will avoid any uncertainty about the confirmation of exclusive possession and close off any prospective loophole that would allow state and territory governments to amend their legislation listed in schedule 4 and then alter the purpose of this provision.

I understand that the government has agreed to this provision and that, indeed, goes to creating certainty with regard to the parliament's intention with regard to previous exclusive possession acts. In effect, this amendment put a lid on the bucket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This was the amendment which I began to move earlier in the proceedings. It must have been some time ago. I believe that the wording has been changed so that the vast majority of senators are now in support of it. The Greens (WA) indicate that we support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: For the knowledge of the Senate, I have checked up on Greens (WA) and Democrat amendments 5, 180, 181, 254, 259, 261, 262, 264 and 196 postponed. They are all no longer able to be moved because they were consequential amendments. I seek leave to withdraw amendment No. 196.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now put the question in relation to Senator Woodley's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not believe that this provision is at all necessary. It repeats the situation that is clear in the act. It is an unnecessary amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I restate the Labor Party's position from the earlier debate that we do support this amendment. We think it is quite valuable.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now move to Senator Minchin's amend ment to omit and substitute subsection (9) of item 9, schedule 1, agreed to earlier today. Is leave granted to reconsider the amendment? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now go back to page 3 of further revised running sheet 18 and postponed Democrat-Greens amendment on sheet 841 revised 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 9, page 13 (lines 29 to 34), omit subsection (9), substitute:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Exclusion of acts benefiting Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders

PARA.TAB: (9) An act is not a previous exclusive possession act if it is:

TAB.TAB: (a) the grant or vesting of any thing that is made or done by or under legislation that makes provision for the grant or vesting of such things only to, in or for the benefit of, Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(b) the grant or vesting of any thing to or in a person to hold on trust for the benefit of Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders; or
(c) the grant or vesting of any thing over particular land or waters, if at the time a thing covered by paragraph (a) or (b) is in effect in relation to the land or waters; or

(d) it is an act which takes place pursuant to a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory that provides that native title is not extinguished by such acts or that any extinguishment by such acts is to be disregarded; or
(e) it is a grant of land made by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity; or
(f) this Act otherwise provides that the non‐extinguishment principle applies.

PARA.TAB: (9A) To avoid doubt, the fact that an act is, because of subsection (9), not a previous exclusive possession act does not imply that the act is not valid.
(9B) The non‐extinguishment principle applies to the acts referred to in subsection (9).

SPEECH.PARA: This is an additional amendment moved on behalf of the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats. It is a reworking of the words that we talked about earlier in relation to what is not an act of previous exclusive possession. I believe the amendment has been worded so that it should now get the support of the majority of the Senate. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate for the purposes of the committee that the government does oppose this provision because it runs contrary to policy in relation to crown to crown grants and refers to providing for the non-extinguishment principle, so it even takes it away from the common law. We cannot support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish the minister would not provoke. He knows that we have already had that debate about the common law. I will let it pass to the keeper this time.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to Senator Minchin's amendment to add paragraphs (b) to (d) to schedule 1, item 49, division 249C postponed earlier today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that was the technical consequential amendment that we discussed between the parties before that Senator Bolkus wanted to confirm was okay. Could we have an indication from the opposition whether that is now agreeable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is the clean‐up amendment that we were talking about last night. It saved us a lot of time in terms of trying to work out what word was and was not relevant now and again through the process. We support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —As sections 36A to 36C have been reinstated, it may be best to go back to running sheet 16 as at 3.43 p.m. on 4 December. However, opposition amendment sheet 845, amendment R114, only amends section 36. Therefore, it is not clear why the opposition wanted to reinstate 36A to 36C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to say is that that note is a little dated now. We have two pages of amendments. There is No. 114 on page 845 and No. 142 on page 842. I have moved amendment No. 142 and now move:

SPEECH.PARA: (114) Schedule 1, item 9, page 74 (after line 28), after subsection (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) A compulsory acquisition will be deemed to be an acquisition involving a conferral of interests on persons other than the Government party, unless it is stated in writing to be for a Government purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: (129) Schedule 1, item 9, page 86 (line 18), omit "34A,".
(135) Schedule 1, item 9, page 93 (line 8), omit "34A,".
(139) Schedule 1, item 9, page 95 (lines 8 and 9), omit paragraph (c).
(140) Schedule 1, item 9, page 95 (line 12), omit "34A,".
(142) Schedule 1, item 9 at the end of section 36, add:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Commonwealth Minister may give notice as to urgency

PARA.TAB: (4) At any time after the end of the period applicable under subsection (1) in respect of an application under section 35 that has not been withdrawn, and before either:

TAB.TAB: (a) the negotiation parties have made an agreement of the kind mentioned in paragraph 31(1)(b); or
(b) the arbitral body has made a determination under section 38;

the Commonwealth Minister may give a written notice to the arbitral body requesting the arbitral body to make such a determination within the period specified in the notice. The period must end not earlier than 30 days after the day on which the notice was given.

SPEECH.PARA: (143) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 14), omit "Relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(144) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (lines 21 and 22), omit paragraph (c).
(145) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 24), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(146) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 27), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(147) Schedule 1, item 9, page 96 (line 28), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(148) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (lines 1 to 13), omit paragraphs (2)(b) and (c) and subsection (3), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (b) it is in the national interest to make the determination at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: (149) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 14), omit "34A or".
(150) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 15), omit "34A or".
(151) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 16), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(152) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (lines 20 to 22), omit paragraph (a).
(153) Schedule 1, item 9, page 97 (line 24), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(154) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 2), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(155) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 22), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(156) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 27), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(157) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 29), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(158) Schedule 1, item 9, page 98 (line 31), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(159) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 13), omit "34A and".
(160) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 17), omit "34A or".
(161) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 21), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(162) Schedule 1, item 9, page 99 (line 30), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(163) Schedule 1, item 9, page 100 (line 2), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(164) Schedule 1, item 9, page 100 (line 20), omit "relevant", substitute "Commonwealth".
(165) Schedule 1, item 9, page 100 (line 28) to page 101 (line 5), omit subsection (7), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (7) The Commonwealth Minister must, as soon as practicable after making a determination, and in any case within 15 sitting days, cause a copy of the determination, together with reasons for the determination, to be laid before each House of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: (166) Schedule 1, item 9, page 101 (line 11), omit "34A or".
(174) Schedule 1, item 9, page 104 (line 30), omit "34A or".
(176) Schedule 1, item 9, page 108 (lines 22 and 23), omit "34A or 36A, or both,", substitute "36A".
(354) Schedule 5, item 11, page 335 (line 32), omit "34A,".

The problem we got into last night is that we carried an amendment to clauses that we had deleted. We had deleted clauses 36A, B and C and then we amended 36A, B and C after we deleted them. In discussions today, it seems to have been quite appropriate to all the parties that, in the spirit of cooperation, given that at the end of the day the will of the Senate was that we have a capacity for ministerial intervention after adequate notice in cases of urgency and so on, we revisit the issue today. We would revisit it in a way that would reinstate clauses 36A, B and C on the basis that, after their reinstatement, they would be amended in accordance with ALP R142. Amendment R142 states:
(4) At any time after the end of the period applicable under subsection (1) in respect of an application under section 35 that has not been withdrawn, and before either:

TAB.TAB: (a) the negotiation parties have made (114) Schedule 1, item 9, page 74 (after line 28), after subsection (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) If a compulsory acquisition is not stated in writing to be for a purpose that does not involve the conferral of interests on persons other than the Government party, it is presumed to be for that purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: an agreement of the kind mentioned in paragraph 31(1)(b); or

TAB.TAB: (b) the arbitral body has made a determination under section 38;
the Commonwealth Minister may give a written notice to the arbitral body requesting the arbitral body to make such a determination within the period specified in the notice.

SPEECH.PARA: If the arbitral body does not do so within 30 days, there is a capacity for ministerial intervention.

This probably should go up as a package. I do not think I am inclined to reinstate clauses 36A, B and C and then not get support for amendment Nos 142 and 114. I suggest that we deal with them altogether. We will have to deal with them sequentially.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't we going to split them?
—I will split them, if you like. Perhaps Senator Minchin would like to respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the purposes of the committee debate, we were obviously distressed to see clause 36A suddenly drop out. We think that clause 36A involves an important process, because the arbitral body is not absolutely required to make a determination within the six-month period that we had proposed. We do believe that it is important for the minister to have the capacity to intervene, if necessary, so we are pleased to see it reinstated. While prima facie the Labor amendment is not in accord with what we originally proposed, as I understand it, we have for the purposes of this committee debate agreed that the reinstatement is on the basis of the committee accepting this amendment. We will therefore not object to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need some clarification with Democrat-Greens (WA) amendments on additional revised sheet 16 that we started to deal with before. They are Nos 132, 134, 133 and a2. You may not need to proceed with them now. They concern item 13, the right to negotiate.
—No. We are not proceeding.
—We will now move to page 2 of additional revised sheet 16 and Democrat-Greens (WA) amendment No. 140 on sheet 800. I think Senator Harradine will move his amendment No. 46.
—Subject to what Senator Margetts says, they have all been subsumed into what we have just done in respect of Senator Bolkus's amendment.
—We will check through all the amendments. There are Senator Harradine's amendments Nos 46, 47, 48 and 49. There is then a group of Nos 40, 41, 43, 50 and 42. There is then No. 32.
—All bar No. 32 are consequential. I am not proceeding with No. 32. All bar No. 32 have been subsumed.
—Senator Margetts, you have amendment No. 177 relating to schedule 1. It reads, `Omit, and substitute items 42, 43 and 44 as amended'. Are you not proceeding with that?
—No.
—That is gone. We now move to opposition amendment No. 124A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke to amendment No. 124A earlier. It concerns renewals. I am told that it is a consequential amendment. As I said, through our clause 124, we amended proposed section 26D(1), which itself excluded the right to negotiate in respect of certain renewals, re‐grants and so on. We did that. To apply that decision consistently, we have to amend subdivision I to ensure that the acts we include in the right to negotiate by the earlier decision are not excluded from it by the regime as applied by subdivision I. In a sense, we are talking about a consequential amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (124A) Schedule 1, item 9, page 56 (after line 27), after subsection (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) This section does not apply where the original lease etc. is the creation of a right to mine, whether by the grant of a mining lease or otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope this is an appropriate moment to do this. My advisers have just pointed out to me an anomaly in the process relating to ALP amendment No. 128. I seek leave to have ALP amendment No. 128 reconsidered and the vote taken again for the following reasons—
—We agree with that.

—ALP amendment No. 128 is an amendment to paragraph 28(1)(a) and it inserts the words `or by the end of that period as extended by the Federal Court under subsection 190D(6).' That amendment was moved and agreed to yesterday, but ALP amendment 274, which inserted subsection 190D(6) and other subsections had previously been moved and not agreed to, therefore—if you are following this—
—What section of the bill does it refer to and what is the subject matter?

—It is section 28 on `act invalid if done before negotiation or objection'. It is under the right to negotiate. It is in this section. Therefore, amendment No. 128, which was agreed to yesterday, inserts a reference to a subsection which does not exist because the proposal to insert subsection 190D(6) was lost. It is merely technical, but it is a nonsense to have in there an amendment referring to a subsection which was not agreed to. I seek leave to have the item reconsidered:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I move that amendment 128 not be agreed to?
—We have not seen the new one yet. I gather I know what it is, but has it been circulated?

—It is merely technical. Your amendment No. 128, which was passed, referred to a clause 190D(6) which was not accepted by the committee. It is merely a clean‐up exercise. If you formally withdraw it, that should be okay.
—I do not know whether I need to withdraw the whole of amendment No. 128, or whether I just need to withdraw reference in amendment No. 128 to the particular words that are superfluous.

—The only purpose of that amendment is to refer to 190D(6). Amendment No. 128 inserts the words, `or by the end of that period as extended by the Federal Court under subsection 190D(6).' If there is no subsection 190D(6), the whole amendment is irrelevant.
—Senator Bolkus is seeking leave to withdraw amendment 128A. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.
—I am advised that there is a particular problem in respect of amendment No. 209, which was the amendment passed while everyone was blinking.
—That was passed yesterday. It is on additional revised sheet 16, on page 2.
—We do not have any other amendments to go to, do we? There is no further cleaning up, so that is it.
—Hooray!

—I do not want to encourage Senator Boswell to say anything at this stage. We are just checking something. Would Senator Margetts like to add something further to the debate while I check amendment 209?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We have come a long way. It was hard to envisage this morning that we would get to not quite 5 o'clock and be in a situation of getting close to a third reading and, hopefully, close to finally voting down the bill, because it is so rotten that it is insupportable.

SPEECH.PARA: The last few amendments have indicated how difficult it has been to deal with such a complex issue in the manner that we have proposed. It shows very accurately how much consultation would have been necessary to make this bill workable. We were dealing with suppositions that things would not work and, unfortunately, the very people on whom this is being perpetrated have not been part of the process.

For instance, we have dealt with debates in relation to whether or not there is a system that would work for fishing permits. It seems to me that if we had sat down with the people who were hoping to claim native title rights in relation to the right to negotiate on waters, we would have been able to work out a workable system with government on things like fishing permits. It would have been possible.

So many topics have been brought up where people have said that the world as we know it will end, but it would have been possible to resolve them by sitting down and working with the people on whom this legislation is meant to be focused. It would have been possible to work through systems which would work in those areas of pastoral leases, expedited procedures, indigenous land use agreements and so on.

What has been manifest in the debate we have had so far is that the minister has been telling us that such provisions are unworkable, and yet there has not been a process by which the workability has even been worked out with indigenous Australians. What we have seen is a farce. We have made some substantial changes, but most have been relatively small changes to a bill that is still manifestly unfair from the point of view of basic human rights and the enjoyment of native title.

The minster has continued to act as if native title is something that was somehow conferred by legislation, somehow a gift that parliament can give or take away—and, of course, it is not that—somehow must be earned, somehow must be proven in a complex legal process, somehow can be struck out in any number of ways and somehow can be impaired in any number of ways by the flick of a pen. That is exactly what has been done; there have been lots of flicks of the pen in this process.

We are dealing with something that, unfortunately, is not understood well by many people in Australia. It is not understood well because it was rushed through in undue haste. There was nothing like the process in 1993 when there was an effort to at least talk to as many people as possible. The process in 1993 still was not an acceptable process, but the 1997 legislation is appalling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem we have got is that in our amendment No. 209 we actually amended a schedule, whereas we should have been amending the principal act. We adopted the words: `does not interfere directly with the actual functioning of the way of life of the community' through amendment No. 209. The wording of subsection 237(a) of the Native Title Act: `the act does not directly interfere with the community life' should be deleted and replaced with the words `the act does not interfere directly with the actual functioning of the way of life of the community who are the holders' and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, we amended the government's bill and the schedule, but we did not technically amend subsection 237(a) of the act. I will go through it again. Subsection 237(a) of the act reads:
the act does not directly interfere with the community life of the persons who are the holders . . .

The amendment should delete `the act does not interfere with the community life of the persons who are the holders' and say `the act does not interfere directly with the actual functioning of the way of life of the community' and then go on to the rest of subsection 237(a). I am told we amended the bill, but not the act. I therefore formally move to amend subsection 237(a) of the Native Title Act. I move:
Schedule 1, item 42, page 130 (lines 25 to 27), omit the item, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Omit "does not directly interfere with the community life", substitute "does not interfere directly with the actual functioning of the way of life of the community".

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Bolkus's verbal amendment be agreed to.
—The opposition amendment subsumes my attempt which was referred to somewhere down the track. It is now made part of the act, so I am supporting that.
—I do not need to say any more, other than that the officials can get together with the clerks and restate what appears in the Hansard .

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Minchin) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments on the third reading of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . Firstly, I want to say that we have been involved in the committee stage of this legislation for 41 hours and 30 minutes. Together with the second reading debate, that means that we have spent over 55 hours and three minutes on this legislation. I am told that, in terms of the history books, the Native Title Act 1993 took 55 hours, so we are on par with that, but we are still four hours and 57 minutes behind the Communist Party dissolution legislation in the 1950s. Senator Minchin, that is the challenge for us next time round.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope this is my final speech in this debate. Before I make those concluding remarks, I would like to thank a number of people who have been of enormous assistance to me, my office and the opposition as a whole. Members of the public usually see only people like me speaking in this chamber and then only very short grabs of it. However, the very real reason why I and other members of the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens have been able to speak in such detail on these issues has been because of the tireless effort of a large number people behind the scenes.

Before I thank those people, I would like to thank the other hundreds, if not thousands of people, who have taken time out over the last 12 months or so to make representations to us, to put their views to us and to sit in the gallery, in parliamentary committees and through hours of debate on this issue. Their interest is not just in this issue but also in the future of Australia.

I would like to also thank my fellow senators on all sides of the House for their contributions to the debate and the way we have pursued this debate over recent weeks. On the Labor Party side, obviously, Senator Cooney and Senator Bob Collins have participated. Their contributions were valuable. Senator Margetts, Senator Woodley, Senator Brown and other Democrats, including Senator Lees, whom I congratulate on her accession to the role of leader, have played a very positive and constructive role.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Minchin, I suppose everyone expected a bit of a bloodbath this week, but we have not provided that. I think the process has actually worked faster than most people would have expected and with less acrimony.

I want to say a few words to Senator Harradine. From time to time in this debate I, and I am sure others, have been frustrated. We have resisted the temptation sometimes to get into competitive vote. I must say to you that I do not envy you your position. It is a hard one in any event. It is a hard one in terms of any normal run and flow of legislation in this place. From time to time, although frustrated, I for one—and I am sure the opposition in general—can say that we are very conscious of your position. We understand the difficult position that you have been put in.

I think it is unconscionable that the question of whether Australia embarks upon a race election can be so directly levelled at a group of people like us, and particularly you within that context. We have resisted the frustration to get into a direct combative disagreement. I think the major reasons for not doing that are that I think you have played a constructive role in this debate and we do recognise the pressures that you have been put under as well.

To all of those outside who might feel a degree of frustration, I point out that we have to recognise that, from time to time, in a process like this we are in the business of shaping, reshaping and making history and individuals have pressures on them. In your case, I think you have conducted your performance here in a way that, though I disagree with you often, I cannot disagree with. We appreciate that.

I would like to thank the members of the Labor Party shadow ministerial team—my colleagues Daryl Melham and, particularly, Gareth Evans. I think the shadow of former Senator Evans still haunts this place of this debate. The presence of Gareth Evans in this debate really cannot be underestimated and undervalued. He has an enormous brain and has played an enormous role. I am sure that everyone who has been involved with us appreciates the role he has played. Daryl's commitment and continual activity in this area is also appreciated. Other members of our shadow ministerial team include our leader, who has taken a very attentive and consistently supportive role in this debate, our leader in this place, John Faulkner, Stephen Smith and Neil O'Keefe.

I mentioned earlier that there is a whole range of people who have been enormously helpful. I have to start with the National Indigenous Working Group and its staff, particularly Peter Yu, David Ross, Noel Pearson, Tracker Tilmouth, Ogla Havnen, Michael O'Donnell, Warren Snowdon, Andrew Chalk, Claire Henderson and Kyrn Steven. The ATSIC chair, Gatjil Djerrkura has played an enormously supportive and advisory role, as have ATSIC commissioners Geoff Clarke and Terry O'Shane.

The people who have worked in my office and Daryl Melham's office over recent months need to be acknowledged. They are Chris McGrath, Christine Evans, Nina Gerace—whose birthday it is today; we wish her the best and hope she has got away from here—Tamara Kamien, Toni Kytrokas, Carolyn Tan, Jeremy Goff, Chris Athanasiou, Angus Frith, Simeon Beckett, Lorena Di Sabato, Liz Iser, Philip Bolton, Richard Williams, Sean Brennan, Ron Castan QC, John Basten QC and Geoff Harders. I thank Simon Banks, in particular, from my office. The two trusted advisers, who have put up with us in the last week or so, Mike Megaw and James Fitzgerald. have to be acknowledged as well for the amazing amount of work they have done. In respect of all of them, thanks very much.

Staff of other shadow ministers' offices and senators have to be acknowledged, especially those in John Faulkner's office. I thank Lenka Peraic, Vikki Gibson, Renee Gamble, George Thompson, Colin Campbell, Justin De Lollo, Christina Valentine and Ruth Webber. Those in Senator Chris Evans's office have also done an enormous job. I must also place on record our appreciation of the partners of Arnold Bloch Leibler, especially Mark Leibler and Dwyer Durack, for their assistance and Mr Alec Shand for his impressive and superlative legal advice.

The people who are often forgotten, but who have really been working slavishly are the staff of the Senate and the two parliamentary committees that have assisted us. In particularly I would like to thank Harry Evans, Rosemary Laing and Kathleen Griffiths; all of the staff in the Senate Table Office—particularly Rosa Ferranda, who has had the near impossible task of preparing running sheets of almost a thousand amendments; the staff of both parliamentary committees, especially Peter Grundy and Steve Curran; Neil Bessell from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee, who has just won a promotion as the Senior Clerk Committees; Krysti Guest and Libby Bunyan; and in the Parliamentary Research Service, Jennifer Norberry and Ian Ireland. They have all done an enormous job. They are professionals who cannot be underestimated. We are forever indebted to them.

We now get to the stage of what we do with the government's legislation. I have to say at this stage that on balance the opposition has decided to support the third reading of this bill. We do so acutely conscious of the fact that less than 30 per cent of the amendments that we have moved—when I say 30 per cent, most of the ones that have been accepted have been more consequential than otherwise—a very small proportion, have passed.

There is, as a result of the process over the last week, much in the government's legislation that we regard as unjust, legally uncertain and likely to be unworkable in practice. If the bill passes into law in its present form, there will be inevitably, sooner rather than later, legal challenges mounted to some or other aspects of it. The validation clauses and the discriminatory overreach of section 4 are just two matters that come to mind. It may very well be that it will only take one court case accordingly for us to be back in parliament trying to make this legislation more workable. All that said, on balance we take the view that the bill as amended by this place will be sufficiently workable and sufficiently improved, if they are the criteria you want to apply, to justify the legislation proceeding into law.

We have consulted closely throughout this whole debate with those whose interests are most closely affected by the legislation—pastoralists, miners as well as, particularly, indigenous Australians. We are convinced that everyone wants this issue to be resolved as quickly as possible and with as much balance and certainty as possible between the competing interests. Indigenous Australians, as represented by the National Indigenous Working Group, are most definitely unhappy and we should not walk out of this place without recognising this. They are most definitely unhappy with the balance presently struck by this legislation and the failure of opposition parties to have more of our amendments accepted.

But we understand their view to be that it is better for this bill to come into force, enabling everyone to get on with the process of advancing and reconciling rights and interests, than for the present totally unsatisfactory limbo to continue.We also find it extremely difficult to believe that the mining industry will see any virtue at all in that limbo continuing for the duration of the protracted parliamentary stand‐off that we have been threatened with, followed by a divisive election in the latter part of next year and a further round of parliamentary processes before there would be any new law on the books. I find it very hard to believe that industry will want to wait another 12 months before they get a new law. They would wait another 12 months and suffer a divisive race election in the meantime.

So whatever voices the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) may think he is hearing, the truth is that, in adopting the extremely confrontationist stance that he has in recent days, he is in no way acting in the best interests of any of the stakeholders—indigenous Australians, pastoralists, miners or the wider taxpaying Australian community. A responsible Australian Prime Minister, one who is a genuine national leader, would do a number of things. Firstly, he would recognise that the bill he put before this parliament was never going to be approved in the form in which he introduced it. Just keep in mind that government amendments to this legislation, both in the House of Representatives and here, far outweigh in number the amendments carried in the Senate.

Secondly, any genuine national leader would accept the realities forced on the bill, and he would also accept the absolute unlikelihood of any more accommodating shift in the Senate's position. Thirdly, any genuine national leader would acknowledge that he has in fact retained—with the help of the Senate, with the help of Senator Harradine, if not the Democrats, the Greens and, particularly, the opposition—the substance of most of the 10 points in his 10‐point plan.

On our calculations, there are clear wins on seven of the 10 points and mixed wins in respect of the other three. Any genuine national leader, having recognised these three things, having recognised the divisiveness of an alternative approach in terms of this country and its standing, would take this and move on. I am sure interested stakeholders have got more out of this process, and know they have got more out of this process, than they would ever have dreamed of 12 months ago.

But the trouble with the present Australian Prime Minister is that he is neither a responsible Prime Minister nor a genuine national leader. He cannot, and never has been able to, bring himself to do the right thing, because he is a weak leader. He is bound and gagged by the National Party and the more extreme elements of his own back bench. That is something that Australia has to live with.

I say in respect of that back bench that we know how this Prime Minister will be judged by history. At best, if he embarks upon a race election campaign, he will be judged by history as someone who has been prepared to live off the political benefits of a race election. That is the best that history will ascribe to him.

But I say to the other side, to the `wets' in the Liberal Party, to Senator Vanstone, Senator Hill, Senator Payne and Senator Coonan: do you also want to be judged in the same manner? Do you also want to be judged as fellow travellers with a Prime Minister who is judged in such a way? We have not heard your voices in this debate, apart from one occasion when Senator Hill gave a short speech during the second reading debate. We have not heard the voices of the others. Silence is no excuse in this matter. I say to them that they have a challenge in the next few months: to save Australia from a divisive race campaign.

I know that there is discussion in the Liberal Party about leadership, but what people do not know is that, over the last few weeks, there has been a coming together of the forces. The Costello ticket seems to have come together with the John Fahey ticket—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are lowering the value of the debate now.

—I am serious about this. I bet you that, any time in the next few months, there will be broader discussion of a ticket based on Costello as leader and John Fahey as deputy. I am glad that some people in the opposition are starting to think that way because it would be unconscionable for Australia to be forced down the road to a double dissolution, given the fact that this government has got so much out of this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In my opinion, the Native Title Amendment Bill is a return to terra nullius—that is, it is a return to the assumption that Australia was empty and, if there are indigenous Australians around, they are in the way. I do not believe the bill has been, as Senator Bolkus has said, sufficiently improved. If I were to vote for this bill, it would mean that I agreed that it was an acceptable starting point to move from here to something that is agreeable. It is not.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank the National Indigenous Working Group very much for all their work with us and for the many hours that we have spent together in working through this very complex issue of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . It is very clear that the yellow document of coexistence was the document that people were working to in trying to reach that level of consensus. This bill does not even come vaguely close.

I made a promise in front of Australia, I guess, to a certain extent, in relation to the six steps to coexistence, and this bill does not come close. I made a promise to Robert Bropho and to Mingli Wanjurri Nangala and to Clarrie Isaacs. As Robert left he said, `Walk tall and tell the truth.' The truth is that this bill is not nearly acceptable, not even close.

I give my immense thanks to my staff, and in particular to Matt Fagan, who joined my staff only a few weeks ago. He has lived, breathed and eaten the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 over the last few weeks. I was going to say that he has used all his waking hours; he is probably dreaming and nightmaring about the bill as well. He has been absolutely fantastic, and my immense thanks go to him. I also thank Gary Corr for his immense work, dedication and warped sense of humour, and I thank Alan Carter, Andrew Chalk, and all the people from the National Indigenous Working Group who have put in just so much time and effort in assisting the Greens (WA) in our response to the Native Title Amendment Bill.

I want to take this opportunity to thank all Parliament House staff, because I will not have another opportunity, for all the work they have done and the assistance they have given us this year but in particular in the last few weeks in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill. I thank the clerks, the Parliamentary Library and committee staff. It has been fantastic.

It is a very sad day for Australia, I think, that this is what we have come to. Quite clearly, the Greens have been told again and again through phone calls, letters and faxes that the 10‐point plan being presented by the government is unfair, unjust and should be resisted. We have come to a marginal improvement, but it is in no way acceptable. The Greens (WA) will not be voting for the third reading and, because we believe it is such an important part of history, we will be dividing on the third reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this debate the Australian Democrats noted the absence of indigenous representatives in the Senate and indeed throughout the whole parliament. We said at the time—and we reassert now—that we stand shoulder to shoulder with indigenous Australia. Indeed, on behalf of the National Indigenous Working Group, the Australian Democrats have co-sponsored with the Greens their position in total. I want to thank the National Indigenous Working Group for their dedication. I recognise the tension and pressure they have been under, but they have produced magnificent support for all of us in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise and acknowledge three people from Aurukun who came this week and observed the debate. They are the Wik people, and they were here to see what was happening. They were amazed when they heard some of the remarks which were made about Aboriginal people and the threat that they might be to other Australians. They found it hard to believe they were hearing that because, they said, `We're Australians too.' That sometimes seems to be forgotten. They gave a human face, I think, to this word which has been repeated thousands of time this week: Wik. It describes some real people who live in Cape York.

I thank all the other senators in this place. I really do not want to name anyone. Perhaps I should just mention my friend Ron Boswell. We do have some stoushes at times, but there is no‐one who is more sincere in his convictions than Ron Boswell. I just do not agree with him; that's the problem. I will not mention other senators. I recognise all those who have taken part in the debate. I do mention the senators in my own party and the support that they have given me, because I only picked this up a couple of weeks ago when something happened here which threw me into the debate. I say that in terms of the bill only, because it is a debate I have been engaged in and a commitment I have had for many years to the struggle for justice for Aboriginal and Islander people.

I would like to particularly thank the staff in my own office: John Davey, Graham Carter from the National Indigenous Working Group, Vivienne Wynter and Kerri Kellett. I know that later on Meg Lees will be thanking the parliament staff, so I will not do that now, but they have been a tremendous support. You hear people outside Canberra talk about bureaucrats as though they were some breed of non‐human animal. The kind of support we get in this place from bureaucrats is just absolutely tremendous. They are wonderful human beings. But I will leave that to Meg.

However, we have been under no illusion that the primary moral responsibility for this matter rests with each of us here in the Senate. The National Indigenous Working Group has left it up to individual senators as to whether or not they support the amended bill. The Democrats believe wholeheartedly that, at this historic time and despite an exhaustive committee process, justice has not been delivered to our indigenous brothers and sisters. My association with Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders has been a journey of 35 years. Today is the first stage in the next stage of the journey, as we continue to walk with them. In conclusion, I state that the Australian Democrats will be voting against the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had some 55 hours of debate on probably one of the hardest philosophical differences ever presented to this parliament. Apart from about five minutes of biff at about a quarter to one last night, the rest of the debate was carried out under the Marquess of Queensberry rules. This has been a very hard debate. At least in the Mabo debate the Aboriginal people went away happy, but in this debate, unfortunately, no-one walks away happy, no-one is a winner. So we have not come up with a satisfactory conclusion for anyone.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge Senator Harradine. I would never question his morality, his ability or his integrity. I know the pressure that he has been under over the last 55 hours, and probably weeks before. If in any way I have offended him, I say, `Peace to you, brother.'

The National Party constituency has had a hard and bitter pill to swallow. They have had to move away from a position of no native title on pastoral leases to one where there is a big compromise. I ask everyone on all sides of the debate to understand their position, too. They have lost a number of things—the sunset clause, the threshold test, the right to negotiate—and have picked up the schedule on the pastoral leases. Many minor amendments—some 1,000—have been moved. I do not know what the score is in respect of the amendments we supported and those we opposed.

I congratulate Senator Minchin, Senator Bolkus, Senator Woodley, Senator Margetts and Senator Brown. They stayed on the course all the time. My main consideration is that I want wealth for all Australians. If this bill is not addressed in some form in the near future, I believe we are going to put a wheel lock on both our mining and our pastoral industries. We have had that debate. We believe we have not come out in front, but we have salvaged something out of it. So I thank everyone very much for the way they have participated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Margetts, I will be voting against the third reading of this native title legislation. It is a step further in what Mick Dodson has called the persistence of doctrines of dispossession. Its outcome is one of dispossessing indigenous people of their right to negotiate about the land. There is some confusion about this, but let me make it easy.

SPEECH.PARA: The right to negotiate has been retained with some aspects of mining at least but, when it comes to the wider issues of the face of the land to which the Aboriginal people so closely relate, the right to negotiate as enormous changes occur across this country in the coming century will be lost if this legislation is to prevail. They cannot negotiate in respect of massive changes involving agriculture, dams, canals, the cutting of native vegetation and mineral exploration camps. In the offshore region, which is so important to them, coastal indigenous people have no right to negotiate when it comes to the application of fishery developments, mining exploration, jetties, ports and other wholesale changes which are going to impact on the face of the country as they have always known it. We are going to see a continued erosion as a result of this legislation for however long it prevails and a retreat of the rights of the indigenous people to have a say in the land which is their everything.

BREAK.PARA: Behind this is enormous pressure for development and economic advantage. As the United Nations Special Rapporteur on indigenous matters, Mrs Erica‐Irene Daes, has observed:
It is safe to say that the attitudes, doctrines and policies developed to justify the taking of lands from Indigenous peoples were and continue to be largely driven by the economic agendas of States.
For the `taking of lands', read the taking of the right to negotiate about lands. That is what is so wrong with this legislation.

That said, I also want to pay tribute to all those who have, by and large, so calmly contributed under such enormous pressure, not least to Senator Minchin, Senator Boswell and also Senator Harradine, whose lunchtime has become somewhat of a legend. I also pay tribute to Senator Woodley, to the opposition as a whole, and to Senator Bolkus, who has been trying to keep me at bay during this debate. He has done a magnificent job in presenting the opposition point of view, notwithstanding our differences of opinion. We had a much stronger concern about and defence of that right to negotiate, about which I have just spoken.

Finally, I would like to pay tribute to my colleague and friend Senator Margetts. This has been a long travail. Like Senator Harradine, we had very limited resources but hundreds of amendments and huge amounts of advice to get through—a very complicated process. I have felt extraordinarily well represented in her work, and I can only hope that the people who have a much more important stake in this have a sense of the work she has done as well. I congratulate you, Senator Margetts for the stoicism and the intelligence with which you have put the case. Of course, I extend that comment to everybody who has taken part in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has indeed been a marathon debate. I never expected it to go for six full days in committee. I think it even exceeds the amount of time spent on the Native Title Act when it was debated in this place. That was when I had only just arrived and was sitting over there, about where Senator Ray is now, watching Senator Gareth Evans hold the floor for so long. It is a bittersweet feeling, I guess, for me in that I am glad it is over, but I am extremely disappointed with the outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with other speakers in thanking everybody involved. I was going to thank Senator Bolkus profusely for his very moderate and reasoned approach to this debate until he said some very unpleasant things about my leader in his remarks. Nevertheless, I do appreciate his cooperation and the way this has been managed in what I think has been a workmanlike, professional way in getting through a very big, complex and difficult piece of legislation. I say that as well to other senators with whom obviously we have had disagreement but who have expressed their views honestly, passionately and with great integrity. I must take this opportunity to thank my own staff; the Wik task force, in particular; the Senate staff who have been superb in this—I have never seen such a flow of amendments and amendments and amendments to amendments—and all the interest groups who I know have been in and around the parliament throughout this debate, consulting and advising everybody involved in it.

I am extremely disappointed with the outcome, as I said. I have personally been working on the issue of amending the Native Title Act since we were elected in March last year, which is now some 19 months ago. It has been a long and arduous task. It is a very complex area of law involving some of the most difficult issues the nation can face in terms of Commonwealth-state responsibilities, common law, statutory law, questions of the entitlement of our indigenous peoples and their interrelationship with the rest of us in terms of our use of land. Some very emotional issues have been involved. I have not enjoyed the personal attacks made on me, nor have my family, but I know that is a function of being in politics and involved in such an emotive issue.

I certainly have made many friends in the course of this long and arduous task in bringing this bill to this point, including people in Aboriginal communities throughout Australia whom I have visited and talked to in great depth about their attitude to this whole issue and the issues that are important to them. I am pleased to see Senator Bob Collins joining the government on this side of the chamber.

I want to thank Senator Harradine for his support of some of the more crucial aspects of this bill—in particular, the validation regime and the confirmation regime. But there are some critical aspects of this package which have not met with the support of the committee and which are very basic and fundamental to our approach to native title—most particularly, the registration test which, as I said, was the one area where, most particularly, Aboriginal people felt we should be doing something. I think the committee has fallen short of their expectations in that area.

As for the whole issue of the statutory right to negotiate and the way that is to operate, I think the outcome of the debate there is extremely disappointing. Most particularly, the vote today to subject the Native Title Act to another piece of Commonwealth legislation—the Racial Discrimination Act—makes the Native Title Act essentially unworkable and makes anyone doing anything under the Native Title Act subject to enormous and endless litigation. That is no way to conduct the land management system of Australia, which is fundamental to the economic welfare and wellbeing of the nation. We will however be voting in favour of the bill on the third reading in this place and sending it back to the House of Representatives. It is a matter for the government in the House of Representatives to determine its position then on the bill.

I can only say with all the honesty I can muster that I do believe we put together a very fair and balanced package. It was criticised by a lot of people because it was a compromise. It did not give the farming community what they felt they had every right to believe was their right—that is, that they had what Mr Keating promised: exclusive possession on their pastoral leases. It did not give the mining industry what it wanted. It certainly did not give state and territory governments what they wanted in relation to this whole area, and it did not give ATSIC and the National Indigenous Working Group the outcome they desired. It was very much in the vein of seeking a compromise that involved sacrifice on the part of all the interest groups involved in this extremely difficult issue and, for that reason, it was subjected to a considerable amount of criticism.

We maintain our view that this was an extremely fair package which does protect, preserve and respect the Wik and Mabo decisions and, as I said, it enables native title to be claimed on 79 per cent of Australia.
