May I close by just thanking everybody involved, and genuinely thanking Senator Bolkus for his cooperation in what has been a marathon debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Four years ago this month we stood in this place on the third reading of the Native Title Act. I can recall saying in that third reading, and it was almost midnight on 23 December—
—It was 23 December at five to 12.

—It was 23 December at five to 12, as Senator Herron reminds me. I said on that occasion that the parliament had been shamed into grappling with the issue of native title to provide justice to the Aboriginals and to recognise that this country was not terra nullius. We as a parliament were shamed into having to focus on that issue by the High Court. It is a problem we should have tackled years before, and I blame myself as much as anybody else. Had we done so, the stakeholders would have had legislative certainty rather than a situation where they are going to the courts time and time again.

SPEECH.PARA: I said on that occasion that probably we would have to revisit the Native Title Act. Because of further decisions of the courts—not the least of which is Brandy, but mainly because of Wik—three years later in December 1996, the Wik decision again confronted us with the need to act. I do not think that is very often understood by the public. Very often they wonder what we are doing in this place dealing with an issue in a much similiar manner. What we have been doing is attempting to enable persons to have their common law rights structured into legislation. That means examining the decisions of the High Court and seeing whether we have it right. We may not have it right. It may well be that the court may say different things at certain times, but we have given it our best shot. That outcome, of course, is not entirely satisfactory to anybody. Did anybody around the chamber believe that it ever would be? That is the question that you have to ask yourselves.

However, as has been indicated around the chamber, I do believe that the outcome gives the government most of its 10 points—seven of them, as Senator Bolkus has indicated, and parts of the other three. Having regard to that, I feel that the government should take a little while to consider it and then see—and I am sure that they will see—that the outcome of this lengthy consideration will be workable. All stakeholders, the native title holders, the pastoralists and the miners will be able to live with the legislation—the outcome of our deliberations.

I also want to thank a number of people. I thank my staff in particular. They have been under enormous pressure. As has been said, I have only four staff. I do thank them. I thank the thousands and thousands of people who have written and called our office on this matter. I can assure them that I am very grateful for them giving me their time and their feelings. Many of the letters were quite touching. Unfortunately, I have not been able to, and will not be able to, respond to most of them. My postage probably would not run to anywhere near covering that. The Christmas stamps certainly would not run to anywhere near covering that, but I thank them for taking the trouble to write to me.

I also want to thank the staff of the parliament. The staff of the parliament have been absolutely marvellous, and the staff of the chamber have been extremely attentive. With all of the piles of paper that we have had to go through, they have expertly attended to our requests to obtain running sheets and the huge number of amendments. Those who compiled the running sheets should also get special thanks. I do thank them. Dr Rosemary Laing and her staff have been marvellous in preparing the amendments on the instructions that I gave them, and the amendments, by and large, were absolutely spot on. I think the result was almost 100 per cent. The amendments, in one form or another, got through this chamber. I also want to thank the staff of the library and the staff of the Joint Committee on Native Title, particularly the secretary, Peter Grundy.

I do not want to be political in any sense, but I do think I should say this now. I heard that some member of parliament did suggest that some of the amendments were Jesuitical. I want to say this so that nobody is under any misapprehension. Utilising the services of the secretary of the native title committee and the resources of this parliament I came to a decision two weeks ago as to what was the bottom line. I had decided that there was need for a bottom line—essential amendments which I believed the government would be able to live with and which would give a semblance and, hopefully, a high degree of justice to all stakeholders. That was done at that time.

Subsequently, I did in fact consult a number of people, one of the most important of whom was Father Frank Brennan. I do wish to acknowledge the assistance he gave to me. I do not wish to say that what I came up with reflected his view, but I know he is an expert in this field and of the people I consulted, a major person was Father Frank Brennan.

Again, I wish to acknowledge the legal advisers that I have been fortunate to have in the last few days in the persons of two lawyers from the New South Wales bar, John McCarthy and Jeff Kildea. They were extremely useful because they were acting on my instructions as to my amendments, but John McCarthy and Jeff Kildea were the representatives of the Aboriginal group in the Crescent Head settlement. That was the first native title claim settlement in the history of Australia since Europeans came here. Indeed, I mentioned during discussions that I had been to Namadgi National Park last Friday night and Saturday night and camped there. They said they are acting for the Ngunnawal people in their native title claim in this area.

BREAK.PARA: I particlularly wish to thank my colleagues in the Senate. I thank you all for the courtesy that you have shown me. I wish to thank especially Senator Minchin and Senator Bolkus and there talented advisors. It is invidious to single out people, but I would like to thank Senator Cooney, Senator Woodley, Senator Margetts, Senator Brown and, of course, Senator Boswell. I do thank you all.

I did apologise to the committee today. Yes, Senator Minchin did wonder what happened at lunchtime. He said that before lunch I was on the government side and after lunch I was on the opposition side with regard to the RDA. He said, `I wonder what he ate for lunch.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Two QCs, Senator Harradine.

—Ah! Some of us did not have lunch on most days. Today I had a sandwich. I cannot remember what was in it, but I know what I ate after lunch; and that was heaps of craw—humble pie—in this chamber. With that, I can only thank honourable senators for their patience.

BREAK.PARA: Let me say to the opposition, Democrats and Greens that I listened intently right through to see whether my minimalist position should change. You understand that it did on occasion. On the issue of the RDA, you might say that I changed my mind. However, you would have noticed that on my running sheet of amendments I did have an RDA provision, so it should not have come as a surprise to anybody that I was wavering one way and the other.

Finally, I would like to thank all of those persons who were praying right throughout Australia for the members of parliament. I think it did sustain and guide us throughout the long period and I hope it will do so in future debates on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bill be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Bill read a third time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We are proposing that the order of business now be that the Senate deal with a notice of motion to be moved by Senator Woodley. Then we will deal with committee memberships, which is a brief housekeeping matter; presentation of a document by a minister; tabling of a docu ment by the clerk; and receipt of a message from the House of Representatives regarding the Public Accounts Committee membership. Then a positive item that will get carried is to grant senators leave of absence and we will set a time for our next meeting. We will then hold short valedictory speeches and then I will move the adjournment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Woodley) proposed:
That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Having regard to the documents presented to the Senate by the President on 25 August 1997, and any other relevant evidence, whether any false or misleading evidence was given to the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, and whether any contempt was committed in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to delay the Senate long on this, and I am not speaking as the chairman of the Privileges Committee this time, only as a member. These sorts of matters have been constantly sent to the Privileges Committee. Similar ones from the same complainants have been there before and have been dismissed. It was hoped that the Connolly‐Ryan inquiry would have given them the avenue to air these grievances, because basically the intention is to air other grievances rather than those strictly defined by you, Madam President. I am really not sure whether the Senate and the Privileges Committee should bother with this one because it will come up with the same results as it has every time in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: This to me has been a waste of the time and resources of the Privileges committee once again. The main reason I suspect it is back here—I am not suspecting Senator Woodley but the people who have raised it with him—is that the Connolly-Ryan commission has closed down. Suddenly their great venue, which I really would encourage them to take these issues up in, is no longer in existence.

I stress that I am not speaking in this debate as chairman of the Privileges Committee. I guess I will not oppose Senator Woodley's motion, but people are going to have to stop thinking, `Oh, look, we've got a little problem here. Let's punt it off to the Privileges Committee.' It is just an absolute waste of resources because we are never going to get to the bottom of it, as we have not on the previous several occasions when this sort of issue has come up related to the same complainants.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from party leaders seeking variations to membership of committees.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell)—by leave—agreed to:
That senators be discharged from and appointed to committees as follows:
Finance and Public Administration References Committee

PARA.TAB: Substitute members: Senators Ray and Faulkner to replace Senators Gibbs and Mackay for the committee's inquiry into the Government's decision to divest itself of 57 Commonwealth properties.

INTERJECT.PARA: Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit

PARA.TAB: Appointed: Senators Coonan, Crowley, Gibson, Hogg, Murray and Watson to take effect from the date of commencement of Schedule 2 of the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Act 1997.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report on progress for 1996-97 for the Data‐Matching Program.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate with the appointment of members of the House of Representatives to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:

That the Senate, at its rising, adjourn till Monday, 2 March 1998, at 12.30 p.m., or such other time as may be fixed by the President or, in the event of the President being unavailable, by the Deputy President, and that the time of meeting so determined shall be notified to each senator.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell)—by leave—agreed to:
That valedictory statements may proceed immediately without any question before the chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the government, I want to acknowledge and thank a whole range of people who make the Australian Senate work and who have ensured that 1997 has been a productive year. I also want to outline briefly the achievements we have made in terms of legislation throughout the year and to thank those who have made it possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Because it is so close to our minds, I firstly wish to say that the debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 was an example of a very effective way of handling legislation. It was certainly one of the most complex, if not the most complex, pieces of legislation to come before this place in a long time. I am happy to inform senators that it has broken the record for being the longest debate on a single piece of legislation in the history of Australia, having finished about 56 hours and 10 minutes after it started. It beat the previous record, which was held by the Native Title Bill and it beat the record of consideration of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill which the Senate dealt with this time last year. I guess it is some record in this term of the government that in the first two years we had two of the longest debates in the history of Australia.

Having said that, we handled an enormous amount of legislation in 1997. We have sat longer than the Senate has done for many years. We sat for 83 sitting days in 1997. We only sat for 71 last year. Of course, that was an election year, so it was not unusual that the time should be a bit shorter. In 1994 we sat for 80 days, so we have sat for generally longer than we have sat before.

If you are interested in statistics, the Senate has sat for a total of 734 hours and 36 minutes. We have sat past 11 p.m. on only 15 occasions, which will keep Senator John Herron happy. We have passed something like 227 pieces of legislation. We hope that some of them have made Australia a better place. That compares, for example, with 1996, where the Senate passed only 83 pieces of legislation. So we have done an enormous amount of work. We have handled something like 2,512 amendments in that time, and something like 1,391 of those were agreed to. If you compare those statistics with 1996, we have done more than double, and triple on some of those matters.

Rather than just state those sorts of bald statistics, an interesting point to note in relation to how the Senate is operating this year as compared with previous years is the number of committee reports that have been handed down in the past year. It probably will not surprise you, but this chamber has received 123 reports in the last 12 months. If you compare that with the statistics for sitting days, you will find that we have been receiving committee reports at a rate of greater than one per day. So the committee system is working at full speed.

From a management of government business point of view, it is interesting to note that there has been a massive increase in the number of bills that have been referred to committees for consideration before they get into the chamber. Those who sit on the Selection of Bills Committee know that the government is concerned to ensure that legislation goes to committees and is reported back as quickly as possible. We have made some reforms to that process to ensure that it takes place. We want to ensure that legislation is available for the chamber to debate. If it is all locked away in committees for too long, that can create bottlenecks. It is fair to say this year that the normal bottleneck at the end of sitting periods has been diminished somewhat. That has been made possible because of the cooperation of senators on the other side of the aisle in the opposition and in the minor parties.

I want to say some words of thanks to the very great number of people who make this place tick. Firstly, I thank all my colleagues, all the coalition senators and all their staff. We would not have been able to handle the amount of legislation we have if it were not for the incredible discipline that coalition senators have shown. With very few exceptions, they have refrained from speaking in second reading debates. They have had to restrict their remarks to other occasions to make contributions to the chamber. Almost without exception, ministers or parliamentary secretaries have been carrying the committee debates without interventions from other coalition senators. It is a remarkable discipline. It has ensured that we have been able to handle a lot more legislation than otherwise would have been possible.

I started off talking about the native title debate. One thing that struck me about it was that, through discussion and cooperation, the senators involved in that debate decided at the very beginning of the committee stage not to call divisions except on the odd occasion. That shows a lot of discipline from all senators to ensure that complicated matters were dealt with without unnecessary interruption. Look at the statistics of that debate. There were 21 packages of amendments. If there had been two or three amendments voted on for each package, you would have had 60 divisions. Each division takes something like eight or nine minutes, so we could have had something like 600 minutes, or 10 hours, of divisions. We would have still been sitting here at lunchtime on Sunday if senators had chosen to divide.

We owe a vote of thanks to those senators involved in that debate. I know that people held very strong views on all different sides of the debate. They could have chosen to vent their frustration and emotion by calling divisions and making themselves feel better. But we all feel better for the fact that the debate is over roughly 60 hours earlier because of that commonsense approach.

I thank my leader Robert Hill, whom I have to work with very closely, and Nigel Henham in his office, who keeps in contact regularly. I also thank other ministers of the Crown and their staff as well as departmental advisers who have to liaise with me and my office very regularly. While mentioning my office, I thank Alana Oatham, who advises me on managing government business. I could not possibly do the job without Alana, who has to liaise with all these people.

I thank all the whips, not just the government whips, who do a tremendous job. I particularly thank Paul Calvert, the government whip, Bill Heffernan, the new deputy whip, Claire Dace, Anna McPhee and Suzanne Ferguson, who all staff the government whip's office. I also pay particular thanks to Senator Chris Evans, the opposition whip, and his staff, including Ruth Webber. I thank Vicki Bourne from the Democrats and Jene Fletcher in her office. I mention the people in the offices because, even though the whips have the jobs and the titles and have to come in here, if it were not, as you know, Madam President—you were a whip yourself—for the staff in these offices, the place would not run. They have to chase down the whips, the leaders and the managers.

This place runs on communication. When communications break down outside the chamber, the processes inside the chamber break down very quickly. If you are trying to change something in this chamber, you need to communicate and try to find a consensus as quickly as possible. If you leave someone out of the communications loop, usually accidentally, you create potential havoc inside the chamber. I thank all those people.

I thank, in the Greens office, Alan Carter and Ben Oquist; and, in Senator Harradine's office, Senator Harradine himself and Kathryn Millar. I thank also the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, John Faulkner, for his cooperation and assistance in helping to make this session manageable. I give particular thanks to the Manager of Opposition Business, Kim Carr, who has been very professional to deal with in managing this chamber's business. As Senator Faulkner knows, in managing a chamber where no party has held a majority for a long time, it takes a lot of cooperation and communication to make it work. I also thank Steven in Senator Carr's office for smoothing communications. I thank all non-government senators in all the other parties for their cooperation. We do not always agree. The non-government senators, particularly the senators on the crossbenches, do things grudgingly. However, more often than not, they are agreeable.

I thank in the other place the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for the opportunities he has given me, and the Treasurer (Mr Costello); I serve as his parliamentary secretary, and it has been an honour to work with him. Very importantly, I thank the Leader of the House, Hon. Peter Reith, and Cate Clunies‐Ross in his office; we have to liaise very closely in ensuring that there is a flow of legislation between the two places and that that takes place effectively.

The real people who make this place tick are not so much the elected people and their staff. It really falls to the people around this chamber and around this building to make the whole place operate. Those of us who spend so many days of our lives in this place realise that. I would like to thank as many of them as I can. I am sure that I will forget or leave out people. I hope that I will not leave out too many. I thank them all.

I would particularly like to thank those who work closest with me and who have made the job of managing government business in my first full year in the job a delight, and much easier than I expected it would be. In particular, I thank Gail Bansemer, the parliamentary liaison officer, who stepped into the job about a year ago, taking over from Nhan Vo Van. Everyone who has dealt with Gail will know that she has done an exceptional job and has fitted into Nhan Vo Van's big shoes in terms of that job very effectively. It is one of the toughest high‐stress jobs. If that job is not done properly, the Senate would not operate, and the government could not possibly operate in this chamber. Gail is ably assisted by Jacquie Meacham, who has done a superb job as assistant PLO.

I thank each and every one of the clerks and the clerks assistant. I thank Harry Evans, who continues to do an exceptional job, and Anne Lynch, who not only does a good job, but who gives me very valuable advice from time to time. This time last year, when I had only been Manager of Government Business for a couple of weeks and I was beginning to tear my hair out, worrying that the whole world would come to an end and that the sky was going to fall in because the government had not got two or three crucial bills through, Anne said to me, `Senator, you don't have to worry. It won't matter that much if these bills don't go through.' Anne, you were quite right; the world did not come to an end over Christmas. When we came back, everything was still in place. The world goes on, and the legislation continues to go through. We just hope it makes Australia a better place.

I thank John Vander Wyk, who works very closely with me. I also thank his staff, particularly Bev Orr and Angie Lilley in the small room outside that door. They have done an outstanding job in keeping this place going. I also thank Dr Rosemary Laing, Cleaver Elliott and Peter O'Keeffe, who all fall into that same category.

In the Table Office, I thank Richard Pye, who provides us with these bizarre statistics about how long we spend here and what we do. I also thank Rosa Ferranda for the excellent job she does in preparing running sheets—and what a job she has done in the last week. It has ben an outstanding job to keep the native title debate on the road, with virtually no glitches on the way through. With only one small exception—and it was not anyone's fault; it was just the senators trying to catch up on the policy issues they had to resolve in here—that debate ran very smoothly. It is a credit to Rosa.

I thank the Black Rod's office—Rob Alison and his staff, including Andrea Griffiths. I also thank the Hansard staff. They come in here and cover what we say for hours and hours on end. They do a superb job. They get here before we get here and they leave long after we leave. They continue to provide an incredibly accurate and professional service. I thank everyone who works in Hansard.

I thank the Sound and Vision Office people who have to take our pictures and keep the television monitors working. I thank the committees and the committee staff. I thank all the other Parliament House staff—and I will go through them in some detail because they all play an equally important role in this place. I thank the attendants. They do an outstanding job. I thank each and every one of you for your contribution—for bringing me something like 532 gallons of water over the past 12 months, numerous pads of paper, pens and thousands of documents that I have to read out. I deeply appreciate your contribution to all of the members of the Senate and to Australia.

I thank the catering staff who keep us all fed—usually overfed. I also thank the crew in the other operations in this building: Lizzie, the hairdresser, whom I get to see about twice a year; the Westpac bank, that I hardly ever visit because there is no money in there for me; the Qantas people; and the people at Aussie's who keep us topped up with high levels of caffeine. They all do a great job.

I thank the Library staff who keep us informed—if that is possible. I also thank PISO, the security people, and the travel staff who have gone through enormous change this year. I would particularly like to thank, under that heading, Bruce Greentree, who is doing an absolutely outstanding job. I hope that Bruce will continue to serve the Senate for a long time to come. I also thank the Jetset people. They have had to set up here under very tough circumstances. My view is that, through a tough transition period, they are providing a very good service.

I also thank the gardeners who give us a fantastic environment to work in. When I am running from one wing of the building to another, I always enjoy running through the gardens and enjoying the ever‐changing vista that they provide. I thank the printing staff, who must print more stuff in any given day in this place than in any other square mile on this earth. I also thank the maintenance people who keep this magnificent building in shape and the cleaners who struggle to clean up the grit and grime that we create.

I thank the gym staff. I visit Lizzie's twice a year, and I have actually visited the gym twice this year as well, but I am sure they look after other the people in this building better than I look after myself. I also thank the nurses in the nurses station who help us incredibly and, most importantly, I thank the Commonwealth car drivers and all the other drivers who get us to and from this building safely.

I have left until last a couple of very important groups of people. I am sure I speak for all senators when I thank members of our personal staffs. I thank the staff in my electorate office in Cannington, Natasya and Anthony; my staff in Perth, Dell; and my staff here in Canberra, Claire, Simon and Karen.

The most important people in all our lives are those whom we are away from for hundreds of days a year—our spouses and our children. They have had to put up with an enormous amount in the last four or five weeks. We have one child here today who is a bit closer to his dad than the rest of the kids of members of parliament. I thank the spouses, boyfriends, girlfriends and partners—or whatever people want to call them in this modern age. They have to put up with life, look after kids, and look after households for days and days on end with their partners hundreds or thousands of miles away from them. Luckily, that is coming to an abrupt end shortly, and we will soon all be back with our spouses.

Madam President, Senate colleagues, and all the people I have just mentioned, we all deserve a long break to recover our sanity and our health. I wish you all a very merry Christmas on behalf of the government, and we look forward to being back here in what will, hopefully, be a very happy new year in 1998.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted to dispense with the suspension of the sitting of the Senate between 6.30 p.m. and 7.30 p.m., which was ordered yesterday? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I, too, would like to make a brief contribution during this valedictory debate. I do recall during last year's valedictory debate that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, said that 1996 had been an exceptionally good year for the new government. I do not think anyone could characterise 1997 as an exceptionally good year or even a good year for the Howard government.

SPEECH.PARA: From an opposition point of view, of course, this has been a year of very great highs, very significant achievements; but I need to also say that there have been some lows. Any opposition would exult in the procession of exits from the government front bench that we have seen this year. Any opposition would revel in this government's plummeting in the public opinion polls—in fact the lowest levels recorded by the coalition parties in well over a decade.

But what opposition would not feel so keenly the distress which led to my former deputy leader, Nick Sherry, earlier this year attempting to take his own life? That was a personal tragedy for Nick and for all his friends and colleagues in the Labor Party. I think it was a very sobering reminder of the sorts of pressures that we bear sometimes in politics. Of all the political events in this year, that is the one that I suspect I will never forget and I know my colleagues will never forget.

I, too, would like to thank all those people who have been responsible for keeping the show on the road over the last 12 months. I join in the thanks that we offer on an annual basis—in fact, more regularly—to the clerks of the Senate. I especially want to thank Rosemary Laing, who looks after our needs, given her responsibilities, so ably and so professionally. I, too, would like to acknowledge the Hansard staff, who manage to meet our almost impossible demands for pinks.

I acknowledge the Table Office and all the staff of the Department of the Senate. I thank the committee staff, the library staff, the attendants, the transport officers, the caterers, the gardeners, the cleaners, the maintenance workers—all those who help and support us here in this building. We do appreciate what they do for us. I know that is a view that is held far more widely than just the senators that sit in this chamber. As far as the opposition is concerned, all our members, senators and staff do appreciate what those that work in this building do for us all.

I wanted to especially take this opportunity to place on record our special thanks and appreciation to Bill Adam from information services who retired this year and Bruce and Kearen from the Senate Transport Office who have served so magnificently for such a long time. Bruce Greentree is moving on to greener pastures. Labor senators just recently took the opportunity to show our very genuine appreciation for all that he has done for us over such a long period. We do sincerely appreciate the efforts of all those members of the parliamentary service. We do acknowledge at this time of the year most appropriately the huge contribution that they make to the efficient functioning of this place. I know that you regularly remind us of that contribution, and I think that is most appropriate, Madam President.

I particularly want to take this opportunity to thank the members of my own team who have contributed to making this such a successful year for the opposition, such a successful year for the Australian Labor Party. I thank the leadership team of the opposition in the Senate; my deputy, Peter Cook, who filled Nick Sherry's shoes and has done so so ably; the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate, Kim Carr; the whip, Chris Evans; his deputies throughout the year; and Senator Ray and his staff, who have given us such able support and given such yeoman service over the last 12 months.

I acknowledge the opposition staff. They are the unsung heroes of this place. They work tremendously long hours. They work fantastically hard for the opposition. I know there are some rewards for that, particularly as they see the stocks of the opposition, the Labor Party nationally, improving. That would not happen without that contribution, without that support, without that assistance, without that commitment. That is really what it is about. We have a tremendously committed opposition staff on the Senate side.

I would particularly like to acknowledge Ruth Webber, our whip's clerk, because Ruth is leaving the Senate and is going to take on even greater responsibilities on behalf of the Labor Party in Western Australia. She has made a great contribution here. We will miss her, but we are delighted that she is able to serve in another capacity and we know that she is going to do a great job there.

I want to sincerely thank my own staff—George, Colin, Vikki, Lenka and Renee here in Canberra and Jenny, Kris and Helen in my electorate office for what they have done. They are a tremendous team who give great support not only to me—they are also appreciated far more widely by other senators and Labor members and, of course, staff on both sides of this building. They have made an enormous contribution. I sincerely and personally appreciate what they have done. I know that they are much valued by so many from the Labor side of politics in this place.

I thank the Labor Senate team. The word `team' really sums up the approach that the Labor Senate caucus has to its work. That goes to the shadow ministers and shadow parliamentary secretaries and other Labor senators. It has been a magnificent performance from our reduced number of Labor senators in this place. It has made an enormous difference to the standing of the Labor Party in the community. We have had a very big task to rebuild over the past 12 months the confidence that the Australian public has in our party. It has been an enormous effort from our Labor senators. It is very much appreciated by me.

Another thing that is very important about the way that we work here is that we have such a terrific working relationship with our colleagues in the House of Representatives—particularly our leader, Kim Beazley, our deputy, Gareth Evans, the Manager of Opposition Business in the House of Representatives, Simon Crean, and the other shadow ministers and members in the House—and staff on the House of Representatives side. We have really been able to meld this operation into a very effective one. It is a very effective team that has some runs on the board. To all those who form part of the Labor team in this building, I certainly want to very sincerely thank you again.

I also acknowledge those from the other side of politics, with whom we work in this building on a day‐to‐day basis. As Senator Campbell has indicated to the Senate, it is never easy in a chamber like this when no one party has a majority. You have to have reasonable working relationships in this place. I thank all those non-Labor senators who have worked with us cooperatively in the best interests of the management of this chamber. I thank you, Madam President, those on your staff and those you work with to preside over this place. Your role is much appreciated by us all.

Let me say to our own team and to others in the building, be they members or senators or staff of members or senators or those who work so hard and are perhaps the unsung heroes of this place: on behalf of the Labor Party I hope you all have a very happy Christmas and a great new year. We in the Labor Party are certainly looking forward to 1998. We think that it will probably be the year that the Labor Party will rebuild even further. In the not too distant future, we are looking forward to being part of the next Beazley Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees, I congratulate you on election to leadership of your party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Thank you, Madam President. I will be brief in commenting on what has been an interesting year. I will add my thanks to the thanks already expressed by Senator Campbell and now Senator Faulkner. I will return to a couple of those who have already been thanked, in particular the clerks in the Senate and all those who deliver to us everything we need as this chamber progresses, and to Hansard and all of those in the library on whom the Democrats, in particular, rely so heavily.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a long year; particularly over the last couple of months it has begun to drag on. I am sure that all of us will be very pleased to get back to home base and to see something of our families again. Over these last couple of weeks it has been very stressful. I especially mention here the five senators who have taken the work of the Wik debate—my colleague Senator Woodley, who has done a magnificent job, along with Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine. Although we have obviously had differences of opinion with Senator Harradine as to where he has finally voted, giving the government the majority of its bill, I respect him enormously for the work he has done throughout this debate. I know he has worked extremely hard with quite a number of advisers.

I especially congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, and the shadow minister, Senator Bolkus, who have been here non-stop hour in and hour out. I was expecting several times either in this chamber or when I looked at the television screen to see that they had been relieved by somebody else coming in and taking over. But neither were going to give an inch. I congratulate them. They in particular deserve a well-earned rest.

I thank my Senate colleagues for their tremendous support during my time as deputy leader, over the last few weeks in my job as acting leader, and in the last 24 hours since the ballot was announced. Thank you especially to all our staff, the individual staff of the Democrat senators, as well as the pool that work for us. It has been a very stressful six weeks for many of them. I wish them well. Some of them have decided to move on, particularly a couple of those based in Queensland.

To everybody, to senators and their staff and all the staff of Parliament House, I wish you a peaceful and relaxing Christmas. I cannot say I actually look forward to getting back to this place next year but, no doubt, as the time rolls closer we will be a little happier to see this place again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Boswell) and the National Party team, I would like to add valedictory comments to those of the other leaders. I make these comments on behalf of the party leader, Senator Boswell, the deputy leader, Senator David Brownhill, the whip, Senator Bill O'Chee, Senator McGauran and Senator Sandy Macdonald. For my part, I bring greetings and thanks not only from the National Party but also from the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, I would like to pay credit to you for the role that you have played this year—the very fine and outstanding leadership and figurehead role that you have played for all of us in what has been both a complex and a difficult year. I refer also to the parliamentary officers who assist you in the chairing of this important chamber and the senior staff—the clerks and their helpers.

It is important to pay tribute to the assistance of all senators having regard to the nature of parliament. It is a bit of a blood sport where controversy tests and makes the arguments to the best degree. I pay tribute to all senators for their roles—those of confusion and of assistance and cooperation.

In particular I draw attention to the untimely death of Senator Panizza earlier this year and the impact that had on all of us in this chamber. I refer also to the illness and incapacity of both Senator Colston and Senator Sherry. Those issues do impact on all of us; we all do feel for them and for their families.

I pay tribute especially to all of the staff. Senator Campbell outlined their duties, their tasks and their names in fine detail. There are thousands of people who assist us in this place, both in a professional capacity and in our parliamentary roles. There are dozens upon dozens of what we would term the support teams who assist us not only with recreation but in so many other essential areas of support that we need in order to be here for the incredibly long hours and the difficult tasks that we undertake.

It is important to recognise the challenging role of our House of Representatives colleagues. They form an integral and important part of this parliament. Without the interaction, the competition and the cooperation that we have with them, the place would not be the obvious success that it is.

BREAK.PARA: We all represent unusual, diverse constituencies and electorates around Australia. Some of us have very large and geographically difficult areas to represent. Others, Madam President, like yourself and Senator Lundy, have very small geographic but again vitally important, significant national electorates to represent.

Those of us who represent rural, regional and remote Australia have that factor of transport built into our daily lives that affects so many other areas on which we concentrate when we are looking at the issues and responsibilities that we must address in this parliament. I acknowledge that we sometimes do bring a bias into our arguments because we represent constituencies that are so far flung.

In our responsibilities in this place, we naturally focus first and foremost on legislation and its impact; secondly, on the budget and the budget processes that are so important to sustain government; and, thirdly, on public administration. Each of these three areas—legislation, budget and public administration—has quite properly been the purview of government for the last 18 months, during which there has been incredible change brought about by the actions of this parliament and the government. I pay credit to everyone, whether it is a public servant, a constituent or a parliamentarian, who has been caught up in that area of change.

Lastly, I would like to extend the National Party's best wishes to all of our colleagues and work friends in so many areas. I would like to extend best wishes for the Christmas and festive season, for the period of recreation leave through January and, of course, for the preparatory month of February when we will all be challenged by the important constitutional convention that will precede our return to this place, hopefully refreshed and rechallenged, in early March.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to sincerely thank the wonderful people who work in this building, from the boiler room to the flagpole. It is a great pleasure to work with everybody here. To you, Madam President, and everybody else in this place, I wish a happy Christmas and a bountiful new year. I am looking forward to seeing a lot more of you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On the valedictories, I wish to make some comments of my own. I start by referring to my friendship and working relationship with Senator West as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I thank her for her friendship and for the way that we are able to work together, and I acknowledge the role of the temporary chairmen in the running of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: At times it is difficult to realise, with the focus of the parliament being on the two chambers—that is, only 223 people—that there are many hundreds who work in this building without whom the parliament could not function. Today provides a brief occasion when we do recall the role that they play.

Within the Senate there is the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans; the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch; and the Clerk Assistants, John Vander Wyk, Peter O'Keeffe, Cleaver Elliott and Rosemary Laing. There are the areas and staff who work with them to see that the chamber functions as it should and, in the case of Peter O'Keeffe, there is Corporate Management. It is a less obvious section of the Senate, but a very important one for senators and members.

As far as the chamber itself is concerned, we are indeed indebted to those of you who are the attendants of the chamber for the highly competent and unobtrusive way in which you look after the chamber, provide the things that are needed and know what is needed. We are indeed indebted to you for that. We are very aware of the demands that have been made upon you in recent times and the shortened hours that you have had for meal breaks and things of a like nature.

Within the Table Office names have been mentioned, but I want to refer to Helen Hueston who is retiring next week after serving the Senate, and serving it very well, for 11 years. We thank Helen for her contribution and wish her well in retirement from this place.

All of us work closely with the Black Rod's Office and the staff of the Black Rod's Office. We are very conscious of the facilities that are provided from there and the necessity for them. In speaking, Senator Ian Campbell also referred to the printing section and the professional role that they play in providing things, generally speaking, I would say, yesterday—that is, at least, when most people want them. To Bruce Greentree, in particular, who has had a very dramatic change to the area in which he has worked, our thanks, and to Darryl Novis, who is in the Transport Office at the present time.

There are many other services, of course, within the Joint House Department. It is a very large department and it would take a very long time to refer to all of them. Most of them are in the basement, which I sometimes think is the most interesting part of the building. I want those people in the basement to know that we do know that you are there. We very much value the service you provide in maintaining this splendid building. It is a building designed to last for 200 years and it will only do so with the constant maintenance, care and attention that has to be given to it on a daily basis. There is no point in letting a building like this run down, thinking that it will be able to be refurbished. That would become almost an impossibility. It is essential for it to be kept in good order throughout. I also refer to John Lloyd and the staff of the gardens. I think the gardens this year, after nearly 10 years, have been absolutely at their best. In particular, I find my courtyard an absolute delight.

We have tenants in the building. Aussies has been mentioned. It is amazing, in a sense, the way that little space has become such a central part of the building. It is not always possible to predict if spaces will become important in a building, but that is. Westpac and Qantas are next to Aussies. We have tenants on the top floor of this building. The Parliamentary Press Gallery people are in and out of the building all the time. I think it is rather nice that we are able to mix with them as easily as we do. The nurses, the hairdresser, the Recreation Centre and more recently Jetset, of course, are tenants of our building. As Senator Ian Campbell said, Jetset have had a very difficult time taking over as they have done.

BREAK.PARA: The other departments in the building are the Department of the Parliamentary Library and Hansard and the services that go from there. We are indebted to the professional standard of research, advice and assistance from the Library and, of course, from Hansard and the Parliamentary Information Systems Office. I think I would have to say that parliamentary information has got well ahead of me. I need a third person between me and the technology of the building to make the best use of it. Sound and Vision and the other areas have grown so much in the last few years.

I value the role and relationship that I have with the leaders of the parties in the chamber, the managers of business and the whips. Having been a whip, I appreciate the role that they play. Generally, they are not recognised as part of the structure of the Senate, but without the efficient operation of the whips' offices very little would occur in here in the way that we would want it to and the way it should happen.

Thank you to the ABC for providing the sound within the chamber and taking us outside the building to others who wish to listen—and enjoy, hopefully—the proceedings of the place. You are unobtrusive back there behind the glass, but we do know you are there and value the role that you play in the operation.
In mentioning the whips, I of course include the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and the staff of those offices.

I am indebted to the staff of my own offices, both here and in my electorate, for what they provide to me and the way they keep the office running in a professional manner. They work very hard indeed.

There are many people that one could mention. I wish everybody who works in the building, and my colleagues the other 75 senators, a happy Christmas for this year and best wishes for 1998. I look forward to seeing you again next year.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I must record, before I begin, my thanks to Senators Tierney and Lundy for allowing me to jump the queue due to my need to catch a flight. Thank you very much. I am going to speak tonight on the subject of Western Australia's old‐growth forests and the WA regional forest agreement which is due to be published shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: As senators will be aware, two seriously flawed RFAs, from our point of view—although not everybody agrees with that—have already been finalised: those for East Gippsland and Tasmania. Both RFAs have been vigorously and rightly condemned by people with a genuine concern for our forests and all the values they contain. We now face the prospect of another abysmal RFA, this time for WA.

I want to state up front that the Australian Democrats in the Senate and my state counterparts in the Western Australian Legislative Council will do their utmost to ensure that Western Australia is not landed with a shonky, deceitful regional forest agreement. We will expose all improper things going on with the Western Australian regional forest agreement whenever we can establish and identify what those things are.

We will also be doing everything we can to convince the Liberal Party, the Labor Party, the National Party and any other parties out there that Western Australia cannot afford and does not deserve a third-rate RFA. No political party should endorse the kind of shonky RFA that we believe WA is heading towards and still maintain any credibility within the WA community at large. As things stand, all indications are that the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement Steering Committee, controlled as it is by the discredited WA Department of Conservation and Land Management and other special interests, is going to serve up an RFA that completely misrepresents the needs and opportunities for forest conservation, forest management and sustainable development in WA.

Right from the outset, CALM has been absolutely determined to control essential information, to conceal the extent and impact of forest destruction and to cover up its appalling lack of knowledge about how to manage forests sustainably. In years to come, when historians look back on this period, I think they will not be kind to CALM executives and their political and commercial allies. Right from the outset, state and Commonwealth ministers have made themselves complicit in a cover‐up and in the concealment that CALM has carried out.

The clearest proof of that cover-up is the exclusion of the community, tourism interests, independent scientists and non-exploitive government agencies from the RFA steering committee. There is an unprecedented level of concern in WA over the continuing loss of WA's unique and irreplaceable old‐growth forests. It is generally accepted, even by some at the highest level of government in WA, that CALM has been a failure and that what remains of WA's old‐growth forests are of far greater value left intact than as woodchips and crude sawn timber.

I want to ask my Commonwealth government colleagues how they expect that an RFA process so obviously under the control and direction of CALM, which has little credibility in WA, can be expected to produce an RFA that the WA community at large will accept. From the outset, there have been many deeply troubling things happening with the WA RFA. Consistent calls from the community for the process to be halted and reformed have been ignored to this date by state and Commonwealth ministers. Those ministers are aware of the massive problems and shortcomings of the WA RFA, and yet they seem to believe that the process can be left to roll on to its predetermined outcome and that the state and Commonwealth governments will be able to sign it and walk away from our forests for the next twenty years. Well, I'm telling you that that is not going to happen.

Ministers must be aware of just how flawed the WA RFA is. It is based on the consistent overstatement of the size and importance of the native forest based timber industry in WA, and a consistent downplaying of the options for transferring wood production from old‐growth forests to plantations and tree crops and the many benefits of doing this, including to the tourism industry. I hope that when the RFA options paper is produced, probably in early January, the full extent of the rorting of the RFA by CALM and other vested interests will be revealed. I have no doubt that this options paper will seriously misrepresent the options and benefits of removing logging from old‐growth forests and will exaggerate the degree of impact this will have, given the small but very important number of workers and communities reliant on native forest logging.

I have no doubt that the report will try to conceal the huge gaps in information and research that should have been available in order to establish a truly comprehensive, adequate and representative conservation reserve system. Already I am advised of grossly misleading maps being produced by CALM—maps that purport to show, for example, the extent of remaining old‐growth forest in Western Australia, yet are designed to minimise that area so as to minimise the amount of forest that needs to be protected in order to meet agreed reservation criteria. How can some ministers sit back and twiddle their thumbs while knowing that so much of the WA RFA is a fraud on the public, future generations and the forests?

My final message to my colleagues on the other side is this: it is still not too late to fix up the WA RFA process. There is enormous interest and knowledge about the forests and the alternatives to their destruction, and that knowledge, which exists in the community, is not being heard in the current process. If you do fix up the WA RFA, it has the potential to be one which does credit to the concept of regional forest agreements. We agree with the concept; we do not agree with the practice.

You could put in place a process that genuinely resolves conflict and produces real, durable win‐win outcomes: for the forests, the community and the industry. I urge you to take the necessary steps to bring this about. Any short‐term flak you may attract from a small but powerful section of the community and a few small but powerful corporate and political interests will be vastly outweighed by the overall community and business support for your intervention, and by the support that the tourism industry will give to such action. So I make one final plea to you to please make the WA RFA work.

In closing, Madam President, I have come to be immensely fond of a great number of people here. I am not going to name them, because I have got only a few minutes, but I do want to wish you all a very merry Christmas and thank you for all you have done this past year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate tonight to unmask misinformation about the current health of the teaching profession. ALP senators, especially Senator Kim Carr, have made some outlandish statements recently about the status of teachers, especially in the state of Victoria. Senator Carr, in the three or four years he has been here, has conducted a non‐stop vendetta against the Liberal Victorian government, particularly on its role in education. He has gone on with a lot of nonsense in the last few years about the actual state of education in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: While he has been focusing on inputs, the most important measure in education is outputs—what the education system is achieving. There has been recently a major scientific report brought down that shows that the sorts of things he has been saying about decreasing quality and about teachers losing self‐esteem are not correct. Let us have a look at the report, which actually counters point by point what Senator Carr has said about the health of the teaching profession in Victoria.

The report I refer to has been incorporated in its entirety into the Hansard record of a Senate committee on the status of teaching. It is the School Management Report of the Office of Review in the Department of Education in Victoria.

The evidence in this report relates to a number of surveys that were conducted in the years 1994, 1995 and 1996. The report presents some very impressive evidence. The survey instruments are highly reliable as measures of teacher sentiment in Victoria. Before I came into this place I dealt with instruments very similar to these in my previous profession as a teacher educator and I am very impressed with the results from this.

The sample is very respectable, being one‐third of the profession in Victoria, and the findings from this survey are very impressive. What they show is consistent improvement across primary and secondary schools, across the years 1994 to 1996 and across all the dimensions that were surveyed.

This is embarrassing news for Senator Carr, and he did try to prevent the incorporation of the results of this survey into the Hansard record of the status of teaching inquiry. We eventually managed to achieve the incorporation of the entire document, so these survey findings I am referring to at the moment are there for everyone to read.

If we look at the particular dimensions that were measured, in terms of changes in outcomes in that school, particularly as they relate to the status of teachers, we find consistent improvement on all dimensions. The first measure was of the quality of work life. Over the three years from 1994 to 1996 this went from 2.87 to 3.10 on a scale from zero to five. Moving towards five shows an improvement. Morale went from 3.07 to 3.31. Leadership increased from 3.38 to 3.65 and goal congruency improved from 3.56 to 3.79.

On all the evidence in this report, there is considerable improvement on all the dimensions measured. The measures on the graphs provided, which have been incorporated in the report, prove this. On the five‐point scale used, the shift in attitude improvement is all in a positive direction.

I am very encouraged by the evidence presented in the management report. It is positive. It shows that in the state of Victoria there is growing self‐esteem in the profession. The position is very healthy in Victoria. It is a very far cry from what Senator Kim Carr has portrayed in this place in a very negative and carping way. He has presented a view of schools in Victoria that does not line up with the evidence.

Senator Carr has spoken increasingly about inputs, but the important measure in education, as I said at the start of this speech, is in outputs. Any improvement in relation to the way that teachers feel about their work and what is happening in their school, along the dimensions measured, is to be welcomed. That is what is happening in Victoria. This is based on scientific data and not just on broad, sweeping allegations. This does put the lie to much of what Senator Carr has said about the state of education in Victoria in this place over the last three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the adjournment debate, I would like to address an issue of vital importance to research, development and commercialisation in Australia. This country has an impressive and unique history of invention and innovation in the pursuit of knowledge. All these characteristics and a recognition of the potential for further research in Australia have been harnessed by the cooperative research centre, CRC, programs.

SPEECH.PARA: These CRCs were designed and implemented by the previous Labor government, but the coalition's stance on CRCs must be brought to this chamber's attention, because this government is, once again, making a series of disastrous decisions, this time with respect to research development and commercialisation opportunities.

The structure of CRCs was influenced by models of collaborative research centres in other industrialised countries. However—characteristically of Australia, some would say—we developed a fluid and flexible model that does not copy other countries' efforts. Instead the Australian CRCs actively involve input from all over the country, from universities, the public sector and industry research bodies, as well as the private sector. Currently, there are 66 centres being supported under the program.

Given the nature and scope of these programs there is not really a typical CRC, but the collaborative nature of the program has resulted in commentators discussing the CRC effect, described by one author as:

. . . the intense activity associated with preparing proposals for CRCs (that) brought many people together for the first time in structured serious discussions about common interests, sharing of facilities, technological transfer and educational possibilities.

One of the primary aims is to capture the benefits of research applicable to Australian industry. The model proposed by the Labor government encapsulated the need to encourage institutions to cooperate and coordinate research efforts and to stimulate education and training, particularly in graduate programs.

The Labor Party also realised that there would be problems in this approach to collective research efforts and, accordingly, implemented evaluation processes during the seven‐year life of CRC programs. One such evaluation of CRCs was included by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in its 1994 report of the inquiry into the organisation and funding of research in higher education.

The positives reflected a primary aim of the government that, by design, CRCs brought together researchers with common interests in science and technology. Industry representatives reported that research links with universities were more stable in the CRC arrangement and that they had been useful in overcoming institutional rivalries. There was also acknowledgment of initial problems and some constructive criticism. The report recommended:

CRC funding levels should be maintained to allow their consolidation. Attention should now be paid to complimenting the initiative with one-to-one project support such as GRID and ARC Collaborative Grants programs to enhance network development around the CRC areas of concentration.
The 1995 review of CRCs by an independent panel puts this history into perspective. The CRC Program Evaluation Steering Committee's report entitled Changing research culture: Australia concluded:

. . . the program is well conceived and the proposals of the Government's broad objectives for the scheme being achieved are excellent. Indeed there is already evidence of a significant and beneficial change in research culture—especially insofar as it concerns universities and their cooperation with government research agencies and industry.
The CRC review also highlighted the success of the program in developing important international links and networks as globalisation continues to affect all countries.

I would like to draw the attention of all those opposite—who have continued to offer platitudes to the Australian community about the way ahead—to the Mercer review of CRCs and ask them to take the time to read it. This review highlights the fact that the program has continued to deliver outstanding success and is now beginning to pay big dividends. Success such as productivity and quality improvements in the filed welding of high strength, thin walled natural gas transmission pipelines from the CRC for Materials Welding and Joining, resulting in a $113 million saving in pipeline construction and operational costs after only one year; or the CRC for Alloy and Solidification Technology who developed technology for continuous casting of magnesium bar and ingot that is expected to make Australian magnesium the product of first choice. This means a realistic expectation of increased investment in smelter expansion, jobs and export earnings.

Apart from the financial benefits, there is a feeling amongst those involved in CRC projects that the Australian model has responded well to this country's various industry expectations. There have been important agricultural, manufacturing, technological and human biological advances. Perhaps the most telling statistic to come out of the recent Mercer review of CRCs was that around 75 per cent of the CRCs surveyed indicated that the commercial breakthroughs and economic benefits gained to date would not have occurred unless the CRC program existed.

Craig Lawn, a partner with Price Waterhouse, provided an overview of the financial benefits of the achievements of CRCs, noting the significant and tangible financial benefits that have already arisen out of the formulation and continuing support of them. He said:
CRCs represent a critical linkage mechanism between business and public based R&D . . . There is a clear desire for stable, pervasive Government policy in this area

The survey by the CRC Association that makes up part of the submission to the DIST-Department of Finance interdepartmental committee represents, according to Craig Lawn, `an important input in the current policy debate'.

After reading the Mercer report in 1996, the previous Minister for Science and Technology, Mr McGauran, said, `The Government's strong commitment to maintaining the CRC program is based on evidence of its significant success.' This was exposed as highly hypocritical because, one month after this statement, this Treasurer (Mr Costello) cut spending on CRCs.

If we examine the budget figures, this evidence is an absolute reality under the Howard government. Previously, Labor had consecutively increased funding to the CRC program but, in John Howard's first budget, the increase in funding was reduced to about 15 per cent of previous increases—to a level of $4.3 million. In the following year's budget, $10 million was ripped out of the CRC program. The Treasurer also announced that they would be undertaking an exercise in looking at increased self-funding, which can be interpreted as nothing more than a thinly disguised code for more cuts. We have already seen these cuts affect the postgraduate programs in the first instance. They have threatened the viability of many centres.

Overlay this issue with the fact that higher education funding has suffered a $1 billion cut over the life of this government, and the cuts to the R&D support for industry are all indicators of the shallowness of this government in actively underpinning the sort of research and development that is required to provide confidence for business and jobs growth in this country. It is not like we have

BREAK.PARA: not had a plethora of reports from industry and other bodies to spell it out for the government. Despite what is acknowledged as a fundamental flaw in the Mortimer report about their rejection of CRCs as a research model, it is good to note that the Goldsworthy report states:

. . . in view of the strategic importance of the information industries in the Australian economy, and of information communication technologies for the productivity and competitiveness of enterprises across the economy, the information industries are not being given their due attention. Government support for R&D relating to information and communication technologies development and applications should be at least equivalent to that available.
That important emphasis on where the CRC programs should be developed must be adhered to by this government if they are to demonstrate any genuine commitment to research and development.

This government must understand that CRCs will disappear if they are not supported by a government that must look towards a long-term approach to policy considerations such as this. The area of research, development and commercialisation is something that must underpin any sound industry development policy and proposals. As Socrates once said, `Knowledge without application is dust.' In Australia, the CRCs provide a unique environment to turn knowledge into a practical source of jobs and therefore a sounder future for all Australians.

ADJOURNMENT.EMPHASIS: Senate adjourned at 7.21 p.m. till Monday, 2 March 1998 at 12.30 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following document was tabled by the Clerk:
Remuneration Tribunal Act—Determination No. 15 of 1997.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 5 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister approved guidelines for funding projects under the Roads of National Importance program, if so: (a) when were they approved; and (b) what are they.
(2) Has the Minister approved guidelines for funding projects under the Black Spots program; if so: (a) when were they approved; and (b) what are they.

(3) With reference to the information provided by the Minister to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee estimates hearing, in response to a question from Senator Conroy relating to the national highway and Roads of Importance program (Senate Committee Hansard, Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, 19 September 1996, p.71), can the following information be provided: (a) an update of all tables provided in that answer; (b) the total amount provided for each category in the forward estimates and the balance that remains unallocated; (c) benefit cost ratios for Roads of National Importance projects which were not included in the answer to Senator Conroy; and (d) for each new project, in addition to the data necessary to conform with the answer to Senator Conroy: (i) a description of the project, and (ii) the benefits that will be achieved and funding arrangements with the States (where applicable).
(4) Can the information requested in (3) also be provided in relation to the Black Spots program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Minister for Transport and Regional Development approved guidelines for funding projects under the Roads of National Importance Program on 16 November 1996.
(b) the guidelines are set out below:
"Roads of national importance will promote regional and national development by:
(a) encouraging inter‐regional and international trade in goods and services;
(b) improving national competitiveness, by maximising transport efficiency and reliability; and
(c) allowing for quick adjustments to the pattern and nature of trade in response to emerging national and international opportunities.

The Commonwealth will provide funding to the States and Territories, on a cost sharing basis, for construction projects (not on‐going maintenance) on roads that demonstrate their national character by satisfying the above and which:
(a) form part of an integrated transport and land use strategy to

PARA.TAB: (i) improve access to major centres of economic activity (for example, manufacturing, agricultural, mining or tourism) by removing bottlenecks or other impediments to efficient road performance, or
(ii) improve links to the National Highway or major transport facilities (for example, ports, road and rail terminals, intermodal terminals and airports), or
(iii) allow people, goods and services to move more freely within major urban and provincial centres, in accordance with the planning objectives for those centres;

ANSWER.PARA: (b) promote improvements in safety, efficiency and reliability, including the use of new transport technologies;
(c) contribute to achieving environmental targets, particularly relating to air quality and greenhouse gas emissions; and
(d) produce net economic benefits.

Commonwealth funding will be conditional on the relevant State or Territory having allocated all the Commonwealth provided untied road grants to roads in the State or Territory and maintaining the existing level of commitment to the road declared to be a road of national importance.

Funding will be focused on those areas of network inadequacy where the largest net benefits, in terms of achieving national economic and social objectives, can be secured in the shortest timeframe, and be subject to the accountability requirements applying to other payments made under the Australian Land Transport Development Program, including open tendering for all projects.
The Government's election commitments will be given priority."
(2) The Minister for Transport and Regional Development approved guidelines for funding projects under the Black Spot program on 15 October 1996.

The guidelines are entitled "Road Safety Black Spot Program: 1996—2000; Notes on Administration". The Program's Notes on Administration have been widely circulated and I a copy is available from the Tables Office.
(3) (a), (c) to (d)(ii) The attached tables provide an update of the material provided to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Com

mittee estimates hearing in response to a question from Senator Conroy. The figures in the tables for 1996‐97 are actual expenditure figures and include some funds unspent from 1995‐96. In relation to the new projects for which notes are contained in the Attachment, unless otherwise stated, all projects are fully funded from the Commonwealth roads program.

(3) (b) The forward estimates provide a total figure for both the National Highway and Roads of National Importance. The amounts paid in 1996‐97 and the amounts currently allocated in outyears to these categories and the balance that remains unallocated are set out in the table below. Amounts for outyears are indicative only.

Note: $22.27m of unspent 1995‐96 funds was been allocated to National Highway projects in 1996‐97. The actual amount of funds available in 1996‐97 was therefore $825.67m. In 1996‐97 $27.4m for general administration expenses was paid to the States under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988, and $2.75m for roads research.
(4) The notional funding allocations to the States and Territories for the Black Spot Program over the period 1996—2000 are as follows:
ROAD SAFETY BLACK SPOT PROGRAM: 1996—2000
NOTIONAL FUNDING ALLOCATIONS

Note: Final allocations may change, subject to a range of factors including the availability of suitable programs of work, maintenance of State expenditure on `black spot' type projects, and participation in the development of the National Exchange of Vehicle and Driver Information System (NEVDIS).
ATTACHMENT
Roads of National Importance
Roads of national importance will promote regional and national development by:
(a) encouraging inter‐regional and international trade in goods and services;
(b) improving national competitiveness, by maximising transport efficiency and reliability; and
(c) allowing for quick adjustments to the patter and nature of trade in response to emerging national and international opportunities.

The Commonwealth will provide funding to the States and Territories, on a cost sharing basis, for construction projects (not on‐going maintenance) on roads that demonstrate their national character by satisfying the above and which:
(a) form part of an integrated transport and land use strategy to

PARA.TAB: (i) improve access to major centres of economic activity (for example, manufacturing, agricultural, mining or tourism) by removing bottlenecks or other impediments to efficient road performance, or
(ii) improve links to the National Highway or major transport facilities (for example, ports, road and rail terminals, intermodal terminals and airports), or
(iii) allow people, goods and services to move more freely within major urban and provincial centres, in accordance with the planning objectives for those centres;

ANSWER.PARA: (b) promote improvements in safety, efficiency and reliability, including the use of new transport technologies;
(c) contribute to achieving environmental targets, particularly relating to air quality and greenhouse gas emissions; and
(d) produce net economic benefits.

Commonwealth funding will be conditional on the relevant State or Territory having allocated all the Commonwealth provided untied road grants to roads in the State or Territory and maintaining the existing level of commitment to the road declared to be a road of national importance.

Funding will be focused on those areas of network inadequacy where the largest net benefits, in terms of achieving national economic and social objectives, can be secured in the shortest timeframe, and be subject to the accountability requirements applying to other payments made under the Australian Land Transport Development Program, including open tendering for all projects.
The Government's election commitments will be give priority.
ATTACHMENT
NEW SOUTH WALES

ROW.ENTRY: Hume Hwy‐residual expenditure for: Cullarin to Yass, Yass Urban link—Pennant Hills Road—widening
Macarthur, Mitchell, Greenway, Werriwa, Prospect, Chifley
Newell Hwy—Moree heavy vehicle bypass study
Indicative funding for a number of major projects yet to be announced

ANSWER.PARA: NEW WORKS
Western Sydney Orbital.
