The funding for 1996‐97 and 1997‐98 will complete the EISs already underway and allow hardship land acquisitions to ensure a route is reserved. No decision has been made on construction.

The project involves construction of a major ring road through western Sydney, which would provide an alternative route to the current heavily trafficked roads and would attract significant industry to the outer west of Sydney.
New England Highway—Thornton Rd traffic lights.

The original NSW proposal was for construction of a major interchange at a cost of over $13m. Following negotiations with the RTA a less costly interim solution of installing traffic lights is being constructed. This will adequately cope with existing traffic and defer construction of an interchange by at least 5 years.
The traffic lights will assist in traffic management at a busy intersection that has a poor accident record.
Hume Highway—Albury/Wodonga Bypass.

The 1996‐97 and 1997‐98 funding is to cover environmental impact studies. Preconstruction work is not scheduled to begin until 1998‐99 although no decision to proceed has yet been made. The level of funding that will be required will depend on the route selected.

The current National Highway through Albury/Wodonga has reached capacity and is causing delays to interstate freight and local traffic. Two options are being considered for providing a four‐lane alternative Hume Highway route at Albury, an internal route and an external route.

Both route options would improve safety, reliability and travel time for long distance and commuter traffic. The internal route would provide a second river crossing with major benefit to local traffic.
Hume Highway—Bookham Bypass
1996‐97 funding for this project was obtained from funds carried forward from 1995‐96 due to savings on other National Highway projects in NSW.

The project will duplicate the next 2 lane section south from Sydney providing continuous 4 lane conditions for more than 500km. Its construction is in accordance with the objective of completing the duplication of the Hume Highway between Sydney and its intersection with the Sturt Highway.
Hume Highway—South Gundagai duplication—duplication of the existing bridge and associated road works.
1996‐97 funding, for preconstruction activities, was obtained from savings on other National Highway projects in NSW. Full construction is not expected to commence until 1999‐00.

This project will duplicate a 2 lane bridge (Sheahans Bridge) which is situated in a length of four lane duplicated highway, which has safety implications. Its construction is in accordance with the objective of duplicating the Hume Highway between Sydney and the intersection with the Sturt Highway.
Barton Highway—Murrumbateman bypass
It is proposed to fund planning for a bypass of Murrumbateman, a rapidly expanding township on the Barton Highway in 1998‐99. Construction is not planned to commence until 1999‐00.
The bypass will eliminate delays at this point on the Highway, which connects to the Hume Highway near Yass, and is consistent with the long term strategy of duplicating this road.
New England Highway—Belford Bends
This project will construct a four lane divided road on a new alignment to replace a section of road with a poor accident record.
Moree Bypass Study
A feasibility study into a heavy vehicle bypass of Moree on the Newell Highway.
Sutton to ACT border—duplication

This is the final project to complete the duplication of the Federal Hwy linking Canberra to the Hume Highway near Goulburn. Construction is scheduled to commence in 1999‐00 following the completion of the Lake George project.
F3—Driver aid system

The F3 is the National Highway link between Sydney and Newcastle and is approaching capacity. The driver aid system will use variable signs to warn of changed traffic conditions ahead and to change speed limits in emergencies.
Weakleys Dr interchange
Construction of an interchange on the New England Highway north of Newcastle at an intersection with a poor safety record.
Roads of National Importance
Pacific Highway Reconstruction Program

In NSW, the program will progressively upgrade continuous significant lengths of the Pacific Highway to four lane divided standard and bypass most major towns. This will be achieved by using the existing asset as much as possible and undertaking a number of new deviation road projects.
In the initial 3 years of the program, the two worst sections will be targeted, the Chinderah to Billinudgel and Coolongolook to Bulahdelah sections.
The Commonwealth has asked NSW to provide a BCR for the entire Pacific Highway project. This is being calculated.
Funding Arrangements

The Commonwealth has committed to provide $60m per year (in real terms) over 10 years on condition that NSW matches this funding on a $1 for $1 basis and maintains its announced Pacific Highway reconstruction program.
Kidman Way
The project involves sealing of sections between Hillston and Bourke of an existing road to create an all weather link between Victoria and western Queensland.
Funding Arrangements
The Commonwealth has agreed to provide $20.7 million over three years. Any additional funding will be provided by the Councils involved.
Summerland Way

The project involves upgrading the Summerland Way, which runs from the Pacific Highway at Grafton north to Beaudesert, to 2 lane highway standard; with an allowance for investigating route deviations across the border ranges.
Funding Arrangements

The Commonwealth has offered to provide $20 million over the next four years conditional on the NSW Government maintaining its announced investment of $50m over 5 years. The NSW Government accepted this offer in June and an agreed program of works is to be negotiated with NSW.
VICTORIA

ROW.ENTRY: Western Ring Road—eastern extension to Edgars Rd
Ballarat Bypass—Gillies St to Sunraysia Hwy duplication (Stage 4)
Ballarat Bypass—Woodmans Hill to Gillies St (Stage 3)
Western Highway—Western Freeway realignment to WRR planning
Western Highway—Leigh Creek to Woodmans Hill planning
Goulburn Valley Hwy—O/taking lanes Shepparton to NSW border
Western Hwy—O/taking lanes Ararat to SA border
Western Hwy—Deer Park to Hopkins Rd grade separation (planning)
Western Hwy—Bridge widening at Fiery Creek

ANSWER.PARA: NEW WORKS
Western Ring Road Eastern Extension—from Mahoneys Rd to Edgars Rd.
This 3km section of the Ring Road will link to State funded work further east. Commonwealth funding will be limited to the NH component of the work.
Goulburn Valley Hwy (GVH)—Shepparton approach duplication
Duplication of a short section of a heavily trafficked road on the outskirts of Shepparton.
Duplication will reduce delays due to lack of capacity and reduce accident rates at this section of road.
Hume Hwy—Donnybrook Rd interchange
Grade separation at an intersection with a poor safety record.
Roads of National Importance
Calder Highway—Bulla Rd intersection

Construction of an interchange at the intersection of the Calder Hwy with the Bulla to Diggers Rest Rd to reduce delays on the Calder Hwy and remove an at grade intersection with a high accident rate.
Calder Highway—Black Forest section
Duplication of a section of the Calder Hwy in accordance with the strategy to duplicate the Hwy between Melbourne and Bendigo.
Calder Highway—Woodend section
Duplication of a section of the Calder Hwy in accordance with the strategy to duplicate the Hwy between Melbourne and Bendigo.
Funding Arrangements
Commonwealth funding for the Calder Hwy is on the basis that the Victorian Government matches the contribution on a $1 for $1 basis and maintains its planned expenditure on the Highway.
QUEENSLAND

ROW.ENTRY: Gateway Arterial—Sandgate to Depot Roads, noise amelioration measures
Bruce Hwy—Rockhampton to Townsville overtaking lanes
Bruce Hwy—Armstrong Creek to RM Creek
Barkly Hwy—widening Cloncurry to NT border
Barkly Hwy—Johnson & Buckley R bridges planning
Bruce Hwy—University Rd, Townsville: Mark Reid Drive to Flinders Highway

ANSWER.PARA: NEW WORKS
Bruce Hwy—Edmonton (Cairns)
A highly warranted project to duplicate a heavily trafficked section of the Bruce Hwy on the southern outskirts of Cairns.
Bruce Hwy—Woolcock St (Townsville)
A highly warranted project involving duplicating and upgrading work within the city.
Bruce Hwy—Duckworth St (Townsville).
A highly warranted project involving duplicating and upgrading work within the city.
Bruce Hwy—Gunalda Range

The upgrading and realignment of a 4km section, which traverses the Gunalda Range between Gympie and Maryborough, to improve travelling conditions and passing opportunities. The section is the location of frequent delays due to the combination of a high percentage of commercial vehicles and a lack of overtaking opportunities.
Warrego Hwy—Toowoomba Bypass Corridor Study

Funding for a study and to reserve the route of the bypass and a new route down the Toowoomba Range. If the route is not reserved it will be lost to urban development. Construction is unlikely to be warranted before 2010.
Warrego Hwy—Oakey Bypass
This is a relatively low cost project with a high BCR that will remove road trains from Oakey.
Landsborough Hwy—Thomson River Bridge
Replacement of a bridge west of Longreach in central Queensland. The bridge will improve the flood immunity of the Landsborough Hwy and increase its utility for road trains.
Construction is not proposed to commence until 1998‐99.
Ron Camm Bridge—Mackay
Duplication of a major bridge in Mackay which is currently operating close to capacity.
Yandina—Cooroy duplication
The next stage of the duplication of the Bruce Hwy north of Brisbane dictated by the rapid growth of this region. Construction is not expected to start until 1999‐00.
Roads of National Importance
Pacific Highway Reconstruction Program

The highway will be widened to six lanes for 6.4km between Smith Street and Pappas Way including a new Nerang interchange, widening to eight traffic lanes between Pimpama and Oxenford, including interchanges at major intersections, and new bridges to carry eight lanes of traffic will be constructed over the Coomera River.
Funding Arrangements

The Commonwealth has committed to provide $15m per year (in real terms) over 10 years on condition that Queensland matches this funding on a $1 for $1 basis and maintains its announced Pacific Highway upgrading program.
Yarralla Rd Study

The study is to examine the issues associated with the alignment of the Warrego Highway between Dalby and MacAlister. In particular the study will examine the economic benefits of a new alignment in terms of reduction of journey times, flood immunity, vehicle operating costs and improved safety for motorists.
Marlborough to Princhester

This project involves construction on a new alignment of 6.2km of the Bruce Highway between Marlborough and Princhester to eliminate a sub‐standard alignment with a poor vehicle accident record and to improve the flood immunity of this section.
Cooloola to Curra

This project involves the widening and rehabilitation of the Highway between the Cooloola Shire boundary and Curra, 14km north of Gympie and includes the construction of a passing lane and intersection improvements.
Bowen—Ayr (Dalberg‐McDesme)

This project involves the construction of a north bound overtaking lane and overlay of existing pavement. The completion of this overtaking lane project will reduce congestion, improve safety and provide greater transport efficiency between Bowen and Ayr.
WESTERN AUSTRALIA

ROW.ENTRY: Great Eastern Hwy (GEH)—Roe Highway to Scott St
Mt Keith to Wiluna (Kalgoorlie to Meekatharra Rd)

ANSWER.PARA: NEW WORKS
Eyre Hwy—widening program

Continues a program of reconstruction and widening of the Eyre Hwy. The current pavement was constructed in the 1960s and has reached the end of its economic life and is below the width requirement for today's traffic volume and vehicles.
Great Northern Hwy—Bullsbrook overtaking lanes

High BCR project involving construction of two northbound and one southbound overtaking lanes in the town of Bullsbrook adjacent to Pearce Airforce Base to enhance the safety of the turn‐off to the base and facilitate safe through traffic.
Great Eastern Hwy—Old Sawyers Road to Old Northam Road

Reconstruct and realign this section of the Great Eastern Highway. This is the first stage of the Sawyers Valley to the Lakes duplication. The work will substantially improve safety by improving the geometry of the road and reducing accidents and maintenance costs.
Great Eastern Hwy—Sawyers Valley to the Lakes Duplication

Project brought forward from 1999 for safety reasons—this section was the site of six fatalities in six weeks in mid‐1995. Completion of this and other projects underway will provide 48km of duplicated carriageway from the Roe Highway in Perth to the Lakes.
Great Northern Highway—Roe Highway to Lennard Street (Midland to Muchea)

This single carriageway section of GNH carries between 12,000 and 20,000 vehicles a day, of which some 25% are heavy commercial, through the Swan Valley on the outskirts of Perth. Work proposed is safety orientated to widen, construct and seal shoulders, provide passing lanes and improve access and junctions with the GNH in the Swan Valley.
Great Northern Highway—Roebuck Plains south of Broome.

This 10 km section of the NH is built at natural formation level on a flood plain and is flooded every wet season, leading to failure of the existing pavement. The project will stabilise and repave the road.
Great Northern Highway—Laurel Downs to Plum Plains west of Fitzroy Crossing.

This is the last section of the current upgrading works between the Broome turn‐off and Fitzroy Crossing. The pavement is severely degraded and flood affected and at the end of its life in terms of maintenance.
Great Northern Highway—Little Panton and Spring Creeks bridges
Construction of bridges to eliminate current flood prone creek crossings in the Kimberly region.
Karalundi section—widening

This section is the last of the single lane sections of the National Highway. The project will widen the road to two sealed lanes and achieve the objective of eliminating the single lane seal sections of the National Highway.
Roads of National Importance
Extension of Mitchell Freeway
The project will involve extending the Mitchell Freeway from Ocean Beach Road, Cragie to Hodges Drive, Joondalup. The Freeway is the major corridor to Perth's expanding north western suburbs.
Funding Arrangements
The Commonwealth has agreed to provide $25m to Western Australia over four years from 1997‐98 for this project.
Upgrading of Mt Keith to Wiluna Road
The upgrade of the road consists of sealing the Mt Keith to Wiluna section of the Kalgoorlie to Meekatharra Road.
Funding Arrangements
The Commonwealth has agreed to provide $15m to Western Australia over four years from 1997‐98 towards the $35m cost of this project.
SOUTH AUSTRALIA

ROW.ENTRY: Dukes Hwy—Tailem Bend to Keith overtaking lanes
Adelaide‐Pt Augusta Rd—overtaking lanes north of Pt Wakefield
Eyre Hwy—Ceduna to Lincoln Gap widening
Sturt Highway—Greenock to Truro planning including Moppa Rd and Bastion Hill passing lanes
Main North Road widen between Grove Way to Kings Road (construction)
Main North Road widen between Kings Road and Montague Rd (construction)
Dukes Hwy—Keith to Vic border overtaking lanes

BREAK.PARA: NEW WORKS
Port Wakefield Rd and Salisbury Hwy—access improvements
These works will allow road train access to Adelaide.
TASMANIA

ROW.ENTRY: Midland Highway‐ Hobart Northern Approaches Study
Bass Hwy—Stage 2 Precon Deloraine to Hagley
Bass Hwy—Stage 3 Deloraine to Violet Banks
Bass Hwy—residual expenditure for: Pateena Rd to Illawarra MR, Liffey R to Hagley, Victoria Br duplication

BREAK.PARA: NEW WORKS
Bass Hwy—Westbury to Hagley

A continuation of the realignment and duplication of the Hwy between Deloraine and Hagley. The project has been delayed due to heritage issues concerning the Hagley Mill. Construction is not proposed to commence until 1998‐99.
Roads of National Importance
Devonport port access road
Construction of an access road to the port area of Devonport to allow easier access for heavy vehicles.
Funding Arrangements

The Commonwealth has offered to provide one third of the funding for this project in collaboration with the State and local governments. The Commonwealth has also offered to provide $300,000 for initial land acquisition. The Tasmanian Government has yet to respond to the offer.
NORTHERN TERRITORY

ROW.ENTRY: Victoria, Stuart & Barkly Hwys—repair of flood damage
Hugh, Finke, Palmer & Manton R. Bridges

BREAK.PARA: NEW WORKS
Victoria Hwy widening
Will complete a major project ($100m) of reconstruction and elimination of narrow seal on the Victoria Hwy.
Elizabeth River Bridge
Replacement of a bridge on the southern approaches to Darwin that is prone to flooding in the wet season.
Bridges over Hugh, Finke, Palmer and Manton Rivers
These works are to allow the proposed increased mass limits for heavy vehicles to be applied in the NT.
Roads of National Importance
Tiger Brennan Drive
Construction of an access road to the new port area of Darwin.
Funding Arrangements
The Commonwealth agreed to make a once only payment of $2.5m towards the $7.5m cost of this project.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

ROW.ENTRY: Federal Hwy—NSW Border to Stirling Av

BREAK.PARA: NEW WORKS
Federal Highway—Sutton Rd to Stirling Avenue
This project will complete the duplication of the Federal Highway. Planning studies are currently underway but physical works are not planned to commence until 1999‐00.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What contracts for public relations services has the department, or its agencies, signed since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the value of each contract.
(3) Did the value of any contract vary from the original cost; if so, what was the reason for the price variation.
(4) How many of the contracts in (1) were awarded following an open tender process.
(5) Where there was no tender process, what assessment criteria were followed in selecting the contractor and why was the normal practice of calling tenders not followed.
(6) Did the department seek guidance from the Office of Government Information and Advertising before signing the above contracts; if not, why not.
(7) How many journalists were employed by the department as at 3 March 1996.
(8) How many journalists are currently employed by the department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: DEPARTMENT
(1) (i) Ray Andrews and Associates for the Research & Development Communication Strategy.
(ii) Communique Public Relations for the Industry Innovation Fund, (formerly the Small Business Innovation Fund), and related marketing activities.
(iii) Peter Cotton, Journalist, 19 December 1997, for specialist media services in relation to the 1997 Australia Prize announcement and presentation ceremony.
(iv) Total Communication and Media Consultants for a series of `ecoawareness' videos intended for screening on airlines and in other appropriate situations.

(3) (ii) The Communique Public Relations contract varied from the original cost. The original contract was for $10,000. Following the Government's launch of the Industry Innovation Fund, (formerly the Small Business Innovation Fund) the contract was extended by one month to undertake additional services marketing the fund, at the additional cost of $10,000.

(iv) An additional cost of $2,560 was incurred when extra components of the project were undertaken. During the project's life the opportunity to extend the reach of the project for a nominal cost became available.
(4) (i) Ray Andrews and Associates were chosen from a select tender list drawn up in consultation with the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA).

(ii) While the tender process for (i) was underway, Communique Public Relations were appointed, at the recommendation of the Industry, Research and Development Board, and with agreement from OGIA, to undertake short‐term public relations work.
(iii) See response to part (5) (iii).
(iv) The campaign production work was contracted using a selective tender process.
(5) (ii) See the response to part (4).

(iii) The contractor was previously engaged for the 1996 Australia Prize and was selected after a limited tender process. Legal advice was received that if we were satisfied with the past product and satisfied as to value for money we could again use the same contractor without a tender.
(iv) See the response to part (4).

(6) (i), (ii) OGIA was involved in both consultancies. OGIA was represented on the selection panel which short‐listed Ray Andrews and Associates to go before the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications (MCGC).
(iii) Yes.

(iv) During the preparation of the contract, April 1996, telephone advice was provided by OGIA as they were in the course of announcing new policy processes. However, the brief sent to the tenderers was drafted in accordance with OGIA's guidelines.
AGENCIES
Australian Industrial Property Organisation (AIPO)
(1) (i) Woolcott Research Pty Ltd for the provision of services for the development of new business and service delivery strategies.
(ii) Emery Vincent (trading as Graphicus) for a corporate image and marketing strategy.

(iii) National Recording Studios (NRS). Two contracts were signed with NRS, each for $18,000, to produce video segments on the protection of indigenous Australians' intellectual property. These were included in a video news magazine prepared by NRS for the Aboriginal and Torres Straits Islander Commission (ATSIC).
(iii) Two contracts at $18,000 each.
(3) (ii) The value of the Emery Vincent Corporate Image and Marketing Strategy contract was reduced to $73,000 following termination of the contract.
(4) One.

(5) (i) Following a limited tender by five companies (nominated by OGIA), Woolcott Research Pty Ltd was selected to undertake a client survey for AIPO. Following the successful delivery of the client survey, AIPO engaged Woolcott Pty Ltd a second time as the company is familiar with AIPO and its customer base and has proved itself capable of working with AIPO. The fees charged by Woolcott Research Pty Ltd have remained constant.

(iii) NRS had been contracted for three years by ATSIC to produce a video news magazine and AIPO was asked to supply segments on the protection of the intellectual property of indigenous Australians. The Attorney‐General's Department and the Department of Communications and the Arts were consulted.
(6) See response to part (5).
Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO)
(1) Keys Young Pty Ltd, for a community attitudes survey seeking views on nuclear related and ANSTO issues.
(3) Yes, by $2,000. To provide for additional fieldwork.
(4) The contract followed tenders invited from companies identified by the Office of Government Information and Advertising.
(6) Yes.
Australian Tourist Commission (ATC)
(1) As at 31 August 1997, the Australian Tourist Commission had entered into the following contracts for public relations services in the period since 3 March 1996:
(i) Lou Hammond and Associates (United States)
(ii) LBP Communications (France)
(iii) PRAP Japan Incorporated (Japan)
(iv) Alternative Travel Marketing (Scandinavia)
(2) The value of each contract is:
(3) The contracts have not concluded.

(4) Contracts (i), (ii), and (iii) were based on selective tendering processes. In relation to contracts (ii) and (iii), these were the renewal of 12 month agreements, following the satisfactory performance of the first 12 months as agreed to in the initial contract.

(5) The normal practice was not followed in relation to contract (iv). Given the unique knowledge required by the agency and the restricted geographic location (Scandinavia), the ATC renewed its existing contractor only after significant efforts to identify other suitable alternative agencies proved fruitless.
(6) No. As the contracts were undertaken with overseas companies, it was not considered applicable in these instances to consult with OGIA.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Minister's media statement, Australian Support for World Food Program:
(1) What was the budget allocation for development food aid to the United Nations World Food Program for: (a) the 1996‐97 financial year; and (b) each of the previous ten years.

(2) In metric tonnes, how much food aid was bought in Australia and sent to developing countries in: (a) the 1997‐98 and 1996‐97 financial years; and (b) each of the 10 financial years before this date.
(3) (a) At which countries does the Government target its provision of food aid; and (b) how much goes to each country.
(4) Can details be provided on how much the countries in (3), and the amount they received in Australian aid have changed over the previous decade.
(5) Which non‐government organisations does the Government engage to deliver its projects.
(6) How does the Government decide which projects and programs are chosen as recipients of Australia's aid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The budget allocation for development food aid to the World Food Program (WFP) in 1996‐97 was $53.98 million.
(b) The budget allocation for development food aid to WFP for each of the previous ten years is attached at Table 1.

(2) (a) In the 1996‐97 financial year the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) purchased 184,954 metric tonnes of food aid in Australia for shipment to developing countries. This comprised 147,645 tonnes of wheat, 22,309 tonnes of wheat flour and 15,000 tonnes of rice. It is anticipated that AusAID will purchase in the vicinity of 180,000 metric tonnes of food aid in Australia in financial year 1997‐98 for shipment to developing countries.
(b) The annual quantities of food aid purchased by AusAID for the financial years 1986‐87 to 1995‐96 inclusive are attached as Table 2.

(3) (a) and (b) In 1996‐97, Sri Lanka (6,064 tonnes), Mozambique (19,450 tonnes) and Bangladesh (50,000 tonnes) were targeted as recipients of Australian bilateral food aid. In the case of development food aid provided through WFP, the Government has directed fifty percent of our contribution to WFP be targeted as food aid to China (34,300 tonnes) and Bangladesh (39,700 tonnes) in 1997‐98. Relief food aid is provided in response to a number of factors. These would include an analysis of the needs of those affected, the appropriateness of food aid as a response, the scale and nature of the emergency and Australia's capacity to assist. There is therefore some variability in respect of the countries to which Australia provides relief and emergency food aid depending on these factors. The countries to which Australia provided relief and emergency food aid in 1996‐97 are attached as Table 3.
(4) Details on the amount of food aid provided by Australia to developing countries, as detailed in the response to (3) above, over the past ten years is attached as Table 4.

(5) No Australian NGOs were directly engaged by AusAID to deliver food aid in the 1996‐97 financial year as all food aid was provided either bilaterally or through the World Food Program. In the 1997‐98 financial year, most of Australia's food aid will again be provided either on a bilateral basis or through WFP. WFP frequently contracts NGO's, including Australian NGO's or their international partners, to distribute food aid in its projects. Following the recommendations of a recent AusAID review of food aid, Australian NGO's will be invited to submit proposals for the provision of any emergency food aid in 1997‐98.
(6) Factors which are considered in deciding to provide Australian food aid vary according to the type of food aid.
In respect of development food aid this may be provided either on a bilateral basis or a multilateral basis through WFP.
Decisions on the provision of bilateral food aid are made in close consultations with the recipient government and in the context of the overall country program development strategy.
In respect of development food aid provided multilaterally, the Government recognises the need for WFP to have flexibility in managing its global program. The Government therefore provides up to

fifty percent of its funding to WFP's development program as an undirected contribution which WFP utilises according to its development food aid priorities. The remaining fifty percent is directed by the Government, through WFP, to specific countries based on an assessment of relative needs and in accordance with the overall regional priorities of Australia's aid program.

In respect of humanitarian and emergency situations, food aid is provided in response to appeals by the recipient government or international organisations such WFP. Decisions to provide humanitarian and emergency food aid are based on a consideration of a number of factors as outlined under 3(a) and (b) above.
Table 1: Australia's Budget allocation for WFP Development activities

ROW.ENTRY: Funds allocated to WFP Development ($ million)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Community Grants Funding

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What was the basis for determining which organisations continued to receive funding; and (b) which organisations had their funding cut or discontinued.

(2) Why has funding been cut or discontinued for: (a) the Buddhist Society which covers members of the Sri Lankan, Thai and Burmese communities; and (b) the Chilean, Filipino, Iranian and El Salvadorean community organisations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) All community grants expired on 30 September 1997 and a new funding round commenced on 1 October 1997. Around 1100 applications were assessed in terms of their capacity to meet nationally and/or locally identified settlement needs. These applications were assessed under the following criteria:
. the relationship of proposals to identified priority needs;
. the relevance of proposal to DIMA's settlement program objectives;
. whether the applicant could be considered for funding by another Commonwealth/State agency;
. the perceived viability of the organisation and its ability to effectively carry out the work program;
. the appropriateness of strategies proposed in the work program; and
. for project‐based awards, the strategy proposed for following-up project outcomes after the grant period.

(b) No organisation had their funding cut or discontinued, as such, as all grants funded in 1996‐97 expired on 30 September 1997. However, those organisations which received funding in 1996‐97 and which were awarded less funding in the 1997‐98 round were the:
. Cambodian Welfare & Cultural Centre;
. Croatian Welfare Association;
. Geraldton Regional Community Education Centre;
. Lady Gowrie Centre;
. Macedonian Welfare Association;
. Refugee Council of WA; and
. Vietnamese Community in WA.
Those organisations which received funding in 1996‐97 and received no funding in the 1997‐98 round were the:
. Buddhist Society of WA Inc;
. Chilean Welfare Association `Pablo Neruda' Inc;
. Damayang Filipino Inc;
. Ethnic Communities' Council of WA;
. Iranian Cultural Society of WA Inc;
. Salvadorean Association of WA Inc; and
. The Romanian Community of WA Inc.
Those organisations which received funding in the 1997‐98 round but not in 1996‐97 were the:
. Balga Anglican Administration Support Service;
. Broome Multicultural Society;
. Christmas Island Neighbourhood Centre;
. Conference of Churches;
. Communicare;
. Muslim Women's Support Centre of WA;
. North Perth MRC;
. Patricia Giles Centre; and
. Sexual and Relationship Assault Centre.
Those organisations which received funding in 1996‐97 and were awarded funding in the 1997‐98 round were the:
. Australian Asian Association;
. Association for Services to Torture and Trauma Survivors;
. Balga Detached Youth Work Project;
. Bunbury Migrant Resource Group;
. Cambodian Welfare and Cultural Centre;
. Catholic Migrant Centre;
. Child Migrants Trust;
. Chung Wah Association;
. Croatian Welfare Association;
. Fremantle Migrant Resource Centre;
. Geraldton Regional Community Education Centre;
. Greek Orthodox Welfare Association;
. Italo‐Australian Welfare and Cultural Centre;
. Lady Gowrie Centre;
. Macedonian Welfare Association;
. Northern Suburbs Migrant Resource Centre;
. Refugee Council of WA;
. Uniting Church Frontier Services;
. Vietnamese Community in WA;
. Vietnamese Women's Support Community; and
. WA Association of Polish Women.
(2) Funding for the 1997‐98 round was not awarded to:

(a) the Buddhist Society; and (b) the Chilean, Filipino, Iranian, Romanian and El Salvadorean community organisations as their applications did not address the identified priorities to the same degree as other applications. The Department also considered that the needs of these communities could be met by other organisations in the Perth metropolitan area.

For example, the Filipino, Chilean, El Salvadorean, Thai and Burmese communities will have access to Community Settlement Services workers funded to work at the Fremantle Migrant Resource Centre, Northern Suburbs Migrant Resource Centre, Catholic Migrant Centre and North Perth Migrant Resource Centre. An additional worker has been funded to cover the developing Kwinana‐Rockingham area. These workers are strategically placed to cover the widest possible geographic area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Government's announcement on 13 December 1996 that from 1 February 1997 the Australian Customs Service would reduce the time taken to examine applications for anti‐dumping from 25 to 20 days:
Has this occurred; if not, why not.

(2) With reference to the Government's announcement on 13 December 1996 that from 1 February 1997 the Australian Customs Service would cut the time to establish a preliminary finding from 100 to 85 days:
Has this occurred; if not, why not.
(3) With reference to the Government's announcement on 13 December 1996 that Australia's anti‐dumping and countervailing arrangements would be referred to the Industry Commission for report in 1997:
(a) Has this occurred; if not, why not; and (b) when is the commission expected to report.
(4) (a) Which of the Willett Report recommendations do not require legislation for their implementation; and (b) which of these have been, or are being, implemented.
(5) With reference to the Government's announcement on 13 December 1996 that recommendations of the Willett Report not implemented would be taken up as part of the reference to the commission:
Has this occurred; if not, why not.

(6) With reference to the Government's announcement on 13 December 1996 that it would not deliver on any of the recommendations in the Willett Report requiring legislation until after the Industry Commission report is delivered:
(a) Is this still the situation; and (b) if the commission is not to be given such a reference, when will the Government implement the Willett Report recommendations requiring legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes

(2) Since 1 February 1997, the ACS has set an operational target for preliminary findings of 85 days. The three investigations completed since then (PVC, wheel rims and coated paper) have not been completed within that target due to their size and/or complexity (see table below).
(3a) Australia's Anti‐Dumping and Countervailing arrangements have not been referred to the Industry Commission.
(3b) Unknown
(4b) 1, 2, 4, 6, 7 (the recommendation relating to electronic publication of the index to the public file and of the entire file has not been implemented), 8, 9, 11 & 16.
(5) & (6) The Government is continuing to review the recommendations of the Willett Report.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industry, Science and Tourism: Research

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Parts (1) to (4)

As the Senator's question on qualitative and quantitative research could take in the day to day research of the Department and the portfolio agencies, I am not prepared to authorise the utilisation of Departmental resources to provide a complete answer to the Senator's question.

Some of the information sought by the Senator has been previously tabled in Parliament in the 1995/96 and 1996/97 Annual Reports of the relevant portfolio agencies. As stated on page 146 of the 1996/97 Department of Industry, Science and Tourism Annual Report, information on consultancy services is available from the department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 October 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Japanese Government, or any of its agencies, approached the Australian Government with an offer to negotiate a mutually beneficial arrangement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by shifting Japanese steel production to Australia; if so, what was the nature of the offer and what was the Australian Government's response.

(2) If an agreement was reached between the Japanese and Australian Governments to shift part of Japan's steel production to Australia: (a) by how much would greenhouse gas emissions be reduced (per tonne of steel), taking into account the change from coal-based blast furnace technology to natural gas based, and the potential for increased use of recycled scrap; and (b) by how much would Japan benefit as a result of cutting subsidies to industry.
(3) Is the Australian Government open to agreements such as this as a means of achieving targets to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Not applicable.

(3) Shifting production of emission intensive industries to Australia, such as steel production, will not result in a reduction of Australia' s greenhouse gas emissions. To the contrary, it will cause Australia's greenhouse gas emissions to rise. This highlights one of the difficulties Australia faces in the current climate change negotiations that, under the Climate Change Convention, accounting for emissions is production-based rather than consumption-based.

All other things being equal the global environment would benefit from reduced total greenhouse gas emissions of a shift from coal-based production in Japan to natural gas production in Australia. However, one weakness of the current production-based approach under the Framework Convention on Climate Change to establishing emission targets is that it cannot sensibly deal with such national circumstances. The approach Australia has been advocating in the Berlin Mandate negotiations, of taking national circumstances into account in establishing fair and realistic targets, addresses this.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Tax Office: Hobart Office Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many staff in the Hobart Tax Office: (a) were employed in March 1996; and (b) how many staff are currently employed.

(2) Are there any plans to further reduce the number of staff employed in the Hobart Tax Office; if so: (a) how many positions are to be removed; and (b) what is the timeframe in which these further reductions are to take place.
(3) How many staff who left the Tax Office over the period March 1996 to date: (a) were dismissed; (b) resigned; (c) retired; and (d) accepted a redundancy package.

(4) (a) Does the Hobart office deal with all inquiries from the general public or are some inquiries referred to other offices; and (b) if some matters are referred to other offices, what matters are referred and to which offices are they referred.
(5) Are any matters referred to the Hobart Office from other offices for action; if so, what is the nature of the matters referred to the Hobart office.
(6) Has the referral of some matters to other offices impacted on the workload of officers employed in the Hobart Tax Office; if so, how have officers been effected by these arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In March 1996 there were 416 staff employed in the Hobart Tax office.
(1) (b) As at 31 October 1997, 390 staff were employed in the Hobart Office.
(2) (a) Yes. It is expected that 7 positions will be removed.
(2) (b) 2 positions will be removed by December 1997 and a further 5 positions will have been removed by 30 June 1998.
(3) (a) No staff were dismissed; (b) 14 resigned; (c) 13 retired and (d) 25 accepted a redundancy package.

(4) (a) The Hobart office deals with the majority of inquiries from the general public however some specialised matters are directed to other ATO offices.The Hobart office also handles counter enquiries and direct telephone enquiries to particular areas of the Hobart office.

(4) (b) Certain calls are redirected to hotlines, or to officers with specialist knowledge in certain fields. Superannuation enquiries and variations of tax instalment deductions are referred to the Moonee Ponds office and Higher Education Contributions Scheme enquiries are referred to the Cheltenham office.

(5) Yes. The regional telephone networks have the effect that telephone enquiries are referred to the Hobart office from other offices in the region and vice versa. Hobart office has also, on occasion, dealt with enquiries from South Australia and Western Australia.
Work that has been referred to Hobart office from time to time from other offices in the region includes:
advisings, appeals, debt collection, tax file number work, income matching work,a special project in relation to foreign source income, and human resource services.

The Hobart office took on some 3,000 Child Support cases from Queensland in mid‐1995. However, an undertaking has been given to the Industrial Relations Commission that those cases will be returned to Queensland and this is expected to occur in April 1998.

(6) The transfer of work to other offices has not unduly affected the workload of staff in Hobart, largely because concurrently, work has been transferred into Hobart office. The main change for officers has been a change in types of work, not a change in workload.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 29 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 876 (Senate Hansard, 27 October 1997, p.8005) which provided information about Commonwealth funding for energy research and development (R&D) projects:

(1) In relation to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO): (a) what amount of money in each of the research categories listed at question (7a) is Commonwealth funding; and (b) what projects make up the $5.05 million for renewable energy. (please list project title and proponent).
(2) In relation to the Renewable Energy Industry Program (question 9a) what projects make up the $1.167 million funding. (please list project title and proponent).

(3) Are there any other sources of Commonwealth funding for renewable energy R&D apart from those listed in the answer to question on notice no. 876, namely, the former Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC), R&D Start, Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy, CSIRO, and the general 125 per cent tax concession for company R&D; if so, please list them and the amounts allocated.

(4) Are there any other sources of Commonwealth funding for fossil fuel R&D apart from those listed in the answer to question on notice no. 876, namely, the former Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC), Cooperative Research Centres, CSIRO, R&D Start, and the general, 125 per cent tax concession for company R&D; if so, please list the amounts allocated and the areas of research.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Energy R&D Expenditure in 1995‐96

ROW.ENTRY: Minor elements in lead for batteries
Battery Energy South Pacific/CSIRO/ Qld Department of Mines & Energy/ Advanced Lead‐Acid Battery Consortium
Advanced lead/acid batteries for electric vehicle

ANSWER.PARA: Proponent is the organisation proposing/initiating the project. Most projects are "joint development" and all parties funding it are proponents.

(2) $1.167 million has been approved to support the commercialisation of Australian renewable energy technologies under the Renewable Energy Industry Program. The following projects make up this total:

ROW.ENTRY: Systematic study of a number of sites in India, in conjunction with the Electrification Corporation Limited of India (REC) to identify remote villages that are capable of electrification by renewable/hybrid systems.
The provision of funding for the development of manufacturing processes for the production of low cost photovoltaic cells.
The provision of funding for market research into and the commercialisation of efficient small wind turbine blades.
The establishment in Australia of pilot manufacturing facilities for a limited production run of the Vanadium Redox Battery.
The establishment in Australia of a 250kW pilot manufacturing facility for small scale commercialisation of Titania Solar Cells.
The establishment of a pilot plant that will form the core of an automated production line for photovoltaic receiver modules.

ANSWER.PARA: (3), (4) In relation to parts 3 & 4, there is no other funding available, within this portfolio, other than that mentioned in answer to question on notice no 876.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware from media and other reports that Swine Fever is rapidly spreading throughout Europe.
(2) Is the Minister concerned that overseas imports of pork into Australia have the potential to introduce Swine Fever into Australia.
(3) What precautions is the Government taking to ensure that overseas imports of pork will not affect our domestic market.
(4) If Swine Fever is introduced into Australia, what measures does the Government have in place to prevent its spread to domestic herds.
(5) If Swine Fever gets into Australia: (a) what compensation will be available to Australian pork producers; and (b) under what conditions or circumstances will such compensation be guaranteed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister is aware of these reports.
(2) Under the strict requirements developed for the importation of pig meat Australia is not at risk from the introduction of classical swine fever in this way.

(3) Conditions for the importation of pig meat from Canada, Denmark and New Zealand, those countries from which Australia currently imports uncanned pig meat, require that the country be free of classical swine fever and other serious diseases of pigs for at least 6 months prior to the slaughter of the pigs from which the meat is derived, that the pigs pass ante- and post-mortem inspection under official veterinary supervision and that the meat be handled in a manner approved by AQIS.
(4) Quarantine restrictions on the handling of the imported product, including wastes and scraps, are designed to prevent access by, and possible infection of, pigs.
In addition, each State/Territory has legislation which prohibits the feeding of food refuse, including meat, to pigs unless it has been adequately treated.

Each State/Territory has legislation, which is nationally consistent, for the control and eradication of exotic animal diseases, including swine fever. This legislation has provisions to prevent the spread of disease between herds.

(5) (a) The Commonwealth/States Cost Sharing Agreement for the Eradication of Certain Exotic Animal Diseases (the Agreement) provides for the Commonwealth, the States, the Northern Territory (NT) and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) to share the costs of eradicating specific exotic animal diseases, including swine fever. It may also be known as the Commonwealth-States Cost Sharing Arrangement.

(5) (b) Arrangements under the Agreement only apply in cases where the eradication measures are carried out according to plans recommended by the Consultative Committee on Exotic Animal Diseases (CCEAD) of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) and approved by that Council.

Each State, the NT and the ACT is responsible for implementing eradication measures in that State or Territory which are required to be carried out according to the plans approved by ARMCANZ. The Commonwealth is responsible for the provision of services by Commonwealth bodies (eg CSIRO) which are called for by CCEAD.
Initially, each State, NT, the ACT and the Commonwealth would be responsible for financing their own costs, but subsequently all eligible expenditure incurred by each State, the NT, the
ACT and the Commonwealth would be reimbursed according to the Cost Sharing Arrangement.

In the event of the Cost Sharing Arrangement being invoked, the Commonwealth would contribute 50% of the eradication and associated control costs, and the States, the NT and the ACT will collectively contribute the remaining 50% on an agreed pro-rata basis.
Legislation has been enacted in each State, the NT and the ACT to implement the Agreement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware from media and other reports that Post-weaning, Multisystematic Wasting Syndrome is rapidly spreading throughout Europe.
(2) Is the Minister concerned that overseas imports of pork into Australia have the potential to introduce this syndrome into Australia.
(3) What precautions is the Government taking to ensure that overseas imports of pork will not affect our domestic market.
(4) If the syndrome is introduced into Australia, what measures does the Government have in place to prevent its spread to domestic herds.
(5) If the syndrome gets into Australia, what compensation will be available to Australian pork producers.
(6) Under what conditions or circumstances will the Minister guarantee the Pork Producers of Australia such compensation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister has been advised by AQIS that postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) is a newly recognised condition causing wasting and death in recently weaned pigs (6—14 weeks of age) in the prairie provinces of Canada. No specific agent has been determined to be the cause although a circovirus which has been associated with the disease is thought to play a role in its causation. A similar condition has also been reported from some areas in the United States, France and Spain. It is not correct, as asserted by Senator Woodley, that PMWS is rapidly spreading throughout Europe.
(2) For a number of reasons imported pork is not considered to pose a risk of introducing PMWS:
. PMWS is a disease of young pigs post-weaning. It has not been reported in slaughter age pigs.

. There is no evidence that PMWS is transmissible via pig meat. Pathological lesions have not been found in the muscle tissue of affected pigs and muscle tissue from affected pigs has tested negative for the circovirus associated with the disease.
. Pigs from which meat is derived for export to Australia have to pass antemortem and post-mortem inspection under official veterinary supervision ie be free from clinical signs of disease.

(3) For the reasons outlined in answer to part (2) of Senator Woodley's question, above, imports of pig meat are not considered to represent a risk from the introduction of PMWS and no precautions, additional to those already in place in the quarantine requirements, are considered necessary in relation to PMWS.
(4) Quarantine restrictions on the handling and treatment of the imported pig meat, including wastes and scraps, are designed to prevent access to the material by pigs.
In addition, each State/Territory has legislation which prohibits the feeding of food refuse containing meat to pigs unless it has been adequately treated.

Each State/Territory has legislation, which is nationally consistent, for the control and eradication of exotic animal diseases. This legislation has provisions to prevent the spread of disease between herds.
(5) The Government's general preparedness policy is to provide a rapid response to exotic animal disease incursion incidents, with the preferred aim

of stamping out the disease. There is no provision to compensate affected industries for income losses, although in specified cases there is provision to pay fair market value for the destruction of livestock in the outbreak area pursuant to the eradication program.
PMWS is not included in the current list of specified diseases, which is as follows:
Vesicular diseases

PARA.TAB: foot-and-mouth disease
vesicular stomatitis
vesicular exanthema
swine vesicular disease

ANSWER.PARA: Rinderpest
Classical swine fever (hog cholera)
African swine fever
Rabies
Newcastle disease (in its classical virulent form)
Virulent avian influenza
Bluetongue (in it classical virulent form)
Screw worm fly

(6) A national review of the list of exotic diseases subject to compensation for compulsory destruction of livestock is currently being managed by the Australian Animal Health Council Ltd (AAHC). A decision on including PMWS will be made in light of the outcome of the AAHC review.
JOHN ANDERSON MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Deputy Leader, National Party of Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Leader of the Government in the Senate, on Tuesday, 25 November 1997 (Hansard page 9095‐9096):

QUESTION.PARA: Whether it is the Prime Minister's intention to seek parliamentary sanction in the event that Australia's offer for the World Trade Organisation negotiations on financial services is taken up and embraced by others.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I should emphasise that the Government's offer is conditional on other countries putting forward significant improvement to their offers, so improving the ability of Australian companies to export financial services to other economies. In accordance with the Government's reform of the treaty‐making process, the final step for undertaking obligations binding under international law in relation to a Protocol to the General Agreement on Trade in Services—if that is what emerges from the current multilateral negotiations—will not be taken until the proposed treaty action has been tabled in both Houses of Parliament for at least fifteen sitting days. During that period of consideration, it would be inquired into and reported upon by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.

In addition, if any legislative changes are necessary to give domestic effect to the Protocol, they must have been passed by any of the Australian Parliaments (Commonwealth or State and Territory) that are involved before Australia takes binding action.
